DOC.HEAD: Nation's Largest Polystyrene Recycling Center to Open in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Schneiders is cq
DOC.TEXT: A huge plastic recycling center will open this fall to reuse all the cheeseburger holders, foam coffee cups and other fast-food detritus from restaurants, hospitals and schools, officials said Friday. ``This a positive step for the environment and for Southern California,'' said E. James Schneiders, president and chief executive officer of the National Polystyrene Recycling Co. ``We know people here want to recycle polystyrene and we are making that possible.'' The company will own the 55,000-square-foot plant currently under construction in Corona, a western suburb, and TALCO Recycling Inc. will operate it, said Schneiders. It will open in October. The company also is planning to open centers in the San Francisco, Chicago and Philadelphia metropolitan areas by the end of this year, Schneiders said. Schneiders and TALCO president and owner John Shedd announced the new center at Wadsworth Elementary School, where students participate in a program to recycle lunch trays made of polystyrene. Students from 17 Los Angeles Unified School District campuses have recycled more than 1.5 million foam lunch trays. National Polystyrene opened the first polystyrene recycling center in the United States. Plastics Again, the plant in Leominster, Mass., can recycle up to 3 million pounds of used polystyrene annually. The Corona plant will be able to recycle more than 13 million pounds of drink cups, plates and eating utensils, along with non-food packing products such as packaging foam and foam containers. The plant will pay four cents a pound for polystyrene materials. Although individuals can drop off their used molded plastic, center officials expect most clients will be companies and institutions, such as hospitals, schools and fast-food restaurants. At the plant, the materials will be washed, ground, rinsed and then melted down. The material will then be formed into long spaghetti-like strips, run through a cold water bath and chopped into little pellets. The pellets can be resold to companies that make polystyrene products. ``Polystyrene had been recycled for years before recycling became a public issue,'' Schneiders said. ``What is new now is the post-consumer recycling of polystyrene. ``Maybe eventually curbside pickup programs will include polystyrene, along with aluminum cans, newspapers and glass bottles,'' he said. ``We sure would like that.''

DOC.HEAD: Official: Navy Explosive Tests to Continue
DOC.TEXT: The Navy will continue underwater explosive tests off Key West, a military official said Friday, despite a confrontation with two dolphin lovers that led to a $10 million lawsuit and a federal investigation. Several more tests are planned, but times and locations are secret, said Joe Cody, a spokesman for the Naval Air Development Center, a wing of the Navy that develops aircraft systems and other military components. Some environmentalists claim the tests harm dolphins and threaten fragile coral reefs. On Thursday, two animal rights activists who claim they were rammed by boats during a protest last week filed a $10 million suit against private companies hired by the Navy to carry personnel and equipment for the tests. The Dade Circuit Court suit by Russel Rector and Richard O'Barry claims they were struck by vessels from Miami-based Moby Marine Corp. and General Offshore Corp. of Key West. The two companies are charged with assault, intentional infliction of bodily harm and negligence. Officials at both companies said Friday they had not seen the suit and could not comment. They were hired to take part in the tests by the Navy. Cody, speaking from the development center's headquarters in Warminster, Pa., said an attorney has been assigned to the case. He had no further comment. The FBI said it was also looking into the allegations from Rector and O'Barry, who trained a dolphin that appeared on the 1960s television show ``Flipper.'' Hospital records indicate the men suffered bruises and sprains. O'Barry had a concussion. They had swum into the test area to try to block the test of the 1,200-pound explosive, which in fact already had been detonated. O'Barry halted an earlier test by hanging onto a buoy in the off-limits zone.

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad Radio Begins Propaganda Broadcasts at U.S. Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The voice of the Baghdad Radio announcer boomed onto the airwaves in fractured English, addressing U.S. soldiers: ``Do you want to go back home from the Arabian desert ... psychologically broken?'' Iraq's new English-language program, broadcast on shortwave radio, stepped up the anti-American rhetoric its Arabic media services have waged for weeks. Taking a cue from broadcasters such as Tokyo Rose and Axis Sally during World War II and Hanoi Hannah in the Vietnam war, the programs featured an eclectic mix of news, music and mockery meant to demoralize soldiers rushed in to Saudi Arabia since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. During the hourlong program, the broadcaster asked, ``Remember what the petrol emirs are doing to American girls. Do you want to defend them?'' In addition to alleging immoral gulf emirs had ``enjoyed'' the company of U.S. women, the broadcast mentioned faraway loved ones, desert heat, quicksand, rising taxes in the United States, war injuries and U.S. soldiers missing in action in Vietnam. The brief messages were interspersed with music. About 30 seconds of Big Band swing tunes that Tokyo Rose herself might have used was followed by: ``To the American soldier in the Saudi Arabia desert: Would you like to be one of the cripples who are only lamented in the charity ceremonies? Do you want to go back home from the Arabian desert and you are psychologically broken?'' Then would come some taped middle-of-the-road music that seemed more appropriate in elevators or a few bars from one of Lebanon's Westernized composers. There were also ``special reports.'' One listed pro-Iraqi demonstrations ``disrupting world capitals,'' another was a tirade against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for trying to destroy the Iraqi economy this year by overproducing oil and driving down prices. A third analyzed the objective of the United States in sending up to 250,000 troops to Saudi Arabia, claiming the main purpose was occupation. The Bush administration has said the troops were there for defensive purposes. Talk radio it wasn't. The format was heavy with long sentences and standard phrases that are the hallmarks of anti-American rhetoric in the Arab region. Lines such as ``imposing American Zionist schemes on the Arab nation'' were unlikely to win the hearts and minds of many U.S. enlisted men. It could not be immediately confirmed that the programs were monitored by the troops in Saudi Arabia. The male broadcastor, speaking in British-accented English, made most of his appeals in the form of questions: ``To the American soldier in the Saudi Arabia desert: How do you fight against Iraq and you know that there are more than 200 churches in it? Do you want to kill a Christian like you and to be killed by him. Will you be pleased to be ended like this?'' With the U.S. buildup the largest since the United States pulled out of Vietnam in 1975, that war was an inevitable topic: ``To the American soldier in the Saudi Arabia desert: Ask your friends about what had happened in Vietnam. The American soldiers' corpses are still lost in Vietnam after they had been eaten by worms.'' And the harsh conditions were also stressed. ``Why do you come to the burning desert?'' the broadcaster asked. Another time he said, ``Didn't you hear the sand dunes in the Saudi Arabian desert are moving and they swallowed many people and they will swallow you?'' It added, ``Also guys, the Islamic Organization in Colorado has condemned the invasion.'' Mentioning home states was a favorite of similar broadcasts during World War II and the Korean War. Back then, many of the U.S. troops did not get broadcast news from home for days. Sexy female voices and the playing of American Top 20 records were meant to get the troops grumbling about the war and missing home. Germany used Axis Sally to say things like ``Hello gang, throw down those little old guns and toddle off home. There's no getting the Germans down.'' Lord Haw-Haw, a British-American citizen, was another broadcaster who made similar statements beamed toward London. He was executed for treason while Japan's Tokyo Rose and Axis Sally received prison terms of 10 to 12 years.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Soldiers Give Saudis Cover for U.S. Military Buildup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A symbolic Arab force being created to help protect Saudi Arabia from its hostile neighbor Iraq pales beside the massive fighting machine the United States is sending. The contributions of Egypt, Syria and Morocco will be relatively small at best, and it is hard to pin down just what those countries are sending. The main significance of the force appears to be that it enables the Saudis to justify the American presence by telling Arabs leery of foreigners that brother Arabs have also come to their rescue. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, architect of the Arab League resolution that brought about the Arab commitment, says Syria and Morocco will join Egypt in sending troops. Moslem but non-Arab Pakistan and Bangladesh say they will also send troops. The force will be a few thousand at most, insignificant as a military threat to 160,000 Iraqis massed with tanks on the Saudi border. ``We are sending not more than 2,000 soldiers to help the Saudis, under the command of the Saudi Arabian armed forces,'' Mubarak told reporters at Alexandria. ``I don't compare our forces with the U.S. forces.'' The Pentagon on Washington has said the United States force might eventually reach 250,000 if necessary. Little has been said officially about the Moroccan and Syrian forces, which sources in the Persian Gulf area have said would total about 5,000 men each. Official sources in Rabat said Morocco has dispatched 1,200 soldiers so far. Syrian officials have said nothing about the their force. Saudi diplomats reported earlier in the week that Syrian soldiers had arrived, but Col. Andrew Duncan of the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies said he understands they amount to nothing more than a planeload of staff officers. Duncan added that the Arab force appears to include the wrong kind of soldier needed to face Saddam Hussein's strike forces. ``The sort of forces coming in really aren't the best things to use in armored warfare in the desert,'' Duncan said by telephone. ``Once elite paratroopers make their marvelous parachute drop, they don't have much more they can do'' against tanks. Egyptian Defense Ministry sources have said Egypt is sending commandos, paratroops, chemical-warfare specialists and infantrymen. The Defense Ministry has not said how many soldiers are going. In a statement Friday, its first on the deployment, the ministry said: ``Elements of the Egyptian armed forces left the homeland . . . (and) have arrived in the areas of operation assigned to them in Saudi Arabia.'' On Aug. 10, Mubarak pushed through an Arab League summit conference the resolution establishing the joint force. The idea purportedly was to help Saudi Arabia defend itself if Iraq invades via Kuwait, which it seized on Aug. 2. The resolution also gave Arab approval to the Saudis' request for U.S. help for Saudi Arabia's U.S.-armed 123,000-man military. Complaints from Arabs began as soon as the invitation was announced. Feelings on the subject run so high that Mubarak's resolution passed at the Arab summit by a bare majority. Twelve of the 20 leaders attending voting ``yes.'' Six of the 12, including Saudi Arabia and Kuwait's ousted government, were gulf states concerned about Iraqi expansion. Military analyst Duncan said even a 15,000-man Arab force would be ``still token, especially if you're only talking about men. They would need something to fight with other than rifles and machine guns.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Battle Heat, Foreign Culture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following is based on a pool dispatch.
DOC.TEXT: Both American troops and their Saudi allies are experiencing some culture shock these days. The most obvious surprise for the Saudi forces has been the presence of women in the U.S. military, particularly the Air Force. A group of Saudi airmen stood in stunned silence the other day as an American woman working a supply line in the triple-digit heat took off her uniform shirt to work in her T-shirt. She was asked to put her full uniform back on. An Air Force captain assigned to an AWACS plane said she often finds Saudi airmen assigned to the crews staring at her. ``They seem shocked at first, but they're extremely polite and I think they're getting used to it,'' the North Carolina native said. ``It must be a strange sight for them.'' Meanwhile, U.S. forces are in a country where alcohol is illegal, shorts are considered offensive and virtually all activity grinds to a halt five times a day for prayers. Even Saudi soldiers, some of whom are working side by side with Americans, stop for prayers. For now, as they are briefed on Saudi and Muslim customs and try to get accustomed to the searing heat, Americans troops are not being allowed to make recreation trips into Saudi cities, although some are housed temporarily at local hotels. The Saudis have been extraordinarily gracious hosts, even as they are occasionally taken aback by the ways of their allies. But both Saudi and American officials say there likely will be at least a few incidents if the U.S. military presence here is a prolonged one. ``When you have two cultures that are so different, so fundamentally different, there are bound to be some conflicts,'' a Saudi government minister said this week. ``But we are confident that we can keep them to a minimum.'' The culture clash comes at an already stressful period of Saudi history. The oil boom took Arabia out of obscurity and the past two decades have brought an incredible development boom in major oil and urban areas. The Saudis are reaching out to the West for help in development and business, while at the same time fighting to maintain their strict, religious traditions. To help keep the balance, the Saudis have tight restrictions on foreigners; only those with work contracts are allowed into the country and almost all of them live in wall-ringed compounds. Suddenly, thousands more Americans are on Saudi soil, most of them young and unfamiliar with Arab and Saudi traditions. The U.S. military is taking a number of steps designed to keep Saudi-American interaction, military actions excepted, to a minimum. Troops interviewed this week seem to understand, although they're not always happy about it. ``The guys sure would like a cold one,'' an Air Force captain said Thursday from the sun-drenched tarmac of a Saudi air base. ``Tell the folks back home to send in the Budweiser plane,'' an Army tank gunner said earlier in the week. Some of the misunderstandings are innocent, but, to the Saudis, offensive. Several Saudi military officials were sitting with U.S. troops early in the week when the Americans served field rations for lunch. Two pork dishes were among the choices offered; Muslims do not eat pork. The greatest cultural adjustment revolves around the presence of hundreds of U.S. military women here for Operation Desert Shield. While the co-ed U.S. military forces banter about, Saudi men and women rarely interact in public beyond quiet conversation. Most Saudi women wear ankle-length black robes, covering their heads and usually their faces with black headdresses and veils. Saudis consider it offensive for women to wear pants, particularly shorts or blue jeans, and Saudi women will hiss at women they consider dressed inappropriately. The women in the U.S. military contingent have been advised to wear the robes _ abayas _ when they venture out in public. ``I think it would be too risky to go downtown without it,'' a 21-year-old female Air Force senior airman from Mount Clemens, Mich., said Thursday. ``I'm not going to take any chances.'' It's unclear when the U.S. forces will be able to wander about in Saudi cities. Officers from each of the services said this week some recreational activities will have to be planned if the stay here drags on much longer, and there is every indication that it will. ``We are guests of the Saudis and we need to be aware of their cultural concerns,'' said Air Force Col. John McBroom. ``We'll brief them (American troops) and tell them what to do and not to do and if they don't do it right we'll send them home. It's that simple.'' Americans have been on Saudi soil since the 1930s, when an expedition drilling for water struck oil, triggering Arabia's interaction with the Western world. ``I think we Saudis always, because of the oil find, have associated Americans with our good fortune,'' a Saudi government official said over lunch this week. ``We are very different, but we have a positive bond.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Operation to Liberate Kuwait Impossible Now, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: With seven Iraqi divisions in Kuwait and another 24 near the Iraq-Saudi border, European and Israeli military analysts say a U.S.-led military operation to liberate Kuwait would be outnumbered and outgunned. The best option for the moment, the experts say, is to go on barricading the ports of Iraq and its friends. They say the forces now assembling in Saudi Arabia should dig in, trust their superior weapons to deter further Iraqi aggression, and wait for Iraq to make the first move. ``But the problem is tension is growing because Iraq is now able to move more forces across the border,'' said Paul Beaver, publisher of Jane's Defense Weekly. ``The risk of escalation is there because there are going to be so many forces in Saudi, most of whom can't talk to the other _ usually a recipe for disaster,'' he said in an interview Thursday. According to Jane's latest estimates, Iraq has seven divisions in Kuwait and 24 on the Iraqi-Saudi border. ``We're talking of them having available now south of Baghdad 400,000 soldiers,'' Beaver said. With a flight landing in Saudi Arabia every seven minutes, the U.S. military force is approaching 50,000, Jane's estimates. But Col. Andrew Duncan of the International Institute of Strategic Studies estimated it would take a six-month buildup of U.S. forces to be strong enough to oust the Iraqis from Kuwait. He said the Americans currently have only a few old, light Sheridan tanks in Saudi Arabia and would need heavy armor for any serious push. ``I would say it's pie in the sky to say there's any military option to invade Kuwait,'' Duncan said. The United States would have less than one mechanized division there by September, and would need at least five to push the Iraqis out and keep them out, he said. Francis Tusa, European editor of Armed Forces Journal International, said another question was whether the Saudis would allow 250,000 or 300,000 U.S. troops on their soil, given the opposition of many Arabs to the American presence in the Middle East. ``I would hang back. I would let the Iraqis make the first move, and let them make a serious move,'' he said. ``The Iraqis, politically speaking, have to do something pretty flagrant and massive before the Arabs will be happy with a U.S. response.'' Dore Gold, a senior analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, said the main American option would be ``a massive air attack on the Iraqi military infrastructure.'' ``But most do not believe that you can use the air force to force ground troops to retreat,'' he said. Beaver said many military strategists believe air attacks against economic targets like power stations and desalination plants would work. But the ramifications are at present ``far too fraught for the Americans to contemplate,'' he said. Ian Anthony, a researcher at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, said the U.S. Air Force could also hit strategic targets like highways that channel supplies from Jordan to Iraq. But neither side is eager to escalate the conflict, he said, because ``for either side now, the next step is likely to have extremely serious consequences.'' Dore said another reason for holding off on action now is that both sides believe time is on their side. ``The U.S. believes that the sanctions against Iraq will be felt in several months, while Iraq feels that the larger mercantile international system will start to cheat in a few months' time and the enthusiastic Arab national support for (Saddam Hussein) will eventually undermine economic sanctions,'' he said. The one thing the multinational force can do is effectively blockade ports, Beaver said. ``That means Mersin in southern Turkey, Aqaba in Jordan, and of course the neck of the gulf or the Straits of Hormuz to prevent Iraqi traffic going in and out,'' he said. But Beaver added that Iraq's sudden decision to settle the eight-year war with Iran could rupture the stranglehold if Tehran opens its border with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Hero Worship Lead to Albert Schweitzer Foundation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The spirit of Albert Schweitzer has found an unlikely home on a quiet street in Connecticut, thousands of miles from the African village where the late theologian, philosopher and doctor spent much of his life as a medical missionary. Inside the Albert Schweitzer Memorial Foundation, large black and white portraits of the Nobel Peace Prize-winner stare down from the walls, interspersed with printed quotations from his work. Relics of his life crowd the first-floor rooms of the small house, including busts of Schweitzer, with his craggy, mustachioed face, and a book the great humanitarian inscribed to Maria Lagendijk, the Dutch nurse who worked with him at his hospital in Lambarene, a small village in the West African country of Gabon. ``You know how as young people you always find a hero, a star you can cling to? That's exactly how it was for me,'' said Harold Robles, the foundation's director, recalling the time when he learned of Schweitzer as a boy in a classroom in Rotterdam, Holland. Robles, an international telemarketing executive who moved to the United States in 1981, turned his lifelong fascination with Schweitzer into a public monument when he established the foundation in 1983. His collection today is used by Schweitzer scholars from around the world. But Robles said his greatest contribution to Schweitzer's memory will occur in New York Thursday with the start of the two-day International Albert Schweitzer Colloquium at the United Nations. Robles spent 2{ years organizing the colloquium, timed for the 25th anniversary of Schweitzer's death on Sept. 4, 1965, at the age of 90. Such renowned figures as Noble Peace Prize winners Oscar Arias Sanchez, Elie Wiesel and Linus Pauling will speak on ``The Relevance of Albert Schweitzer at the Dawn of the 21st Century.'' Rhena Schweitzer Miller, Schweitzer's daughter, is serving as an honorary chairwoman. She said the gathering, which already has attracted nearly 700 people, will help people see the continuing relevance of her father's philosophy. ``He talked about many things before his time,'' she said, reciting his interest in such contemporary issues as the environment and nuclear war. Because of the West African hospital he designed and built in 1913, Schweitzer is known to most people as a famous doctor, Robles said. He spent most of his life in the remote village, establishing a leper colony and a large general practice. But Schweitzer had numerous other accomplishments that are less widely known. His book ``The Quest of the Historical Jesus'' influenced a generation of theologians. A gifted musician, Schweitzer wrote a groundbreaking biography of Johann Sebastian Bach in 1905 and published Bach's complete organ works, because he also was an organist. But in his own mind, Schweitzer seems to have thought of himself first and foremost as a philosopher, said Robles. In a quotation Robles is particularly fond of, Schweitzer said: ``When you portray me, it should not be as the doctor who ministers to the sick. It is my philosophy of Reverence for Life that I consider my primary contribution to the world.'' Robles' first wrote to his hero when he was 8. Schweitzer wrote back, telling him to study hard and finish his schoolwork before making any great plans to come to Africa. Robles continued to write to the hospital, beginning what was to be a lifelong correspondence with Lagendijk, the nurse who was working with Schweitzer in Africa. The woman would write on Schweitzer's behalf and pass on requests from the young boy. When Schweitzer visited Rotterdam when Robles was 11, Lagendijk made sure the boy was on the list of those to meet him. Robles said people always are amazed by the fact that he remembers little of this one face-to-face encounter he had with his hero. ``The way I met Schweitzer and the way I admire him and came to know him is through his books,'' Robles said. ``I read him over and over and over again, and that is how I met the man.''

DOC.HEAD: Sea Lion Squatters Return to San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf
DOC.TEXT: If a guy can't hit it off with those sun-baked Southern California females who like to play in the surf, he can always go back to San Francisco and sit on the dock of the bay. Especially if he's a sea lion. Last year, hundreds of squatters with fish breath descended on a dock near the city's famed Fisherman's Wharf tourist attraction and made themselves at home. Now many are back. The 100 or so sea lions on Pier 39 are just ``a bunch of really lonely guys,'' said Ann Maurer of the California Marine Mammal Center in Marin County. They are ``young males that couldn't establish themselves with females during the mating season in the channel islands off Santa Barbara,'' she said. Except for a lack of sea lionesses, the pier ``is everything a sea lion could ask for,'' Maurer said. ``As far as the sea lions are concerned, K dock is just another strip of beach with plenty of sun and a lot of fish just over the side.'' Their choice of residence brings them in close contact with humans, many who have never seen the lumbering ocean mammals outside a zoo. The barking, sometimes pushy sea lions are protected under the federal Marine Mammals Protective Act and may not be harassed, hunted, captured or killed. About 300 of the animals that can weigh up to 800 pounds took up residence on Pier 39 last year, with most departing by spring. They began returning last weekend, Peigin Barrett, executive director of the marine center, said Friday. ``They come and go with the fishing and breeding seasons,'' she said. ``What's unusual is to see them in one place and so close to humans. They are only about eight feet away with just a railing separating them from people.'' Business owners for Pier 39, which contains tourist shops and amusement arcades, called the marine center for help when sea lions started congregating at the dock last year. ``Neighbors complained about all the noise from the animals,'' Barrett said. Ultimately, the sea lions were simply left alone. The pugnacious critters are not intimidated by the boat people who normally inhabit the 20 or so berths on the dock. The harbor's managers moved the boats for the duration of their seasonal visit. ``We give them that dock when they show up, move out boats to other docks,'' said Pier 39 spokeswoman Alicia Vargas. ``It's live and let live, and as long as we've got the space to spare, they're welcome to it. Besides, they're kind of cute and the tourists like them.'' Barrett said the sea lion invasion can teach people more about sea life. ``People get a close look at the sea lions. It is very educational,'' she said. ``There were several sea lions that had fishing debris around their necks and the public could see the damage caused by carelessness.'' The current complement is likely to stay until springtime, then try their luck again next year in mating competition on the islands. ``Get used to it,'' Barrett said. ``As far as the sea lions are concerned, Pier 39 is home.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actor Nicolas Cage admits he has bizarre tastes in film roles, almost as off-beat as those of producer David Lynch, with whom he worked on the new deep blue comedy ``Wild at Heart.'' ``I've followed his movies ever since I saw `Eraserhead,' and I've seen all of them,'' Cage said. ``I was a big fan of Lynch, so, when I started working with him, I was a little bit nervous.'' Like his 1986 film ``Blue Velvet,'' Lynch's gory, spaced-out creation ``Wild at Heart'' is anything but mainstream. In it, Cage plays Sailor Ripley, an ex-con with a snakeskin jacket, a habit of aping Elvis Presley, and a chain-smoking sexpot for a girlfriend. The 25-year-old Cage said he doesn't feel out of place. ``My taste is sort of left field,'' Cage said. ``It's not that I'm trying to be underground, it's just that's what I like.'' A nephew of Francis Ford Coppola, Cage played a 1930s gangster in ``The Cotton Club,'' Kathleen Turner's boyfriend in ``Peggy Sue Got Married,'' and a bungling thief in ``Raising Arizona.''

Paul Newman is seeking to recover $40,000 loaned to a former executive of the Hole in the Wall Camp, which the actor founded in 1987 for children with catastrophic illnesses. A lawsuit filed in Bridgeport Superior Court on Thursday alleged that Jeffrey Glick, the camp's executive director from 1987 to 1989, borrowed the money from the camp in Ashford and later left the state without paying it back. ``There's no scandal; we just want to get our money back,'' said Newman's lawyer, Leo Nevas. He said Glick was fired after it became apparent he was not going to repay the money. Glick was hired on the condition that he live near the camp, and was loaned $40,000 to buy a house in nearby Brooklyn, the lawsuit said. Meanwhile, Glick and his wife put up for sale their house in Kerhonkson, N.Y. The lawsuit said Glick told camp directors several times in late 1988 and 1989 he had difficulty selling the house, but assured them the loan would be repaid. On June 6, lawyers for Newman discovered the Glicks had sold their home in June 1989 for $127,500. Nevas said he believes the couple, who failed to appear at an earlier hearing on the lawsuit, now live in Buffalo, N.Y.

Charles Grodin advises would-be actors not to take it personally when they're rejected for roles. ``When you realize that there may be 1,000 people who look and sound very much like you, it's very hard. So many of the better people get lost because of the sheer numbers,'' said Grodin, who co-stars with Jim Belushi in the new comedy film ``Taking Care of Business.'' ``You can't take it too personally,'' Grodin said Friday. His philosophy is spelled out in his book, ``It Would Be So Nice If You Weren't Here,'' published last year and out in paperback next month. Aspiring actors, he said, should ``think not so much about getting ahead as becoming as good as you can be, so you're ready when you do get an opportunity,'' Grodin said. ``I did that, so I didn't suffer from the frustration of all the rejections. They just gave me more time.'' Grodin, 55, made his film debut as Mia Farrow's doctor in ``Rosemary's Baby.'' He has since appeared as the navigator in ``Catch 22'' and an overly ambitious hero in ``The Heartbreak Kid.''

Sheila E., a singer, drummer and dancer in Prince's band who appears with comedian Andrew Dice Clay in the film ``Ford Fairlaine,'' left the hospital after treatment for a collapsed lung. The 32-year-old performer, whose full name is Sheila Escovedo, entered Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Monday and was discharged Friday. The condition occurs spontaneously and has no known cause, said hospital spokeswoman Paula Correia. During her hospital stay, her visitors included Lionel Richie, Tito Puente, Vanity and Prince, publicist Nancy Utley said. Miss Escovedo, who appeared in Prince's movie ``Purple Rain,'' launched a solo career in 1984 with her hit record ``The Glamorous Life.''

DOC.HEAD: Reported Price Jump Threatens Trouble for Collider
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department's delay in announcing its revised cost of the superconducting super collider amid reports of a $3 billion jump confirms that the atom-smasher project ``is way out of control,'' a congressional critic charges. The announcement had been expected Friday, but the Energy Department said the four groups making the estimates are still working out differences. The revised figure would be ready by Sept. 7, the department said. In a letter to Rep. Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, Deputy Energy Secretary Henson Moore said the ``reconciliation process is still under way.'' He gave no more explanation. On July 25, Moore said the four groups would try to have a final figure Aug. 17. Preliminary estimates of three of the groups were around $8 billion. A fourth estimate prepared by a group under DOE contract but acting independently is between $11.5 billion and $11.7 billion, the newsletter Inside Energy reported. The department has not confirmed the estimate. Usually, only three groups of estimators work on DOE projects. The previous highest figure, $8.6 billion, was made last month by the group of scientists that redesigned the collider. For a nearly a year, DOE planners have said it would cost about $8 billion. When first proposed in the mid-1980s, the collider was estimated to cost $4.4 billion. ``Delaying reports and rising costs confirm the suspicion this project is way out of control and very likely to run into serious budgetary questions,'' said Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, a leading opponent of the new machine. ``I grow more confident each day the collider won't survive,'' he said. The spiraling cost has been one of the main arguments Eckart and other congressional opponents have used against the atom smasher, to be built south of Dallas. Congress has appropriated $318 million, including funds to start construction, for next year. But that could be jeopardized because of the higher estimate, Eckart said. ``Given the ineptitude in giving us accurate cost estimates and facing a real budget summit ... that will make major cuts across the board, the SSC may have just priced itself out of existence,'' he said. With the $8 billion figure in mind, the House in May capped the collider's federal funds at $5 billion for the next five years. Texas has pledged $1 billion. The rest is expected to come from foreign investors and other sources. The three preliminary estimates agreed on the costs of building the 54-mile tunnel and the superconducting magnets. They varied in the cost of potential delays. The independent group says the collider alone will cost $9.7 billion, and that detectors _ the giant microscopes that record atomic collisions _ will cost another $2 billion, Inside Energy reported. Moore told the newsletter the group may have thought more detectors are needed. But members of the Texas delegation said the collider's funding would remain intact through the budget summit. Sens. Lloyd Bentsen, a Democrat, and Phil Gramm, a Republican, are among the budget negotiators. ``I don't even believe that's in question,'' said Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Dallas. ``I have every confidence the SSC will be built on time and within budget. I've heard nothing that makes me doubt the budget we've already got for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Figures for Eighteen States Issued
DOC.TEXT: At least four states may have lost population since 1980, according to preliminary Census figures. Louisiana, Michigan, North Dakota and West Virginia registered population declines, data released Friday showed. The Census Bureau said 14 other states reported increases. Reports for the 18 states were sent to state and local officials as part of the Census Bureau's local review program. Census officials emphasized that the figures are preliminary and were provided to allow local governments to question the results in the event people were missed or overcounted. Final official state population figures are scheduled to be issued Dec. 31. Here is a list of the figures made public Friday, compared with the results of the 1980 census. Reports for other states are expected to become public over the next few weeks. Connecticut: 3,226,929, up from 3,108,000. Delaware: 658,031, up from 594,000. Idaho: 1,003,558, up from 944,000. Kentucky: 3,665,220, up from 3,661,000. Louisiana: 4,180,831, down from 4,206,000. Maine: 1,218,053, up from 1,125,000. Michigan: 9,179,661, down from 9,262,000. Mississippi: 2,534,814, up from 2,521,000. Montana: 794,329, up from 787,000. Nebraska: 1,572,503, up from 1,570,000. New Hampshire: 1,103,163, up from 921,000. North Dakota: 634,223, down from 653,000. Oregon: 2,828,214, up from 2,633,000. Rhode Island: 988,609, up from 947,000. South Dakota, 693,294, up from 691,000. Tennessee: 4,822,134, up from 4,591,000. Vermont: 560,029, up from 511,000. West Virginia: 1,782,958, down from 1,950,000.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Control Advocates Cheered by 1976 Souter Brief
DOC.TEXT: A 1976 legal brief signed by Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter argues against an unlimited constitutional right of individuals to possess firearms, says a group seeking stricter regulation of handguns. ``The Second Amendment does not create any right in U.S. citizens to possess any and all weapons regardless of state regulation, but rather concerns only authority of the states to keep and raise militias,'' said the brief, released Friday by the Washington-based Center to Prevent Handgun Violence. The brief defended New Hampshire's concealed-weapons law. ``Souter's brief directly contradicts the National Rifle Association's position ... that the (Constitution's) Second Amendment guarantees individuals an absolute right to own and possess guns of all types,'' said Barbara Lautman, executive director of the Center. An NRA spokeswoman said the organization could not respond before seeing the brief. Souter was New Hampshire's attorney general when the brief was filed in the state Supreme Court. It was signed by both Souter and attorney Richard B. McNamara, and whether Souter actually wrote the brief could not be determined immediately. The brief urged the state court to reject the appeal of a man, Stephen Sanne, who had been convicted of carrying two loaded guns without a permit. Sanne argued that the conviction violated his constitutional rights. The nation's highest court, which has not issued a ruling on the issue in decades, never has decided specifically just what the Second Amendment protects. The amendment says, ``A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed.''

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Win Round With USAir
DOC.TEXT: USAir must let 8,000 employees vote again on whether to be represented by the Teamsters union, because the first organizing drive was tainted by illegal anti-union activities, a federal labor board says. The Teamsters had lost their bid to represent workers in a ballot count announced in January. But the National Mediation Board ruled Friday that actions by the airline interfered with the union's organizing campaign. The union may request a rerun election within 30 days. The Teamsters, who were trying to win the right to represent 8,000 workers who load airplanes at 180 airports around the country, had charged that USAir unfairly interfered with their organizing drive. The union said USAir managers called meetings with small groups of workers to discuss the union's campaign, put up anti-Teamsters posters urging workers to burn their ballots and produced two anti-Teamsters videotapes. ``The carrier, through the totality of its conduct, has tainted the laboratory conditions for a fair election,'' the ruling said. ``Remedial action must be taken.'' The board, created in 1934, mediates disputes involving railroads and airlines. ``We're extremely disappointed,'' said David Shipley, a USAir spokesman. ``As far as we're concerned, we ran a perfectly legal election campaign.'' A Teamsters union official said no one was immediately available to comment on the ruling. Another election means an all-or-nothing event for the Teamsters, who already represent some 1,800 USAir workers in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Buffalo and Boston. If the union loses again, those workers would no longer be Teamsters members. The Teamsters had represented cargo workers at USAir before its 1989 merger with Piedmont airlines, whose employees were not members of the union. Last December, the Mediation Board ordered the election to determine whether workers at USAir and former Piedmont employees would be represented by the Teamsters. Three other unions representing pilots, flight attendants and mechanics at USAir gained the right to represent the Piedmont workers without elections. There were 8,002 workers eligible to vote, and under the board's rules, the Teamsters needed at least half of those workers to mail in ballots in the union's favor. Only 2,371 workers mailed their ballots in favor of the Teamsters, with most of the workers not bothering to vote. USAir is based in Arlington, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Student Finds Dinosaur Remains
DOC.TEXT: A zoology student digging in a Canadian canyon near the Montana border has discovered the bones of a hadrosaur, or duckbill dinosaur, three years after she found fossilized eggs from the same species. Wendy Sloboda, 20, a second-year student at the University of Lethbridge in Alberta, came across the hadrosaur remains while helping measure sections of sandstone last month near Milk River Canyon. The rare hadrosaur remains had been preserved in rock for at least 65 million years. When alive, the animal would have weighed nearly three tons, measured about 30 feet long, and stood about nine feet tall on its hind legs.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Expands Military Mail to Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia means more work for the U.S. Postal Service, which is opening 29 military post offices to handle mail to the Middle East. Twenty-four new Army Post Offices will handle mail for Army and Air Force personnel, and five additional Fleet Post Offices to handle Navy and Marine Corps mail, the Postal Service said Friday. Only first class mail, cards and letters may be sent to the Middle East. Each item must be under 12 ounces and is subject to customs requirements. Under the military mail system, items addressed to the APO numbers are brought by the postal service to Chicago, Washington or New York where they are sorted and dispatched to Saudi Arabia. FPO mail is going via New York or San Francisco. On arrival the distribution is completed by military personnel. Postal officials said mail should take between eight and 10 days to travel between the United States and the troops in the Middle East. Military personnel will be providing their new APO and FPO numbers to friends and family, but mail sent to old numbers will also be forwarded.

DOC.HEAD: Hotdog ``With Everything'' Leads to Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: A man asked a street vendor for ``a hotdog with everything'' and got it. And how. The vendor gave him the hotdog and a small packet of cocaine and charged him 125,000 pesos, about $42. The buyer, a police agent, had inadvertently stumbled into a cocaine outlet, the Excelsior news service reported Friday. Police arrested Teresa Esparza Paez, 60, two sons and five other people and confiscated more than three pounds of cocaine. Investigators said ``a hot dog with everything'' apparently was the code used by cocaine buyers who frequented the stand.

DOC.HEAD: Florida State Picked Over MIT for New Magnetic Research Lab
DOC.TEXT: Florida State University will become the national center of high-magnetic field research after edging out the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in a competition for federal funds. The selection Friday of FSU by the National Science Foundation will make the Tallahassee-based institution eligible for a grant of up to $60 million over five years. Depending on the availability of federal funds, FSU could receive up to $18 million in the next 12 months to build a laboratory with powerful magnets creating unprecedented magnetic field strengths. Physicist Jack E. Crow will direct the science at the laboratory, which is expected to be in operation within three years. Research related to production and use of magnetic fields can lead to new devices for the computer industry, new materials with exceptional strengths and major advances in medicine. Europe and Japan have made strides in such research while U.S. capabilities have lagged. David A. Sanchez, an assistant director of the foundation, said Florida State showed a greater commitment to creating ``a national center of excellence'' even though MIT currently has a stronger faculty. Sanchez said FSU has pledged to create slots for 54 people, including tenured faculty, visiting faculty and visiting researchers. By contrast, he said, MIT had no recruitment plan for faculty which he said was critical ``since the major scientific figures at MIT are near retirement.'' Florida State and MIT were the finalists in a competition that involved an unspecified number of universities. The facility will be called the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory. The state of Florida will commit $58 million for the facility in Tallahassee over five years. FSU is joining with the University of Florida and Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, a leader in the area of pulsed magnetic technology. Qualified scientists and engineers from across the nation and around the world will be able to make use of the laboratory, which will have from eight to 10 magnets. MIT originally had proposed to build the lab for $68 million, Sanchez said. It proposed to meet the $8 million reduction by eliminating several magnet developments and reducing the faculty support. FSU, he said, would have met the reduced funding by eliminating several projects, extending the timetable for several of the proposed magnets but not reducing faculty commitment.

DOC.HEAD: Civic Rights Restored to Socialist Leader Banned by Pinochet
DOC.TEXT: The Constitutional Tribunal has restored full civic rights to Socialist Party leader Clodimiro Almeyda, reversing a ban imposed on him by former military ruler Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The ruling Friday paved the way for Almeyda to become Chile's Ambassador to the Soviet Union. President Patricio Aylwin, an elected civilian, appointed him to the ambassadorial post shortly after succeeding Pinochet last March 11. Pinochet stripped Almeyda, 68, of all his civic rights for 10 years in 1988, accusing him of promoting terrorism and armed struggle against his military regime. Almeyda consistently denied the charges. Almeyda was foreign minister in the leftist government toppled by Pinochet in a bloody 1973 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Alternative Fuels Say Their Time Has Come
DOC.TEXT: The sign outside the fairground proclaims, ``We will not be caught between Iraq and a hard place.'' It's the newest slogan of energy conservationists gathering this weekend for the Midwest Renewable Energy Fair. They believe the Middle East crisis should refocus attention on how much America depends on fossil fuels _ after a decade of lagging interest. ``We are caught with our backs against the wall again. We don't have a solar industry or a renewable industry to fall back on,'' said Bob Ramlow, a fair organizer and operator of a solar products company in this central Wisconsin town. The fair is the largest of three planned nationwide this year to encourage reduced dependence on finite fossil fuels and expanded use of energy sources that are environmentally safe and renewable _ like the sun and wind. About 10,000 people were expected to attend the three-day fair, which ends Sunday. Educational seminars and displays like solar-powered microwave ovens and wind-powered stereo sound systems dotted the fairgrounds. Some participants described themselves as 1960s-style ``back-to-the-earth refugees'' who remember the gasoline crisis of the mid-1970s and ensuing goals to wean the United States from heavy oil consumption. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in the oil-rich Persian Gulf, which caused gasoline prices to climb as much as 20 cents a gallon within a week, serves as a reminder that the United States has failed to achieve those goals, Ramlow said. He is one of several Amherst residents who moved to the town of 2,500 in the 1970s to escape cities and experiment with alternate energy. His home is fully solar-powered. ``I have a color TV,'' he said. ``A VCR. I have clock radios, tape decks, stereos, a Nintendo game for my kids. You name it. I have it. You don't have to give up something to use less energy. ``A lot of people in this area use wood for heating,'' he added. ``A lot of people drive high-mileage cars. There is definitely a good environmental attitude around here.'' Innovation is the pride of the 40 or so exhibitors at the fair. John Osborne of Plymouth, Mich., displayed a 12-volt computer system that can be powered by alternate energy sources. ``I am trying to appeal to the people who are running an office out of their homes with solar power,'' Osborne said. ``I want to get high performance computers into the hands of these innovative people. They are pioneers.'' Osborne said the Middle East crisis demonstrates how he's doing more than saving money by turning from fuel-burning power sources. ``I have got solar panels on my roof. Nobody holds me hostage for my power,'' he said. Most organizers, exhibitors and fairgoers predicted the Iraqi invasion, while forcing a U.S. military buildup, might bring something positive if it awakens dormant energy concerns. ``All the politicians want to jump on the bandwagon. When that happens, you can tell it's hot,'' said Mike Torzewski, treasurer of the group of energy-conscious Amherst residents who organized the fair. Ken Wirtz, a visitor from nearby Wisconsin Rapids, strolled by some displays with perhaps more interest than he might have had before gasoline prices soared. ``When it costs you $20 to fill up your gas tank, it makes you think a little bit,'' he said. Richard Perez, editor of Home Power, a magazine published in California that last year urged the return of renewable energy fairs, said the time is right to expand use of solar and wind power. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``makes us realize we are incredibly dependent on foreign oil, which makes us not free at all,'' Perez said. ``I have a saying, `No one has to die for solar energy.'''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Revises Food Price Hikes Upward for 1990, Partly Blames Oil Crunch
DOC.TEXT: Consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, sharply more than had been predicted and perhaps slightly because of the Mideast oil crunch, the Agriculture Department says. The new forecast compared with the 3 percent to 5 percent price hike the department has been predicting for 1990 since December. Double-digit price gains in the first half of this year for fresh fruits, pork, eggs and dairy products, along with ``uncertainties about future energy prices,'' are mostly to blame for the upward revision, said the department's Economic Research Service. ``However, most of the year's price increases probably took place in the first half,'' the agency said Friday. ``Gains in the second half are expected to be more modest.'' But the report added that this assumes most of the evolving oil price shock will take until next year to spill over into the grocery store. Retail food prices rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981. Much of that gain was fallout from the 1988 drought that hit much of the nation. One USDA official who spoke only on condition of anonymity said that without the Mideast crisis and rising energy costs, the new food price estimate for 1990 would have been in the range of 5 percent to 6 percent. Thus, the official said, an allowance of only one percentage point was made at the upper end of the estimate to allow for higher oil prices. Further, the source said, some department analysts had wanted to hold the new 1990 food price increase to less than what was decided. Most felt the oil pinch is not going to hit this year, the source said.
DOC.HEAD: Commerce Department: Taiwan Dumping Cheap Sweaters in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Sweaters made of manmade fibers in Taiwan are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department says. The National Knitwear & Sportswear Association in New York had filed complaints last September against sweater manufacturers in South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The department said Friday it ruled against the manufacturers in Hong Kong on July 21 and against those in South Korea on Aug. 3. The findings clear the way for the International Trade Commission to determine whether the products are harming U.S. industry. If the commission finds U.S. firms are being damaged, the government can impose duties on the imports to make their prices comparable to those of U.S. companies. The department said the imports represent 72 percent of the $1.3 billion U.S. market and the three countries represent 55 percent of the imports. It said the value of the sweaters imported from South Korea in 1989 was $476.1 million; from Hong Kong, $208.8 million, and Taiwan, $485.5 million. The department said the imports are made predominantly of acrylic fiber. Sweaters containing at least 23 percent wool are excluded.
DOC.HEAD: Local Review Beginning in 1990 Census
DOC.TEXT: Local officials across the country are beginning to receive preliminary housing counts, the Census Bureau reports. Official population numbers won't be issued until at least the end of the year, though preliminary ones will be sent to state officials within a few weeks. The early housing reports are designed to allow local governments to challenge the Bureau's findings, pointing out areas where homes and people may have been missed, officials said. The census got under way in March with the mailing of nearly 100 million forms. In recent weeks workers have been going door-to-door to try to count people who were missed in the first phase. Sending the preliminary count to local officials does not mean that the effort is complete, Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant said. The figures are open to challenge and workers will be sent out to double-check areas where officials question the totals. In addition to sending housing counts to city, county and town officials, preliminary population counts will be sent to state governors, state redistricting officials and members of Congress who has requested the information.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says U.S. Military Could Be In Saudi Arabia For Years
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military commitment to Saudi Arabia's defense is a ``long-term'' one, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says. ``Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate,'' Cheney told reporters Friday on his plane headed for Saudi Arabia. The secretary's four-day swing through several Persian Gulf nations is his second to the region since Iraqi troops crushed Kuwait and threatened Saudi Arabia's vital oil reserves. As U.S. warships began intercepting Iraqi ships, and the sweep of U.S. troops continued unabated into Saudi Arabia, the secretary said he could not put an end point on the massive military endeavor. Noting that Iraq has 10 divisions with an estimated 160,000 soldiers in Kuwait, Cheney said, ``It's far too soon for us to talk about any change in our deployment.'' Asked about the chance for a decades-long commitment to the region on the order of a NATO defense, Cheney said, ``What we're doing now is carrying out the commitment we made to the Saudis 10 days ago, and that commitment is to send a lot of force, enough to be able to do what the president directed us to do.'' ``The commitment is long term. The question of how long the deployments are for will depend upon developments,'' he said. Pressed to explain his reference to a years-long commitment, the secretary replied, ``There's no way I can answer that question. ... I have said repeatedly that we do not know how long we will have to stay, I do not know when we will be able to come home.'' The secretary refused to say how many U.S. soldiers, sailors and airmen have been deployed to the region, saying only that the flow was continuing at a brisk pace and that no decision has been made yet to halt it. Pentagon sources have said tens of thousands of troops have already landed in Saudi Arabia with some 45,000 Marines in line to be deployed. Three aircraft carriers and their battle groups have been dispatched to the region along with the super-secret F-117A Stealth fighter-bomber and dozens of F-15 and F-16 jet fighters. Asked whether there was enough firepower on the ground to repel the Iraqi threat, Cheney said: ``We have a lot of capability in theater. I'd like to have more there before I'll be comfortable with the situation.'' The Pentagon has requested that as many as 38 civilian airliners be turned over to military use for cargo and troop transport while some of the Army and Marine units are being transferred by slower-moving ships. The secretary was to spend his first evening in the region aboard the carrier USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea. He planned to spend most of Sunday visiting Army, Air Force and Marine units at various sites in Saudi Arabia, but reporters accompanying him were instructed that they wouldn't be able to describe the exact location of such units. Cheney's plane stopped in the Azores, a group of Atlantic islands belonging to Portugal, for refueling en route Saudi Arabia. The secretary said he added a brief stop in Cairo onto the end of his trip, which will take him to Bahrain and several other Persian Gulf states before he returns to Washington early Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Prince Calls for Swift Action Against Saddam
LaserPhoto BX7 of Aug. 17
DOC.TEXT: Swift military action, not an economic boycott, is needed to drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait and topple Saddam Hussein, said a brother of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd. Prince Turki bin Abdul Aziz, a former deputy minister of defense, said he believes the United Nations international embargo intended to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait cannot work. ``This embargo, this boycott, is not going to be useful because you know there are many merchants of war who make their living by contributing to the escalation of war among nations,'' Prince Turki said through an interpreter at a news conference Friday. The best course would be for an international force to take swift military action, the prince said. ``I think if they want to put a quick end to it, the United States knows how to do that,'' he said. Saddam ``is a sadist and a psychotic. He enjoys killing people,'' the prince said. ``I am not talking about eliminating him physically or assassination, but they should put an end to his rule _ to his regime because he is a bloodthirsty person and that's his trade, he lives off blood,'' he said. The prince, 53, also said he was disappointed in King Hussein of Jordan, who met Thursday with President Bush. ``I was hoping that King Hussein would not go down and lower himself to come to the United States as an emissary of Saddam Hussein,'' he said. ``I thought he would honor himself further if he hadn't done so.'' It was originally believed the king was carrying a message from Saddam, but Hussein said Thursday that he had no such message. The prince, one of the king's seven full brothers, said he came to Cambridge to talk about how he could enhance Harvard University's educational programs in medicine and human rights.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Obit-Pearl Bailey, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Pearl Bailey died Friday at age 72. Here are some reactions:

``I have lost one of the greatest friends I've ever had in my life. I've lost a co-worker and a wonderful person.'' _ Song-and-dance man Cab Calloway, who starred with Bailey on Broadway in the acclaimed 1967 version of ``Hello, Dolly!''

``The entertainment world has lost one of the most creative performers of our time. Her talent was unique and enduring and her warmth was felt by everyone in the audience.'' _ Carol Channing, who first played ``Dolly'' on Broadway in 1964.

``She was so sophisticated and witty and funny. She had it all. She had an incredible talent then ... There's only one Pearl. We loved her so dearly.'' _ Lorraine Gordon, widow of Village Vanguard nightclub owner Max Gordon. Bailey appeared at the Vanguard in the early 1940s.

``Pearl Bailey personified everything really good about music. She always made you feel good when you watched her sing.'' _ Michael Greene, president of the National Association for Recording Arts and Sciences.
``Pearl Bailey was the mother of the world. She was a very spiritual woman and she never recognized color. Her ideology was, `we are humans.''' _ Stan Irwin, Bailey's manager for 25 years.
``I've lost my best friend.'' _ Louis Bellson Jr., Bailey's husband, to whom she was married for 38 years.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Obit-Pearl Bailey, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: 1933_At age 15, Pearl Bailey made her stage debut in an amateur night at the Pearl Theatre in Philadelphia, where her brother had already performed. She sang ``Talk of the Town'' and ``Poor Butterfly,'' and earned $5 for winning first prize. 1946_Appearing on Broadway for the first time, she played Butterfly in the Johnny Mercer-Harold Arlen all-black musical, ``St. Louis Woman,'' and stole the show with renditions of ``Legalize My Name'' and ``A Woman's Prerogative.'' She received the Donaldson Award for best newcomer on Broadway. 1950_She appeared in two musicals, ``Arms and the Girl'' and ``Bless You All,'' which ran for 84 performances. 1954_After a four-year absence, she starred on Broadway in the Truman Capote-Harold Arlen musical, ``House of Flowers.'' With Bailey playing Madame Fleur, the owner of a lavish West Indian bordello, ``House of Flowers'' ran for 165 performances. 1967_Her career peaks with her starring role in an all-black version of ``Hello, Dolly!,'' an enormous critical and commercial success. Cab Calloway was her leading man and at the annual Tony Awards, she received a special award for her performance. She was again in the title role in a 1975 revival.

1947_She made her film debut in ``Variety Girl,'' a showcase for Paramount performers, and sang two specialty numbers. 1954_Appeared in Otto Preminger's adaptation of the all-black Broadway musical ``Carmen Jones,'' playing Frankie, one of Carmen's friends. 1956_Appeared in the comedy ``That Certain Feeling,'' which starred Bob Hope and Eva Marie Saint. 1959_Again working with Preminger, she played Maria the cookshop woman in the film version of George Gershwin's ``Porgy and Bess.''
Recorded for several labels, including Coral, Decca and Columbia. Among the albums she made were ``Bad Old Days,'' ``Cole Porter Song Book'' and ``Echoes of an Era.''

In 1966, along with Carol Channing, an earlier star of ``Hello, Dolly!'' she co-starred in the special ``Carol Channing and Pearl Bailey on Broadway.'' She also guested on specials for Bob Hope and Bing Crosby and appeared on talk shows hosted by Milton Berle, Johnny Carson and Perry Como among others. She had her own series, ``The Pearl Bailey Show,'' which ran during the 1970-71 season.

She wrote several books, including two autobiographies, ``Raw Pearl'' amd ``Talking to Myself,'' and a cookbook called ``Pearl's Kitchen: An Extraordinary Cookbook.'' She received the USO Woman of the Year award in 1969 and was appointed as a special advisor to the United States Mission of the United Nations General Assembly in 1975 by President Ford.

DOC.HEAD: One Guerrilla Dead in Attack on Peruvian State Bus
DOC.TEXT: A guerrilla attack on a bus belonging to the state transport company left one rebel dead and a policeman injured, police said. The attack took place Friday morning in the Lima district of Los Olivos, according to police sources. Poice said three guerrillas, two men and a woman, boarded the bus and shot a policeman on board, leaving him seriously injured. The guerrillas attempted to set fire to the bus, but were prevented by the arrival of a squad car, police said. Police sources said the officers shot dead one of the guerrillas and captured the other two. In another attack on Thursday afternoon, guerrillas tossed four sticks of dynamite from a speeding car at a private bus carrying 20 workers in the Lima district of Rimac, police said. Six workers were injured by the blast, according to the police. No arrests were announced. Police said Wednesday night members of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement bombed a bank in the district of Comas, on the outskirts of the capital. The guerrillas have distributed leaflets and sprayed graffiti around the capital urging an armed strike next Tuesday. More than 19,000 people have died in clashes between the armed forces and rebel factions since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Return to Saudi Arabia Lured by Good Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Well-paid jobs, good benefits and tax breaks draw Americans back from vacation to the uncertainties of Saudi Arabia, although some say they are returning only to test the waters. ``I want to pay for college and law school _ otherwise I'll end up a bartender,'' said 23-year-old James Byrne of Owego, N.Y., one of several expatriates on Saudi Arabian Airlines flight 24 from New York to Jiddah Friday. Byrne left his wife and 1{-year-old son in New York while he finishes the second year of a two-year contract with Boeing to supervise the crew working on the five Saudi-owned AWACS radar planes and their refueling tankers. Byrne, who earns $30,000 a year tax-free and lives on a Boeing compound where housing is free and amenities are plenty, said he couldn't afford not to return. Still, Byrne said he was concerned about the military situation and intended to ask his company to provide him with a gas mask against chemical warfare. Byrne said many of his expatriate friends in Saudi Arabia were also uncertain about whether to leave, but wanted to wait out the year to avoid paying U.S. taxes. Nancy Bonnette of Austin, Texas, also said the financial incentives for staying are great. She said she and her husband want to spend between two and four more years in Saudi Arabia. To the dismay of friends and family, the Bonnettes never really thought twice about returning. Mrs. Bonnette said her decision was sealed when a friend at the Pentagon told her the Defense Department viewed the U.S. build-up as a relatively long-term commitment, and didn't expect an all-out war with Iraqi troops. Others on the flight back to Saudi Arabia said they would wait and see. `We're going back to Jiddah for one week. ... During this week, if I don't like the feeling I'm getting, I'm leaving,'' said Julie Hallberg of Balsam Lake, Wis. Mrs. Hallberg and her husband, Monte, work at the international school in Jidah, located on the Red Sea, 1,000 miles from where American troops are massing near the Persian Gulf. Mrs. Hallberg, a physical education teacher, said she left her children _ ages seven, four and one _ with her parents for a week. She and her husband will return for the kids if they're satisfied the situation is calm. Mrs. Hallberg said her husband, who remained in Jiddah while she vacationed with their children in the United States this month, had told her life was unchanged by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``The day it started he didn't really know that much about it,'' Mrs. Hallberg said. Mrs. Hallberg said she hopes to stay in Saudia Arabia, where the family has lived for seven years. `You make good benefits and we ended up liking it,'' she said. For some, the arrival of thousands of American troops in the peaceful country represented the end of an era in which foreigners lived a sheltered, comfortable existence mixing mainly among themselves. ``I've been here nine years and now I don't know what I am going to do,'' said James Green, a Briton with a photographic studio in Jiddah. Several major U.S. companies have flown dependents out of Saudi Arabia, suggesting that women and children stay away temporarily. Boeing Co. took women and children to headquarters in Seattle last week, and Aramco, the huge oil consortium has offered to transport dependents. It was unclear how many Americans have left the country. But Bob Bonnette, a data processer with Saudi Arabian Airlines, said people living in the Eastern provinces nearer the Kuwait border would feel less secure. The Arab News, an English-language newspaper, reported that flights into Dhahran which is the center of U.S. troop activity continue to bring foreign workers into the country. It said air traffic _ primarily from India and Pakistan _ was unchanged from last year. Many workers in the oil fields are Asian.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Takeover Leaves Kuwaiti Tankers in Legal Limbo
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's armed takeover of Kuwait has left five American-flagged oil tankers worth nearly $150 million in legal limbo as to who owns them, shipping industry sources say. The ships are the last of 11 Kuwaiti tankers reflagged by the United States in mid-1987 to ensure American naval protection from attacks by Iran in the Persian Gulf. They remained under the Stars and Stripes when the other six reverted to Kuwaiti registry following the Iran-Iraq cease-fire on August 20, 1988. One of the five, The Chesapeake City, reportedly just escaped seizure when the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2 caught it forging into Kuwaiti waters. The 401,000-ton crude carrier Bridgeton, the world's sixth largest ship, and the four oil products tankers of about 80,000 tons each, were last reported at anchor at ports around the gulf while officials ponder their status, said Walter Oates, a U.S. Maritime Administration spokesman. The vessels have been manned for the past year by American crews, about 30 per ship. Oates, in a telephone interview, said Kuwaiti officials had recently indicated they wanted to deflag the other five ships, ``But that's obviously a moot point now.'' Another U.S. maritime source, who declined to be named, said the ships probably would remain under U.S. jurisdiction pending clarification of their legal status. He said it was ``a strange situation. ... Nobody really knows what happens next.'' The Kuwaitis in 1987 set up a Delaware corporation, Chesapeake Shipping Co., to meet U.S. legal requirements that American-flagged ships have U.S. owners. The firm could not be reached for comment. Philip Wake, a senior consultant for Lloyds Maritime Information Services in London, said that as long as Delaware Shipping Co. remains a legal entity, Kuwait probably would be considered the owner of the tankers. ``But when something like this crops up, it's a political question to a large extent. And when it gets to the lawyers, they can have a field day,'' he said. Wake said an ultra large crude carrier like the Bridgeton is currently worth about $40 million on the tanker market, with oil products tankers in the 80,000-ton range worth about $27 million. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein annexed Kuwait after the invasion and abolished its government. But the United States and other countries have not recognized the action and froze both countries' international assets. U.S. sources said they did not know the whereabouts of some 15 other state-owned Kuwaiti tankers. A sister ship to the Chesapeake City, the Sea Isle City, was also in the gulf en route to Kuwait and was diverted to the Saudi Arabian port of Jubail, the sources said. The Bridgeton was undergoing a Coast Guard inspection at Khor Fakkhan just outside the gulf on the day of the takeover. Oates said it was still there, along with the other two tankers, Ocean City and Surf City. Flying the U.S. flag during the gulf ``tanker war'' entitled the Kuwaiti vessels to U.S. Navy protection at a time when Iranian gunboats were attacking commercial shipping in retaliation for Iraqi air strikes on Iran's own oil tankers and terminals. The Iranians singled out Kuwait and Saudi ships because of those countries' support for Baghdad. No reflagged tanker was ever directly attacked while under naval escort, but the Bridgeton hit a mine and the Sea Isle City was badly damaged by an Iranian Silkworm missile while at Kuwait to take on cargo.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Flee Across Dessert to Saudi Arabia and Freedom
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen carloads of American and other refugees tore through desert sands to avoid Iraqi troops in a dramatic escape from Kuwait to Saudi Arabia, a Californian member of the convoy says. ``It was a hectic, rather perilous drive past Iraqi checkpoints and through uninhabited desert regions between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,'' Stephanie McGehee, 37, said after the group made it over the border Friday. McGehee, of Leucadia, Calif., a member of the group and a part-time photographer and reporter for The Associated Press in Kuwait, spoke by telephone from the Khafji border post. The total number of people in the 13-car convoy was not immediately clear, although nine people crammed into McGehee's car, including two other Americans, a Canadian, a Briton and four Indians, for the four-hour journey. On Friday, Iraq ordered Britons and Americans in Kuwait to report to two hotels, prompting fears they would be taken to Baghdad as hostages. Many foreigners apparently decided to risk the Iraqi tanks and desert for freedom. McGehee said that she and Canadian Cathy McGregor donned Kuwaiti floor-length black chadour overcoats. McGregor, in her early 30s, had been a top executive with the Kuwait SAS Hotel for about five years. And McGehee, who had lived 12 years in Lebanon and Kuwait, said she used her knowledge of Arabic dialects to talk her way past the Iraqi invaders who have occupied Kuwait since Aug. 2. ``It seems the Iraqis got the impression the entire convoy comprised only Arab evacuees,'' said McGehee. ``I spoke at length in Arabic with a mixture of Kuwaiti and Lebanese accents to the Iraqis at the last checkpoint (15 miles off al-Khafji).'' The ploy seemed to work at first and none of the other cars were checked. But the Iraqi troops suddenly told the party to return home, McGehee said. They moved a few miles back toward Kuwait, then veered into a desert expanse and kept driving until they saw some Bedouins who pointed to the Saudi border. ``We breathed a sigh of relief when we saw a sign that showed clearly we were entering Saudi Arabia,'' said McGehee. McGehee and McGregor lived in a house in an old quarter of Kuwait city, a stone's throw from the Sheraton hotel and the al-Jahra boulevard. The Iraqi invaders punched into Kuwait city with 350 tanks through al-Jahra at sunrise more than two weeks ago. McGehee sighted them and phoned the AP a series of reports. ``Two days later the going got rough, the risks high,'' she said. ``Cathy and I had to move to a safer place. The Iraqis were already rampaging, looting, raping and murdering.'' They moved to another Western residence, where McGehee tried to carry on communicating news of the invasion. There they spent 10 days, ``until Westerners began to panic.'' ``It became extremely dangerous for us Westerners to circulate in the city and we had to stay indoors most of the time,'' she said. ``What hurt us most was the long breakdown in telephone and telex links with the outside world.'' She said the city became oppressively silent, except for the staccato of machine gunfire and deafening bomb blasts. On the ninth day in hiding, she said, the Iraqis announced they wanted all U.S. and British expatriates to gather at the International Hotel, across from the U.S. Embassy compound. ``Many of us panicked,'' she said. ``We thought the Iraqis were bent on moving us to Baghdad where we would be kept hostage.'' She said she contacted many Westerners, and the decision among them was unanimous: ``We go.'' They gathered every car they could find. ``Driving along the asphalt road was smooth but frightening, because the Iraqis were always there,'' she said. ``Our drive through the desolate desert was much safer, rather comforting, even though we felt we were moving to nowhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Blasts Off With British Broadcasting Satellite
DOC.TEXT: A British television broadcasting satellite orbited Earth today after a successful ride into space aboard an unmanned Delta rocket. The liftoff Friday night was nearly two hours behind schedule because of thunderstorms and last-minute problems with a computer used to display range data. The British Satellite Broadcasting satellite, called Marcopolo 2, will transmit programs directly to thousands of homes in Britain. ``One of the nice things about this launch is that it was not only successful, but the holds (delays) worked out for a night launch, which is always more spectacular,'' said former astronaut Charles ``Pete'' Conrad, now a vice president for rocket builder McDonnell Douglas. The satellite separated from the booster as planned about 28 minutes after the 8:42 p.m. liftoff from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. An on-board kick motor is to put the satellite into a 22,300-mile-high orbit on Sunday. An identical spacecraft, Marcopolo 1, was launched aboard a Delta rocket last Aug. 27. It was the United States' first commercial launch of a payload into orbit; Friday's launch was the ninth. The cost of both Marcopolo satellites and launches is about $300 million, said Ellis Griffiths, director of engineering for British Satellite Broadcasting. Marcopolo 2 eventually will be situated over the Atlantic Ocean near the first satellite. Each 1,450-pound spacecraft has a lifetime of at least 10 years. Once Marcopolo 2 becomes fully operational in early December, it will enable the company to transmit at full power over five transponder channels. Only one channel currently is being beamed at full power; the other four are at half power. British Satellite Broadcasting is the only company in the world that is transmitting television programs directly from orbiting satellites to homes, Griffiths said. So far there have been no satellite problems, he said. Unlike in the United States, it's not always feasible to mount large satellite dishes in Britain, Griffiths said. ``In large blocks of tenements to have huge dishes everywhere, it's just totally impractical,'' he said. About 50,000 units have been installed in British homes so signals can be received directly from the powerful satellites, Griffiths said. Each unit consists of a 15.7-inch-square antenna and a receiver about the size of a videocassette recorder. British Satellite Broadcasting expects to have about 1 million units installed by the end of the year, Griffiths said.

DOC.HEAD: `Big Five' Meet on Expanding U.N. Military Role in Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ambassadors of the five permanent members of the Security Council and their senior military aides have held an extraordinary joint meeting to discuss a larger U.N. military role in the Persian Gulf crisis.
