Also Friday, the Security Council expressed ``anxiety'' over the fate of foreigners trapped in Kuwait and Iraq and called on the U.N. secretary-general to take all necessary steps to help them. The Security Council was scheduled to meet again today on the crisis, which began Aug. 2 when Iraqi tanks and troops poured into Kuwait and then massed at the Saudi Arabian border. French Ambassador Pierre Louis Blanc said the five permanent members of the Council met Friday to ``exchange information on the naval activities in the gulf and in the area.'' He spoke to reporters after the meeting at the French mission. The meeting was attended by U.N. envoys of the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union and by military advisers of the five governments, together known as the Security Council's Military Staff Committee. The committee was created 44 years ago but has been inactive, meeting on a perfunctory basis two times a month. Diplomats said Friday's meeting was not ordinary. It included senior U.S., British and French officers. A senior Soviet official was unable to attend and the level of the Chinese military was not known. No immediate indication surfaced that the five were moving to form a joint U.N. military command in the gulf, but Western observers said the group moved with extraordinary speed to discuss coordination and a U.N. military role. ``We won't have a U.N. army tomorrow,'' one observer said on condition of anonymity. ``But we could have exchange of information and coordination, letting each other know about rules of engagement. And that is quite significant. ``By U.N. standards, that is whirlwind progress,'' the observer said. Under the U.N. Charter, the Military Staff Committee is charged with coordinating all U.N. military actions of an enforcement nature, excluding peacekeeping. It is intended to organize and command joint military operations, which never have come into existence. The last time the U.N. flag was flown in a U.N. enforcement operation was during the 1950-53 Korean War. That war was not strictly a U.N. operation, however, and was handed over to the United States. Moscow has been pressing for an expanded U.N. peacekeeping role and for revival of the U.N. Military Staff Committee. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said Friday the Soviet Union would send troops to the gulf if the United Nations calls for a multilateral military force. Late Friday, the speaker of Iraq's parliament, Sadi Mahdi, said Iraq will hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against his country ends. His statement was carried by the official Iraqi news agency, monitored in Nicosia. Mahdi said foreigners would be spread throughout Iraq, housed in military and civilian installations. Hundreds of thousands of foreigners, including about 4,000 Britons and 2,500 Americans, were stranded when Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Another 500 Americans were in Iraq.

Pearl Bailey, the singer and actress known for her throaty drawl, her wit and warmth, is dead at 72. Her standbys included ``Hello, Dolly!'' and ``Bill Bailey, Won't You Please Come Home.'' Bailey collapsed Friday evening at a Holiday Inn where she had been staying with her husband, jazz drummer Louis Bellson. She was visiting her two sisters, Eura Robinson and Virgie Murray, and undergoing physical therapy. She died half an hour after being admitted to Thomas Jefferson Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Kellyann McDonell. The cause of death was not immediately known. Bailey had a history of heart ailments and underwent surgery last month to replace her arthritic left knee with a metal and plastic joint. An autopsy will be conducted in two or three days, McDonell said. In 1970, President Nixon named her America's ``ambassador of love'' to the world. She was a special delegate to the United Nations under the Ford, Reagan and Bush administrations. ``Pearl Bailey was the mother of the world,'' said Stan Irwin, her manager for 25 years. ``She was a very spiritual woman and she never recognized color. Her ideology was, `We are humans.''' She wrote humorous and inspirational books, including ``Hurry Up, America, and Spit.'' Last year she published an autobiography, ``Between You and Me.'' Bailey was well known for playing the conceited Dolly Gallagher Levi in the black version of the musical ``Hello, Dolly!'' on Broadway from 1967 to 1969. She also appeared on Broadway in ``House of Flowers'' and ``Bless You All,'' and enjoyed a long film career, with her movies including ``Carmen Jones'' and ``Porgy and Bess.'' ``I have lost one of the greatest friends I've ever had in my life,'' said veteran song-and-dance man Cab Calloway, who starred with Bailey in ``Hello, Dolly!'' She was one of show business' great personalities, cheering the loudest at Shea Stadium when the once-hapless New York Mets won the World Series in 1969 and dragging Johnny Carson from behind his desk for a fun-filled rendition of ``Our Love is Here to Stay.'' ``The entertainment world has lost one of the most creative performers of our time,'' said Carol Channing, who first played Dolly on Broadway in 1964. ``Her talent was unique and enduring and her warmth was felt by everyone in the audience.'' The langorous sexuality of her voice, her warm smile and eloquent gestures put audiences immediately at ease. Her direct personality translated smoothly from the nightclub stage and Broadway to film and television. Flipping a feather boa or swathed in chinchilla, ablaze with rhinestones and jewels, Bailey was renowned for her throwaway style of singing, a mumbling growl laced with husky patter. Among her best-loved songs were ``St. Louis Blues,'' ``Row, Row, Row,'' and ``That's Good Enough for Me.'' ``I'm more of a philosopher than a jazz singer,'' she said in a June interview with The New York Times. ``When people say, `Pearl, where did you get your style?' I tell them: `I have no style. I just sing songs.''' Bailey, who has been performing 57 of her 72 years, was one of the few entertainers who could still be called a trouper in the classic sense. But she considered herself foremost a singer. ``I'm not a comedienne,'' she once told an interviewer, ``I call myself a humorist. I tell stories to music and, thank God, in tune. I laugh at people who call me an actress.'' Born in Newport News, Va., on March 29, 1918, she was the daughter of a minister and the youngest of four children. Ancestors on both sides of the family included Creek Indians. She moved with her family as a child to Washington and later Philadelphia, where she made her debut at age 15, winning an amateur contest by singing ``Poor Butterfly.'' She moved from California with her husband of 38 years to the Arizona resort community of Lake Havesu in 1979. She also is survived by a son, Tony, and a daughter, Dee Dee.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Gathers Strength, Threatens Southern Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Yancy skimmed the northern tip of the Philippines' main Luzon island today with wind gusts of up to 91 miles per hour and was approaching southern Taiwan, the Manila weather bureau said. In a weather bulletin issued at noon (midnight EDT Friday), Yancy was centered 175 miles northeast of Basco City, the capital of Batanes province, an island group about 410 miles north of Manila. No casualties or major damage have been reported. Forecasters said Yancy gained strength overnight with sustained winds of 81 mph and gusts of 91 mph. Yancy also slowed down and was moving west-northwest at 7 mph, forecasters said. Senior weather forecaster Daniel Dimagiba said that if Yancy maintains its present course, the sixth major weather disturbance to strike the country this year will move out of Philippine territory by Sunday morning and hit southern Taiwan. Dimagiba said Yancy has a radius of 375 miles, which would mean its effect could be felt as far as the central Philippines. Provinces in the entire Luzon island, including Manila, have been placed on storm alert because of this, he added. Sea travel in the typhoon's path was ``extremely dangerous'' and the weather bureau had advised ships and smaller seacraft to stay in port. Philippine Airlines canceled eight flights from Manila to the affected areas. About 20 typhoons and storms hit the Philippines yearly.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Crime Experts To Advise Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is facing a crime wave, and it's turning for help to the city that gave the world ``Scarface'' Al Capone and the St. Valentine's Day Massacre. The Soviets are hunting down the latest in crime-fighting techniques from lie detectors to fingerprinting networks to communication systems. ``Their interest really kind of shook me up,'' Matt L. Rodriguez, a deputy superintendent for the Chicago Police Department, said Friday. A six-member team will leave for Moscow next month to teach Soviet police how to deal with such antisocial phenomena as bank holdups, restaurant arson, mugging and auto chop shops. The planned exchange follows a spring visit by Soviet officials who met with experts from Chicago's police department and the Office of International Criminal Justice at the University of Illinois. ``I recall when they came through here that they were quite emphatic,'' said Rodriguez, a member of the team. ``They came here to learn and didn't want any side trips. They wanted business meetings.'' Georgi Oganov, a spokesman at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, D.C., said such crimes as drug trafficking, tax evasion and fraud are on the rise in the Soviet Union. ``This is a group of crimes that accompany any kind of radical change or economic movement such as we have,'' Oganov said. ``We have, for 70 years, been very stable ... Obviously, now we have the upsurge of little-known crimes.'' Vasily Trushin, a deputy Interior Ministry official, said on Soviet television last September that serious crime was increasing throughout the nation. He said more than 1.5 million crimes were reported in the Soviet Union during the first eight months of 1989 _ a 33.2 percent increase over the same period in 1988. More alarming, Trushin also reported a 40.8 percent increase in such violent offenses as murder, rape and robbery. The U.S. delegation will be armed with reports from the police department's organized crime division, one of the first in the nation to have a fingerprint identification system. It also broke ground in the 1960s in the field of criminal communications and had the first crime laboratory in the nation, Rodriguez said.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Port Could Serve as Sanctions Loophole for Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: This Red Sea port, Jordan's only outlet to the sea, could prove of crucial importance in the success of the international effort to clamp sanctions on Iraq and force it to withdraw from Kuwait. Shipping sources say even if the U.S. Navy tries to prevent merchandise and food supplies from reaching Iraq through Aqaba, it will be unable to determine what is Jordan's and what is Iraq's. Local importers say they are already placing orders for goods they intend to channel from Aqaba to the eastern border with Iraq, in violation of mandatory United Nations sanctions imposed since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. King Hussein has said he will abide by the sanctions but wants to resolve the issue of how and to what extent sanctions should be applied by Jordan, whose economy is heavily dependent on trade with Iraq. President Bush, at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, met with Hussein Thursday and said later: ``I can't say I am satisfied, but what I am is encouraged'' that Jordan intends to abide by the sanctions decision. Asked if the king assured him Jordan would stop Iraqi goods transiting Aqaba, Bush said flatly ``Yes.'' But Hussein told reporters that Jordan was still trying to find out from the U.N. ``exactly what these sanctions mean.'' The monarch said Aqaba was Jordan's ``only outlet to the sea and to the rest of the world'' and could not be shut entirely. Crown Prince Hassan on Friday told Britain's Independent Television News that Jordan stands to suffer perhaps more economically than any other country as a result of the U.N. sanctions. Pending clarification from the United Nations, ships continue to unload cargo in Aqaba. Scores of heavy trucks, many with the distinctive yellow Iraqi markings, rumble along the desert highway on their way inland. Daily, many can be seen crossing the border into Iraq. ``As long as goods continue to reach Aqaba, ostensibly for the local Jordanian market, part are bound to find their way across the border,'' one Jordanian merchant said on condition of anonymity. He said local importers, who like most Jordanians are opposed to the imposition of sanctions against Iraq, are determined to find ways to continue channeling vital supplies. Shipping sources in Aqaba said on condition of anonymity that the embargo was also strongly opposed by the 5,000 dock workers and 20,000 truck drivers who would lose their jobs if the port were closed to Iraqi cargo. ``All these people have a vested interest for the violation of the embargo, quite apart from supporting Saddam Hussein like most Jordanians,'' one source said, referring to the Iraqi president. Hassan said the issue was not just one of dollars and cents for Jordan, but that there is ``tremendous public opinion'' in favor of Saddam, who is seen among many Arabs as a champion of the poor. The prevalent belief among Jordanians is that short of a total blockade of Aqaba, plugging the sanctions loophole is virtually impossible. There was no unloading of ships at Aqaba on Friday because of the Moslem weekly holiday. But port officials said normal work would resume today on the 15 ships docked in the port. Before the gulf crisis, an average of 35 ships were in the port daily, the shipping officials said. Lloyd's List International, the authoritative shipping newspaper of the insurance underwriters, Lloyds of London, said Thursday sanctions against Iraq had cut cargo handling at Aqaba by 80 percent. The newspaper said all cargo bound for Iraq had ceased, although such exports are difficult to track. The publication estimated that Aqaba's proportion of cargo destined for Iraq would normally be about 70 percent. The shipping sources said much of the cargo leaving the port by truck was from warehouses in Aqaba's free port area. They said stored goods exceeded $10 million in value.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I want to pay for college and law school _ otherwise I'll end up a bartender.'' _ James Byrne, 23, of Owego, N.Y., who thinks the generous working conditions in Saudi Arabia are worth the risk of being caught in a war.

``Pearl Bailey was the mother of the world. She was a very spiritual woman and she never recognized color. Her ideology was, `We are humans.''' _ Stan Irwin, the longtime manager of entertainer Pearl Bailey, who died Friday at age 72.

``The important thing I see in an event like this is not only ... the fun and razzle dazzle. It's a way of showing the people that it takes years to become that good. It takes tradition, positive attitude and lots of hard work.'' _Cenek Petak, a Prague musician discussing today's scheduled Rolling Stones concert, the first time the band has played in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Convention Features Pop Music and TV Stars From 1960s
DOC.TEXT: It's a trip into the groovy world of long hair, bell-bottom jeans and love beads. Promoters say they're expecting thousands of people to turn out for this weekend's ``Celebration of the '60s Convention,'' a festival of local pop music and TV cultures of the era. Fans from as far as Japan and Australia are expected at the convention at a downtown hotel featuring actors Davy Jones of ``The Monkees'' and Butch Patrick, who played Eddie on ``The Munsters.'' Lead singers from such 1960s Chicago bands as the Buckinghams, the Cryan Shames, the Mauds and the Ides of March also are billed for the three-day convention that ends Sunday. ``It's just been one big buzz,'' said Australian Jeff Wunsch, 33, one of the 70 fans who showed up Friday night for opening festivities. Wunsch said he took out a loan to travel to the convention. ``I just couldn't have missed this,'' he said. ``It's like seeing old friends. You play their records. You see them on TV.'' ``We just believe that the music and the culture of the '60s will never die,'' said organizer Mike Bush. ``People might not necessarily remember the names of these bands. But if they hear the melody and a few words, they say `Oh yeah.' It's the music that's the strong point.'' Also billed are the Cowsills _ the musical family that inspired the television show ``The Partridge Family'' and performed such hits as ``Hair'' and ``The Rain, the Park and Other Things.'' Tommy Boyce and Bobby Hart planned to reunite at the convention. The pair, who wrote many of the songs made popular by ``The Monkees,'' say their songs are still played across the country because they're uncomplicated and easy on the ear. ``We're into teen-age love,'' Hart said. ``All we've ever done is fun stuff. The stuff people want to remember.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Germans Agree on Essence of Unification; Signing Possible Next Month
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet and West German foreign ministers say they have agreed on the main points of a German unification plan and that the Allies may sign a treaty giving up control in less than a month. ``We are going to change opinions about the future of united Germany and the Soviet Union,'' Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze predicted at a joint news conference Friday with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The new treaty will cover cooperation in the economy, trade, science, technology, culture and Soviet troops stationed in former communist East Germany, Shevardnadze said. The Soviet foreign minister said he expects to initial and possibly sign the final document giving up the four Allies' authority over Germany on Sept. 12 in Moscow, as scheduled. Shevardnadze and Genscher said they agreed on the essence of the concluding document on external aspects of unification, although a few final details remained. Shevardnadze said he expects the other parties in the ``two-plus-four'' talks to agree with their work. The ``two'' are East Germany and West Germany and the ``four'' are the World War II allied victors: the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. Genscher said initialing of the two-plus-four document next month would show that there is no external reason to prevent German unification, which he expects to occur Oct. 13-14. Shevardnadze said the document might even be signed Sept. 12. The four powers and the united Germany then would be expected to ratify the treaty under their respective constitutional processes, he said. Genscher said he expects West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to spell out details for the Soviet-German treaty proposal in a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which would be sent before the Sept. 12 meeting. Shevardnadze said the two sides also had agreed on ``material and financial concerns regarding the presence and withdrawal of Soviet troops'' from East Germany. Genscher said final details will be worked out in meetings between the Soviet and West German finance ministers Aug. 24. West Germany has agreed to help pay for the Soviet soldiers' upkeep because the Soviet Union is short of convertible currency, which is necessary now that East Germany has switched to use of the West German mark. Cost of this agreement to West Germany for the second half of this year is estimated to be $780 million. Genscher also said East Germany and West Germany will issue statements before Sept. 12 on their respective final troop ceilings. Gorbachev and Kohl agreed at a meeting at a Soviet mountain resort in July on the most difficult issues of German unification. These included the united Germany's membership in NATO and reduction of its combined armed forces from 600,000 to 370,000 over three to four years. The Soviets agreed to withdraw their 380,000 soldiers from East German territory in the same time period. Genscher said the two men also discussed the withdrawal of the four powers' troops from Berlin. The earlier Kohl-Gorbachev meeting decided that Western soldiers could stay in Berlin as long as Soviet troops remained in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Young AIDS Patient Embraced By Pope During 1987 Visit Dies
DOC.TEXT: Brendan O'Rourke, a boy embraced by Pope John Paul II in 1987 in a symbolic gesture of compassion and acceptance of people with AIDS, has died from an AIDS-related illness. He was 7 years old. Brendan, who was born premature and contracted the disease from a blood transfusion at the age of 2 months, died Friday at the University of California, San Francisco Medical Center, the hospital said. The cause of death was not given. The boy's mother, Elaine O'Rourke, said Brendan was hospitalized with pneumonia last month. His funeral is scheduled for Monday. A photograph of the pope reaching through a crowd to embrace the boy during the 1987 papal visit to the United States was printed in newspapers across the world. ``That picture tells a great story,'' said Monsignor James. D. McKay, the former pastor at St. Cecelia's, which the boy's family attended. ``When the pope embraced him, it was sort of a symbol, an expression of acceptance and compassion and encouragement and support for him and all the things he represented: children, the disadvantaged,'' McKay said. Brendan met with the pope again during a 1988 visit to the Vatican for the beatification of Junipero Serra, the founder of California's mission system. Brendan and his family all received communion from the pope during the trip. Brendan wasn't phased by all the media attention his encounters with the pope received, his mother said. ``He was just a neat kid,'' she said. ``After a while he got to be a bit of a ham.'' His knack for humor was evident even during his hospital stay, she said. ``At one time, he was playing harmonica in the hallway with a sign saying `Please give money,''' Mrs. O'Rourke said. Brendan collected $7, which he intended to spend on toys. ``The last two days he was very sick,'' she said. ``But he went peacefully this morning.'' Said McKay, ``He knew he wasn't going to have a long, normal life. And he seemed to be able to deal with that rather well for somebody of his age. For somebody even 10 times his age.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President Urges Pardons of Husband's Slayers
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is asking the legislature to pardon at least five men accused of murdering her popular publisher-husband, a killing that set off the 1979 revolution. In a letter to National Assembly speaker Miriam Arguello, the president expressed hope the pardons of those involved in the fatal shooting of La Prensa publisher Pedro Joaquin Chamorro will help pacify the country. ``In the spirit of national reconciliation which I am trying to encourage in our long-suffering Nicaragua, this is an opportune moment to make this pardon effective,'' Mrs. Chamorro's letter said. Excerpts of the covering letter accompanying an amnesty bill were published Thursday by La Prensa, an afternoon newspaper and for many years Nicaragua's only opposition daily. Mrs. Chamorro took office April 25 after defeating the leftist Sandinistas by a landslide in elections three months before, and one her campaign's main promises was to help bring peace and conciliate feuding factions. Pedro Joaquin Chamorro had gained widespread popularity for denouncing in his newspaper human rights abuses, corruption and other excesses under President Anastasio Somoza, the last of a long line of strongmen who ruled Nicaragua with an iron fist for 42 years. His automobile was ambushed as he drove to work Jan. 10, 1978, and he was shot to death on a Managua street. His death set off days of violent demonstrations and helped rally opponents around the leftist Sandinista movement which seized power in a revolution a year later. La Prensa continued to expose and criticize government mismanagement and other excesses under the Sandinistas, who subjected it to strict censorship and closed it for long periods of time because of it. Mrs. Chamorro asked the legislature to approve the pardons as soon as possible, saying she ``is confident the National Assembly will respond with the same sentiments of forgiveness and reconciliation.'' Sources at the National Assembly, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the legislature will start debating the bill at its next session on Wednesday. ``It will be discussed and approved urgently,'' one source said. The draft bill mentions no names but specifies that ``those favored by this pardon will be freed immediately'' after the assembly approves it. Police at the time arrested five men described as hired guns _ Silvio Pena, Domingo Acevedo, Silvio Vega, Harold Cedeno and Juan Ramon Acevedo. All were convicted and sentenced from 21 to 30 years in prison without parole. On Thursday, the Sandinista newspaper Barricada said Mrs. Chamorro also asked that 82 other common criminals be pardoned along with the five men. The Chamorro family, after the Sandinistas took power, also filed charges against Anastasio Somoza Portocarrere, a son of the dictator, a Somoza official named Fausto Zelaya and Cuban exile Pedro Ramos for engineering the murder. All three fled into exile after Somoza fell, and Barricada said Mrs. Chamorro's petition did not specify if they would be included in the pardon.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Grim Reaper in Case Of Mistaken Identity
DOC.TEXT: The Grim Reaper has been hauled into a police station and stripped of his dreaded scythe. The spectre of death was actually an actor, Damien Thibodeaux, who got lost Friday in Boston's financial district while promoting a murder mystery being staged at a waterfront restaurant. Police, alarmed by the reactions he was getting, intervened. ``He was just walking around with that thing,'' said Officer Richard Estrella. ``The kids were scared.'' Police frisked Thibodeaux, who was dressed in a black cowl and wore pale makeup, and took him back the police station. No charges were filed, but officers told Thibodeaux they would keep his sickle and return it to his employer. Thibodeaux, who is originally from Louisiana, said he had just moved to Boston. ``I was promoting a dinner theater show for (Comedy) Showcase Productions and my job was to pass out fliers around town,'' he said. ``It's my first job in Boston. I won't be doing it again.''

DOC.HEAD: Square Dance Gets Official Status in Illinois
DOC.TEXT: Swing your pardners, Illinoisans. Now do-si-do! It's official. The more than 12,000 members in Illinois' 212 square dancing clubs can now allemande and bow their corners to the call of the newly designated state symbol. Gov. James R. Thompson signed legislation Friday at the Illinois State Fair making the square dance the official American folk dance of Illinois. ``Square dancing is as endemic to Illinois as the prairie plants that border our agricultural landscape,'' Thompson said. ``It is fitting that we recognize the significance of our particular regional favorite, the square dance,'' he said. Similar legislation has been approved in 11 other states.

DOC.HEAD: Showers in the Midwest; Fog in the East
DOC.TEXT: Showers fell in the Midwest early today and fog settled over much of the East. Skies were mostly clear around the rest of the country. The East was looking for continued hot, humid weather with highs in the 80s and 90s and thunderstorms stretching from Maine to Ohio. A high pressure system was expected to bring stifling heat and humidity to the South. Skies were expected to be sunny, expect for some thunderstorm activity in Florida and Georgia, with temperatures climbing into the 90s. A large band of showers and thunderstorms were forming over the Midwest, extending from the Dakotas into Wisconsin and Oklahoma. Autumn-like weather was arriving in the Great Lakes, with strong high pressure from Canada driving temperatures into the 50s. Rain was also expected in the Pacific Northwest, with cool air spreading showers around the region. The highs for most of the area were expected to be in the 90s. Some parts of Southern California and a large section of Arizona could expect temperatures to rise above 100 degrees. The nation's high temperature Friday was 105 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., Havasu City and Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Base Closes Under Washington Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The United States has formally handed over one of its military bases, making the naval communications station the first of two installations to close in Greece under Washington's worldwide defense cuts. Control of the Nea Makri base, 20 miles northeast of Athens, was officially passed to the Greek navy during a flag-lowering ceremony Friday. The facility was set up in 1963 to electronically monitor ships in the Aegean and serve as a communications link for the U.S. 6th Fleet in the Mediterranean. At the height of operations, 312 U.S. active-duty staff were employed at the base and 125 local employees. U.S. authorities have been winding down operations at Nea Makri since April when they pulled down the base's tallest antenna to symbolize the impending closure. Rear Adm. Peter H. Cressy, Commander Fleet Air Mediterranean, represented the United States at the closing ceremony along with U.S. Ambassador to Greece, Michael Sotirhos. Representing the Greek navy was Rear Adm. Iraklis Krikos. Striking Greek personnel at the facility demonstrated during Friday's ceremony under a long-running pay dispute with base officials. They claim to be owed $36 million in back pay and social security contributions. The strikers also demand new jobs in the Greek civil service on closure of Nea Makri, and another U.S. base at Hellenikon, near Athens. Hellenikon air base, established in 1947, is scheduled to close early next year. The United States' two remaining bases, both on the northern coast of Crete, will continue to operate under an eight-year defense pact signed by the two countries last July. The Souda Bay naval facility provides support for U.S. naval forces in the Mediterranean while reconnaisance aircraft use a nearby airfield. Iraklion air station is an electronic surveillance and relay base. It monitors radio communications and Soviet activity in the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Prime Minister Invites Solzhenitsyn to Visit
DOC.TEXT: Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev has urged exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn to accept his restored Soviet citizenship and return home as Silayev's guest, according to media reports today. In a letter published on the front page of Sovietskaya Rossia newspaper, Silayev said Solzhenitsyn's homecoming was ``one of those moves that our homeland needs as much as air. ``The interests of the state and its future destiny compel me to ask you and your family to accept an invitation to be my personal guests at any time you choose,'' wrote Silayev, premier of the largest Soviet republic. Solzhenitsyn, 71, was one of 23 people whose citizenship was restored Wednesday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who also apologized for two decades of political repression by previous Soviet leaders. The Nobel Prize-winning Solzhenitsyn, 71, was arrested for treason in February 1974, forced onto a plane to Germany and stripped of his citizenship. He now lives in Cavendish, Vt., and says he won't return unless all his books have been published in the Soviet Union and are widely available. Solzhenitsyn's wife, Natalia, said her husband also wants the expulsion order and treason charges lifted before he will consider taking back his Soviet citizenship. Solzhenitsyn's books include ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' about the horrors of Josef Stalin's prison camps, ``One Day In The Life Of Ivan Denisovich,'' ``Cancer Ward,'' ``August 1914'' and ``The First Circle.'' Several of his works have been published in the Soviet Union but few novels from any author are widely available in the shortage-plagued society. Silayev, calling Solzhenitsyn ``the great son of the Russian people,'' said his invitation was motivated ``by the common love of the long-suffering Russian land and its people. ``Your words about Russia have rung out the world over, invoking its fate in the cruel and ruthless 20th century,'' he wrote. ``Today, your words have reached our homeland as well, and they are needed everywhere, in all walks of life, religious and spiritual, cultural, public and economic.'' Silayev said that at a time Soviet society is going through tumultuous and divisive changes, ``your coming to Russia is, in my view, one of those moves that our homeland needs as much as air.'' Soviet officials have identified only 10 of the 23 people whose citizenship Gorbachev restored under presidential decree. They were deprived of their rights as Soviet citizens between the years 1966 and 1988. Besides Solzhenitsyn, they are chess champion Victor Korchnoi; writers Vasily Aksyonov, Vladimir Voinovich, Lev Kopelev, Georgi Valdimov and Valeri Tarsis; scientists Yuri Orlov and Valeri Chalidze; and artist Oskar Rabin. The full list is to be published later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Stepfather Gets Life Sentence In Potty-Training Murder
DOC.TEXT: A man who killed his 2-year-old stepson by plunging him headfirst into a toilet escaped being condemned to death because the judge thought a death penalty would be overturned on appeal. ``I feel the court has no choice but to follow the jury's recommendation for life'' in prison, Circuit Judge Randall McDonald ruled Friday. Thomas Coe, 23, must serve 25 years before being eligible for parole. He was convicted of first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in the death of Bradley McGee. In response to the killing, the state Legislature rewrote child welfare laws to put the child's safety above the goal of keeping families together, and allocated $79 million for more child-protection social workers. McDonald said the sentence was appropriate, since he could find no case where the death penalty was upheld for a child-abuse murder. ``I guess you can get the death penalty if you kill a man,'' responded Pam Kirkland, the child's foster mother for 14 months. ``But you get life if you kill a child.'' Bradley died of massive head injuries July 28, 1989, only two months after he was ordered returned to Coe, and his mother, Sheryl McGee Coe. Coe testified being angered when he picked up Bradley by the ankles and slammed him into the commode as a punishment for soiling his pants. But he said he never meant to harm the child. Coe's wife testified that her husband routinely ground his fist and cayenne pepper into Bradley's genitals, and forced him to pick his feces off the floor with his mouth. Mrs. Coe, 21, earlier this year pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in her son's death and is serving a 30-year prison term. Jurors who convicted Coe on July 30 were deadlocked 6-6 in the penalty phase, resulting in an automatic recommendation for life. Defense attorney Robert Norgard said he planned to appeal both the conviction and sentence. Prosecutors refused comment. Bradley's death sparked public outrage because it occurred while he was under the supervision of state social workers. Bradley's main caseworker, Margaret Barber, was convicted of child abuse for disregarding a psychological report that described the Coes as unfit parents. She was sentenced to three years' probation.

DOC.HEAD: Tanks Are Rolling Out, Stones Are Rolling In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th pvs, `A gigantic...' to CLARIFY Letna Plain atop hill near downtown Prague; Pickup 17th, `A video...'; Stones set to play at 3 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Six months after Soviet tanks began rolling out, the Rolling Stones have rolled in, marking a high point for the new cultural freedom long denied by the country's ousted Communist rulers. The band plays for the first time in Czehoslovakia today at Prague's Strahov Stadium, listed in the Guiness Book of World Records as the world's largest, with a capacity for 240,000 people. ``It's a great opportunity for us to play to people who could never hear us before,'' Keith Richards, the band's lead guitarist said in a documentary aired Thursday on state television. Proceeds of the concert will go to the Czechoslovak Children's Foundation, which benefits handicapped children, Romanian refugees and victims of the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, according to media reports in London. The charity is headed by Olga Havel, wife of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel. Unused for the last five years, the stadium was given a new coat of paint before technicians started assembling the mammoth sound system and elaborate stage for the Rolling Stones concert. Close to 100,000 thousand people are expected to enjoy ``Sympathy For The Devil,'' ``Jumping Jack Flash'' and other hits from the band's 25-year-long career, rarely heard publicly in Czechoslovakia under Communist rule. On Feb. 26 Soviet tanks began leaving Czechoslovakia, ending two decades of military occupation and sealing the fate of Czehoslovakia's hard-line Communist rulers, ousted in a popular revolution late last year. And on Aug. 12, the first truck of The Rolling Stones world tour started rolling into Prague, marking the new winds of liberalization after forty years of Communist rule and state-decreed culture. The impact of the Stones' arrival has been dramatic in Prague, where over the years fans have had to buy the band's albums at inflated prices on the black market. ``It's a dream come true, something I never hoped to see in my life,'' said Ivan Kadanka, a 43-year-old drummer, whose band will perform as a support act to the Rolling Stones show. ``It's a unique experience, something I am going to tell my children and grandchildren about.'' If the emotional content of the performance is overwhelming for musicians, the sheer size of the show exceeds the imagination of Czech promoters. ``When we started talking about it in May, we were six people who put together $400 of capital, and started daydreaming about a show that costs $1.5 million to produce,'' said Milan Pesik of Mars Productions, a promotion group. Pesik said the Stones thought the promotion group was ``a bunch of phonies who wanted to have fun at the band's expense.'' It was only the invitation of President Havel that got things moving, he said. Soon an unprecedented publicity campaign was unleashed in the country's media, a stranger to the hype of big-time show business. ``Hi, I'm Mick Jagger. The Stones are rolling into Prague,'' the band's singer and leader said in Czech to millions of TV viewers for two weeks, several times a day. That message established Jagger as a household name in a country that in the past had virtually banned rock music. A gigantic red tongue in a huge mouth _ the Stones's traditional logo _ appeared atop a hill where a statue of Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin once stood. The hill, the summit of which is called Letna Plain, looks out over the city center. A video screening of the show on the American leg of the show was held on Prague's Old Town Square Monday and attracted about 10,000 viewers. Supraphon, the state record company and Bonton, its newly born private competitor, released the band's latest album, ``Steel Wheels,'' on unusually short notice in a country where world hits usually reach the charts years after their popularity has faded in the West. But for some, the Stones concert has a particular meaning at a time Czechoslovakia struggles to implement market and democratic reforms. ``The important thing I see in an event like this is not only ... the fun and razzle dazzle,'' said Cenek Petak, a veteran saxophone player. ``It's a way of showing the people that it takes years to become that good. It takes tradition, positive attitude and lots of hard work. ``It's something you cannot achieve overnight by waving a magic wand, and that I think is a message this country should hear right now,'' Petak said.

DOC.HEAD: Families Wait For Word From Relatives Trapped In Mideast
DOC.TEXT: The father of a 14-year-old girl whose India-bound plane was intercepted in Kuwait by invading Iraqi troops implored the government of Saddam Hussein to release her. ``I'm hoping and I'm praying and I'm making a desperate plea to the Iraqi government,'' said Dr. Chandra Polam, a Pittsburgh cardiologist. ``She's a child. She's by herself. Show mercy.'' The British Airways plane was intercepted by Iraqi soldiers when it made a stopover in Kuwait on an Aug. 2 flight to New Delhi. Vinil Polam, going to visit her grandparents, joined the thousands of Americans caught up in the Persian Gulf crisis. Airline officials have told Polam his daughter is safe at a hotel near the Kuwait airport. But that has done little to allay more than two weeks filled with anxiety, confusion and frustration. The sense of alarm that relatives feel was heightened Friday when the speaker of Iraq's parliament said all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' _ presumably including the 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait _ would be held until the threat of war against his country ends. He said they would be spread throughout the country, housed in military and civilian targets. Relatives of other Americans and foreigners stranded in Kuwait and Iraq by the invasion are desperately seeking news of their loved ones. Some have organized support groups. Others are eating and sleeping by their telephones. For Mary Trundy, waiting for word from her twin brother trapped in Kuwait is all frighteningly familiar. In 1979, 43-year-old John Stevenson escaped from Iran just hours before militants seized the U.S. Embassy. ``It's a nightmare that doesn't end,'' Trundy said from her home in Brockton, Mass., about 20 miles south of Boston. ``It's just too much now, two times in a row.'' Stevenson called his sister twice the day of the invasion, and hoped to escape to Saudi Arabia the following day. ``He said it was just like Iran again, only that they weren't shooting in the streets,'' she said. In eastern Iowa, Nedra Hanken of Monticello awaited word of her 31-year-old daughter, Beth, who has lived with her husband the past five years in Kuwait. ``We haven't heard anything and I don't know that any other American families have, either,'' she said. In New Harmony, Ind., Joan Khaja's 12 brothers and sisters were concerned when she left home for Kuwait last month, five months pregnant, to take her two small children to visit their grandparents. Now that concern has turned to fear, and Khaja's family maintains a 24-hour vigil near television and telephone. In Odessa, Texas, Donnita Cole said, ``You wait for the telephone to ring. When it doesn't ring, you worry to death.'' Her husband is an employee of OGE Drilling Co. and has been living in Kuwait City. Mrs. Cole said she had developed a mini-support network of other families in the same situation. ``We kind of give each other moral support when one of us starts to crack a little,'' she said. ``I think we're going to be in for quite a long spell on this.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens to Use Weapons of `Mass Destruction'
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq threatened today to use weapons of ``mass destruction'' against any attacker. It did not specify the weapons it referred to, but Baghdad has an arsenal of chemical weapons and long-range missiles. Also today, Iraq indicated for the first time that it would use soldiers who had been deployed against Iran to bolster troops facing a growing multinational force in Saudi Arabia. Iraq on Friday began withdrawing thousands of troops from Iranian territory occupied since their 1980-88 war. The Iraqi army daily, al-Qaddasiyah, declared today in an editorial that the 30 divisions which had been facing Iran in the north would now be deployed in the south. The daily said the troops ``which are leaving Iran's borders ... and the high readiness of our air force will be an additional might to what we had already prepared against the aggressive forces.'' Al-Qaddisiyah also said Baghdad was prepared to use all the weapons at its disposal against aggressors. ``Weapons of mass destruction and strategic deterrence possessed by Iraq will be lying in wait to turn those who contemplate committing aggression into scattered pieces,'' the daily said. Iraq has used chemical weapons against its own Kurdish minority, and against Iranian forces during the Iraq-Iran war. It was not known how many of the 30 Iraqi divisions, more than 200,000 men, would be moved to Kuwait or the Saudi front. The Iraqis are believed to have at least seven divisions in Kuwait and more than 120,000 troops massed on the border with Saudi Arabia. Another newspaper, the government-run al-Thawra, said President Bush's order authorizing U.S. ships to intercept vessels heading to or from Iraq violated international law. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz called on other nations to oppose Bush's move. The Iraqi News Agency said al-Thawra asserted Iraq's determination to confront the United States if necessary. ``Bush orders to U.S. warships to intercept all ships heading to Iraq and leaving it is a clear violation to the United Nations charter and the basis of international laws,'' the daily said. Aziz said Bush's order set a precedent for any nation to intercept shipping ``if the world does not reject this abnormal behavior and foil it to defend the international law,'' INA reported.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto's Husband Says Police Trying to Frame Him
DOC.TEXT: The husband of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today claimed that police are encouraging his friends and associates to help authorities him on corruption charges. ``They're taking them in every day telling them to sign blank letters,'' said Asif Ali Zardari, who accompanied his wife back to the federal capital for the first time since her government was dismissed nearly two weeks ago. In the past week, several people have been arrested in Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sindh on charges ranging from corruption to gun-running. ``It's a very calculated effort to get to her (Ms. Bhutto) through me,'' Zardari said. ``If they hit me, it hurts her.'' Riot police held back hundreds of wailing women today trying to catch a brief glimpse of the former prime minister as she addressed 3,000 supporters. ``We don't want to go into any court other than to the court of the people,'' Ms. Bhutto said. ``I don't need any certificate of clearance from this government.'' A stunned Ms. Bhutto left the federal capital on Aug. 7 after President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her 20-month-old government on a variety of charges ranging from corruption to ineptitude. Ishaq Khan appointed a caretaker Cabinet of Ms. Bhutto's enemies and former allies. He has proposed judicial tribunals to investigate corruption charges. Zadari stood by his wife as she addressed her supporters. Her opponents have labeled him ``Mr. 10 Percent,'' a reference to the amount he's accused of charging people seeking government contracts. Ms. Bhutto and Zardari have repeatedly denied the charges, and none has been proved.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Daughter Released from Jail
DOC.TEXT: Zoia Ceausescu, daughter of deposed and executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, was released from jail this morning, where she had been detained while under investigation for corruption. She was picked up from the central Bucharest prison by her brother Valentin, who was released Friday. The two refused to speak to reporters and left in a five-car convoy to an unknown destination. Also released today were Zoia's husband, Mircea Oprean, and Poliana Cristescu, the former wife of the late dictator's youngest son, Nicu. All four had been accused of various counts of corruption and ``undermining the national economy.'' The four had been under arrest since the December revolution that overthrew of Nicolae Ceausescu, a Communist hard-liner. Although the military prosecution had asked for a 30-day extension of their detention, the Bucharest military tribunal decided the investigation into their crimes ``can be carried out without maintaining their state of preventative detention.'' It is unclear when their trials could take place. The trial of Nicu reopens on Tuesday in the central town of Sibiu, where he had served as Communist Party boss under his father. He is also charged with ``complicity in genocide'' for allegedly ordering the shooting of demonstrators during the December revolution. Nicu was widely regarded as a playboy with political ambitions, but Zoia and Valentin had distanced themselves from their father's iron-fisted and corrupt rule. The trial of Nicolae Ceausescu's sister, Maria Agache, also charged with corruption, reconvened briefly Thursday, then adjourned until Sept. 13.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Requests Arab Foreign Ministers' Meeting on Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Egypt today asked Arab foreign ministers to meet in Cairo in a week to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Hassaan el-Abbadi, Egypt's assistant foreign minister, told reporters the meeting of the Arab League council ministers was proposed for Aug. 26. The ministers were to hear a report from Chadli Klibi, the league's secretary-general, on whether a resolution adopted by an Arab summit in Cairo on Aug. 10 is being implemented. That resolution sanctioned the dispatch of Arab forces to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries requesting help in defending against a possible Iraqi attack. The measure, approved by 12 of the Arab League's 21 members, also demanded immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and reinstatement of the Kuwaiti government the Iraqis ousted after the Aug. 2 invasion. The resolution called on Klibi to report back to the League's council ``within 15 days'' on its implementation. Except for dispatch of Arab troops to Saudi Arabia, little has been done to carry it out. But Arab diplomatic sources said the aim of the meeting was probably to keep pressure on Baghdad. Mubarak has been a leader in diplomatic efforts to end the crisis, including a mediation bid just prior to the invasion. He also organized the Aug. 10 Arab League meeting, which came two days after Kuwait's annexation. The gathering brought heated arguments by the Iraqi delegation and the representatives of the deposed Kuwait government. Mubarak has said he still hopes for a peaceful resolution to the crisis. The Iraqis say the annexation of Kuwait is irrevocable, and Baghdad considers the emirate a southern region of Iraq. Egypt has sent a force to Saudi Arabia that President Hosni Mubarak says will not exceed 2,000 men. Morocco was reported to have sent 1,200 men and Syria a handful of staff officers.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Tops 200 As Rival War Bands Clash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4 grafs for grafs 5-8, `The country's...began Sunday.' with 4 grafs to UPDATE death toll. Pickup 9th, `Police armed...'
DOC.TEXT: Black factions fought running battles today with axes, spears and homemade guns, raising the toll from this week's fighting to more than 200 dead and hundreds wounded. The anti-apartheid African National Congress on Friday accused the government of encouraging the violence in the black townships to justify repressive measures and to prolong white rule. Police fired tear gas to disperse rival bands of Zulus, a tribe that has largely rejected a future government controlled Nelson Mandela's ANC, and the pro-ANC Xhosas in the sprawling black township of Soweto. War bands burned houses and stoned vehicles, witnesses said. The country's top police official, Gen. Johann Van Der Merwe, today ordered military and police reinforcements to Soweto, where at least 53 people have been killed and more than 300 wounded since Thursday. So far, only armed police have patrolled in Soweto. ``This strong contingent will do everything possible to stop the senseless violence,'' Van Der Merwe said in a statement. ``It's a very tense situation. There's a lot of tension and people are arming themselves,'' one witness said. Officials put the total dead at 205 in clashes that began Sunday. Police armed with assault rifles and shotguns roared through parts of Soweto in armored vehicles and trucks. Youths who built barricades with rocks and burning tires were dispersed with tear gas. Police and residents also reported looting and indiscriminate gang attacks on individuals. A family of six, including a 5-month-old baby and three other children, were badly burned when a firebomb was thrown into their shack in Kagiso township, north of Soweto. The bloody conflict erupted in the township of Thokoza east of Johannesburg on Sunday, and spread during the week to four more areas, including Soweto, southwest of Johannesburg. The fighting pits Zulus of the Inkatha movement against mostly Xhosa supporters of the African National Congress. The ANC accused the government's security forces Friday of plotting to use Inkatha to stir up tribal rivalry in the townships around Johannesburg. More than 5,000 people have died in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in the eastern Natal province in the past five years. The ANC issued a statement saying state security forces in collusion with Inkatha were trying to ``spread a climate of fear and terror in the towns which are known to be strongholds of the ANC. They want to provoke a mass backlash among blacks and whites in support of tough repressive measures by the government in order to undermine the process towards peace.'' The spreading unrest led to an unscheduled meeting Thursday between Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk. They have been meeting to clear the way for formal negotiations on an end to white minority rule. Inkatha President Mangosuthu Buthelezi said ANC supporters ``frequently insult, denigrate and attack Inkatha members on the trains, in the buses, and other places, which has resulted in the conflict in Soweto.'' Buthelezi, making his statement in Ulundi in Natal province, said Inkatha was committed to democracy and opposed to violence. But, he said, ANC slurs against Inkatha had been extremely provocative and ``until respect for one another is observed, it will be difficult to obtain peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Minister Indicates Saudis Will Increase Oil Output
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia plans to increase its oil output by up to 2 million barrels a day to help offset the shortfall on world markets caused by the Iraqi invasion, the oil minister indicated today. But he said Saudi Arabia alone cannot make up for the 4 million barrels of oil a day that international markets lost when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and most nations responded by imposing an oil embargo on Baghdad. By invading and annexing Kuwait, Iraq gained control of about 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, and the withdrawal of its crude from the market has caused oil and gas prices to soar. The Saudi oil minister, Hisham Nazer, spoke with reporters today at a news conference in the summer capital of Jiddah. He said that if an emergency session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries proposed by the kingdom does not occur ``then it will be left for each member state to decide alone'' on the increase in output. He said that even if Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, increases its output by the maximum of 2 million barrels a day, it cannot make up for the 4 million barrels daily that the sanctions on Iraq and occupied Kuwait removed from world markets. Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates could increase output by half a million barrels per day, Nazer said, but ``this would leave us with 1 million barrels less.'' Meanwhile, the turmoil in the Middle East, where thousands of U.S. troops are being deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack, contineu to create havoc on world markets. Unleaded gasoline hit a record high Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as crude oil prices shot up and speculators kept betting that the Middle East standoff would curtail supplies. September wholesale unleaded gas futures soared to as high as 96.25 cents before settling at 95.97 cents per gallon, up 8.5 cents from Thursday's record close. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, finished up $1.27 at $28.63 per barrel. For the week, September crude rose $2.40 per barrel, while unleaded gasoline was up 16.5 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuation Under Way in Tomah, Wis., After 8-Inch Rainfall Imperils Dam
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 1,000 homes were morning as rivers swollen by an 8-inch rainfall threatened to rupture the Lake Tomah dam, authorities said. Hundreds of residents were evacuated from around the Lemonweir River in Tomah after the Friday night rainstorm, said Carleen Pearson of the Monroe County Police. ``It's chaotic,'' said Donette Gorbet of the Tomah Police. ``We're telling everybody to stay away from Tomah.'' About 300 people were transported to a Tomah junior high school gymnasium, said authorities in this west-central Wisconsin town of 7,000. Although flooding left the dam in a precarious condition, water pressure on the dam was beginning to recede by midmorning, authorities said. Tomah Police Lt. Chris Anderson said the situation should come under control later in the day. A 25- to 30-mile stretch of Highway 12-16 and parts of Interstate 90 between Oakdale and Sparta also were closed, Pearson said. The rain soaked the town over a three-hour period Friday night. Assistant Fire Chief Stu Westphall said the city was in ``a mess.'' No deaths or injuries have been reported. No damage estimate was available. The city's ambulance service, civil defense and police department were involved in the evacuation, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Deliberations Continue in Jogger Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jurors due to resume deliberations at 11 a.m.
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the Central Park rape trial denied a defense motion for a mistrial and jurors failed to reach a verdict at the end of the ninth day of deliberations. Justice Thomas Galligan of Manhattan state Supreme Court called jurors late Friday and told them to break for the day and resume deliberations today. Michael Joseph, attorney for defendant Antron McCray, said he asked for the mistrial because he didn't want the jurors to reach a verdict if they were tired or felt pressure to render a decision. Earlier, jurors saw for the third time during deliberations a videotape of McCray's statement to police, and had testimony read back to them from McCray's parents, who contend their son's statement was coerced. In the videotape, Antron McCray said he kicked the jogger and feigned having sex with her to impress his friends. McCray, 16, Salaam, 16 and Raymond Santana, 15, are accused of raping and trying to kill the jogger in the park the night of April 19, 1989. They also are charged with attacking two male joggers in the park that night. The other charges against the youths include sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery. The woman, now 30, eventually recovered and returned to her job as a Wall Street investment banker. She testified that she suffers from impaired balance, vision and smell as a result of the attack and cannot recall what happened that night.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Group Attacks Radical Rightists
DOC.TEXT: A group of masked youths attacked members of a right-wing political party as they passed out leaflets in East Berlin on Saturday, and seven people were reported injured. About 30 members of the far-right Republican Party were working at an information booth near an East Berlin subway station Saturday morning when a group of youths attacked them, the East German news agency ADN said. The attackers carried rocks and knives and punched and kicked the Republicans, the news agency said. The injured sustained cuts and bruises, and one party member suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized, ADN said. Police said they were searching for the attackers. The Republicans are a West German political party that advocates sharp restrictions on the rights of foreigners to live in the country. The party has been given permission to enter candidates in the Oct. 14 elections to create five state governments in East Germany. East Germany will be reduced to those five states when it joins with West Germany by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Groups Tried for Opposing Government
DOC.TEXT: A court in southern Vietnam has put members of two religious groups on trial on charges of anti-government activity, Vietnam's state radio reported. It said the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court tried members of the groups on ``the charge of taking advantage of their religion to spread propaganda against the revolutionary administration and the socialist regime.'' The radio identified the groups as the ``Small Soul Organization'' and the ``High-Tide Movement of Maria Catholic Priests.'' The radio gave no other details. A transcript of the broadcast Friday was seen Saturday in Bangkok. Communist authorities in Vietnam have had poor relations with Catholics and other religious groups, although the climate has improved since more pragmatic party officials came to power in late 1986. In recent months, however, authorities have been blaming religious and other groups for trying to destablize the government as it braces for the loss of crucial aid from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Discover Second Tumor in Lee Atwater's Brain, Reports Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 10 grafs new to UPDATE with Atwater undergoing additional radiation treatment, alert and receiving visitors; spokeswoman's response to reports of second tumor; corrects category code; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Atwater, who'
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater was alert after undergoing radiation therapy for brain tumor ``progression,'' a spokeswoman said today. The spokeswoman, Leslie Goodman, didn't respond directly when asked about reports that doctors had discovered a second tumor in the brain of the 39-year-old Atwater. She said physicians ``were not specific on that.'' Two South Carolina newspapers today quoted unidentified sources as saying doctors had discovered a new growth. ``Their statement was that there has been tumor progression and that's about as much as we know and about as far as they intend to go in their description,'' she said. ``His condition is unchanged,'' Goodman said. ``He's alert, seeing visitors and did undergo radiation treatment yesterday.'' An RNC statement issued late Thursday had said a biopsy performed on Atwater this week ``indicated tumor progression requiring additional treatment.'' The statement also said Atwater began receiving radiation treatment Wednesday. The State newspaper in Columbia, citing close friends of Atwater, and The News & Courier of Charleston, citing a source close to the situation, reported the discovery of a second tumor. Goodman said in response to those reports that doctors ``aren't sure whether it's a new tumor or part of the old tumor.'' Meanwhile, a circle of family _ including Atwater's mother _ and close friends on Friday rallied to support Atwater as news spread that his condition had worsened. A friend described Atwater, who managed President Bush's 1988 campaign, as ``very, very weak.'' Atwater, who underwent brain tumor surgery on April 3, has been in and out of the hospital repeatedly for treatment of ailments ranging from a blood clot in his leg to a nagging fever. Until this week, however, doctors thought the small tumor in the right side of his brain was virtually gone. On Thursday, RNC Chief of Staff Mary Matalin said physicians who have been treating Atwater ``all concur this development is concerning.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Has Soviet Bombers That Can Deliver Chemical Weapons
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has Soviet bombers capable of delivering chemical and conventional weapons with pinpoint precision anywhere in the Persian Gulf and eastern Mediterranean, Jane's Defense Weekly reported Saturday. The Sukhoi Su-24 Fencer low-level strike bombers present the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf ``with its gravest military threat,'' Jane's said in its Aug. 18 issue. U.S. military intelligence sources estimate that the Iraqi air force has about 10 of the aircraft, the magazine said. It said the Su-24 Fencer is similar to the US F-111 and has a combat range of about 650 miles, without the need to refuel. ``With a midair refueling capability, almost certainly possessed by the Iraqis, range would be limited only by the endurance of its two-man crew,'' said the magazine. Although primarily designed to attack land targets, Jane's said the aircraft could also be used against ships. It can carry the full range of Soviet tactical weapons, many of which are in Iraqi hands, it said. ``In capable hands it is a formidable weapon, although the Iraqi air force's ability to master its operation is under some doubt,'' the Jane's article said. U.S. intelligence sources believe Iraq has had Fencers since the beginning of the year but it is not known whether they are owned by Iraq or on loan from the Soviet Union, the magazine said. Iraq, which signed a friendship treaty with the Soviet Union in 1972, has long wanted the Su-24 but experts believe Moscow refused to supply them out of fears of destabilizing the Middle East, Jane's said. The magazine said it is likely that Moscow, under pressure from Iraq to supply intermediate-range missiles, instead agreed to supply the Fencers.

DOC.HEAD: A Pamphlet To Arm Voters Against Manipulation
DOC.TEXT: A new political reform group believes thousands of Americans are willing to spend $3 each to become better citizens. The Center for National Independence in Politics has set up a 900-number telephone line to take orders for the ``Voter's Self-Defense Manual,'' an eight-page pamphlet small enough to fit in a shirt pocket. Its purpose: to give voters a way to get around the manipulations of today's political campaigns, to see behind the commercials and gimmicks. In addition, the $3 call to 1-900-820-CNIP produces a list showing how six national groups _ conservative, liberal, business, labor, environmental and defense _ rate the caller's senators and representatives. Also provided is a breakdown of how much money the lawmakers have been given by political action committees representing agriculture, business, the health industry, labor and professional, ideological and political groups. ``The manual is directed to the person who is frustrated out there,'' CNIP President Richard Kimball said in an interview last week. ``We figure we're going to have five minutes of their attention.'' The pamphlet is CNIP's first project. The organization, based in Tucson, Ariz., and supported largely by foundations, is nonprofit and bipartisan. Former Sens. William Proxmire, D-Wis., and Barry Goldwater, R-Ariz., are among the founders; former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford are honorary co-founders. Kimball ran unsuccessfully in 1986 against Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. He says he feels embarrassed to confess that he spent much of his time raising money ``so I could put out a commercial showing myself feeding carrots to horses.'' Campaign advisers had told him voters would feel kindly toward a candidate seen as a horse-lover and projecting an ``Arizona image.'' ``That is dangerous stuff in a democracy,'' Kimball now says. So he set out to find a way to educate voters on ways to combat modern campaign technologies. CNIP resulted. The manual advises on methods to cut through campaign posturing, get information, analyze commercials, sift emotional appeals, measure ``the ratio of meat to mush.'' ``You must remember that elected officials are nothing more than temporary hired help,'' it says. ``View their campaigns as job applications. Ask if the candidates are giving you, the employer, the information you need in order to hire wisely.'' Callers get one copy. Another is sent to a library in their state. Kimball's concern is deadly serious. ``Throughout the world,'' he writes in the pamphlet, ``people struggle in the streets for a small measure of democracy, while here, in the nation of its birth, it has begun to die.''

DOC.HEAD: `It's Scary Out Here' First Night in Desert
DOC.TEXT: The sergeant is halfway done with digging his first foxhole on his first night in the Arabian desert when word comes to pull back. He swings his shovel in protest until the reason, transmitted by whisper, makes its way down the line: the platoon is out of position. ``We're too far out in front of the rest of the company,'' the sergeant says. ``They could be firing and killing us.'' The shovels are put away, rucksacks are quickly packed and the platoon within minutes makes a short retreat, guided to a new site by a dim fluorescent signal flashed by a sister platoon several hundred yards away. Platoon 22 _ the second platoon of the 82nd Airborne Division's 2nd Brigade _ digs in again. A few minutes later, the company commander explains to a reporter that the platoon had taken position far enough out front to be hit by friendly mortar and machine gun fire. The captain isn't happy, but shrugs it off. ``He's our newest platoon leader,'' he said. ``It's good to get him out here to practice.'' Friday night's exercises gave the troops a chance to practice on the first night the Saudi government allowed American troops to train long after sundown. More such drills, including some joint exercises with Saudi troops, are planned. The first night of desert training, witnessed by two reporters and a photographer, demonstrated the formidable challenges American forces would face in a desert war in the Middle East. And it provided journalists the first chance to spend extended time with some of the young men who would fight that war. They are a diverse group from throughout America _ some eager to fight, some terrified by the prospect. But all share a similar hope that the crisis will soon be resolved, either through combat or diplomacy. ``We're here sweating because our lives may depend on it,'' said one private who carried a 50-pound pack through 95-degree evening heat. ``But it's really not up to us. Our lives are in the politicians' hands.'' The sun was just beginning its descent when the three platoons began the exercise, walking in a V-shaped formation roughly three miles into the seemingly endless Arabian desert. As the sun dropped off the horizon, a herd of camels traipsed past the curious Americans. The need to carry more water makes the soldiers' packs extra heavy. During a break, a 20-year-old medic from Newburgh, N.Y., lightens his pack a bit by taking a few gulps. The infantrymen he is there to help drop into a circular perimeter, their weapons aimed across the darkening terrain. ``Finding the courage is tough _ it's scary out here,'' the medic says. ``But you've got to swallow that and go out and do it.'' Inside his bag are needles with antidotes to certain chemical weapons; the medic prays they will not be needed. ``We just want to go back to the states and be with our kids,'' he says. None of a dozen soldiers interviewed under the sparkling desert sky has any idea when the trip home will be. Some ask aloud whether they will make it. Most hope diplomacy convinces Iraq to leave Kuwait; a few would rather take on Saddam Hussein's forces now. ``If it would get us home faster, then let's go kick him out of Kuwait,'' one private says. ``What we have now is hurry up and wait. It's frustrating.'' It is so dark that one can move around virtually unnoticed; so quiet that whispers can be heard. Much of the talk is idle chatter. ``The sky is just like the sky back home,'' one soldier says to his companion in a two-man foxhole. The response: ``But it just isn't the same unless I'm sitting out on my back porch.'' A few yards away, another soldier tells a passerby: ``My wife is having our baby in five weeks. I wish I could just say hello.'' A radioman with the medic begins a sentence saying, ``If Saddam doesn't pull out of Kuwait ....'' The medic completes the thought, ``... he'll be squished like a grape.'' The men are barely in their foxholes when they are instructed to head back to their transport trucks, a nearly three-mile walk in the pitch black night. Those in the back of the line can see the shadows of just the few men ahead. In training, one sergeant says, soldiers have been known to stop, thinking a tree several feet ahead in the darkness is the man they are supposed to follow. ``That cuts you off from the front,'' he says. ``And if you get cut off, you die.'' The Saudi desert has no trees, but the going is treacherous in the dark because of short, sharp shrubs underfoot and small dunes that turn a walk to a stumble. During the trek, most of the soldiers say they understand that they must be here and are ready to fight to defend the Saudi kingdom. These are the troops _ airborne paratroopers _ who arrived first, when there was little firepower to back them up. ``When they called us out, we thought we were going to drop right into a war,'' the medic says. Helicopters on night flights pass in the distance, a reminder that much more U.S. firepower is in the region now. As they wait, the 82nd Airborne forces train about 12 hours a day. They have some complaints _ the lack of mail is the biggest _ but say morale is high. They complain largely because there is little else to do. ``It's Army tradition,'' one sergeant says with a laugh. ``But we're fine.'' A reporter keeps asking what it would be like to fight in the desert. The soldiers keep asking what it's like back home. ``Please tell them we'll be back,'' a lieutenant says. ``We just don't know when.''
DOC.NOTE: EDS: This is based on a pool dispatch.

DOC.HEAD: Minister: U.N. Considering Military Action To Enforce Sanctions Against Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister said Saturday the United Nations is considering joining in military action to enforce its sanctions against Iraq. Prince Saud al-Faisal also ruled out a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis unless Iraq withdraws its troops from Kuwait and reinstates the emir, who was deposed in the Aug. 2 invasion. ``We are hoping _ ardently hoping _ that military action will be avoided,'' Saud said in an interview with Western and Saudi journalists. But he added: ``Unless the two principals are accepted by Iraq, I don't see any prospects for a diplomatic solution.'' ``That is the only way it can be resolved. There is absolutely no other way,'' he added. The reporters were invited by the Saudi government to travel to this Red Sea city about 1,000 miles from where thousands of U.S. troops and other members of a multinational force are deploying on the Persian Gulf. Saud said his country supports actions by the United Nations to strengthen its economic boycott of Iraq. The United Nations has endorsed a total boycott of Iraq, and the United States and Britain have moved to enforce those sanctions using naval forces to stop ships believed to be carrying goods to or from Iraq. Saud indicated the action could soon involve a multinational force under the auspices of the U.N. ``The United Nations now is in consultation to see if some action, more than the boycott, is required and we support that action and we hope it will be a further signal to Iraq to respond to the international community's conviction that they have to withdraw from Kuwait,'' he said. Asked what kind of action, Saud said: ``They are considering military action.'' '' A Saudi official explained that Saud was referring to possible military enforcement of a blockade. Saud, who just returned from Washington and was expected to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney this weekend, refused to discuss any specific Saudi conditions under which the United States has agreed to send more than 50,000 troops to the desert kingdom. He said foreign troops arrived at Saudi Arabia's request and added that the oil-rich kingdom is willing to help pay for the cost of the deployment. ``Saudi Arabia will, as it does, contribute its share for the defense of Saudi Arabia,'' he said. Saud added that the U.S. forces, along with contingents from Egypt, Britain and other countries arrived ``at the request of Saudi Arabia and they will leave at the request of Saudi Arabia.'' The number of troops in Saudi Arabia ``by no means comes close to the number of troops in Iraq,'' he added. Saud said Iraq has between 120,000 and 160,000 men in Kuwait and has mobilized one million people. Saud would not say how long he expected American troops to remain in Saudi Arabia, but said it is up to Iraq to move to end the crisis. ``The ball is in their court,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Even Without Real Ammo, Desert Life is Challenging
With AM-Gulf-US Troops, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Elliott Minor, the AP's Albany, Ga., correspondent, recently spent a week in the California desert as part of his annual National Guard obligation. Here is his report.

With the temperature approaching 120 and a harsh sun beating down, some weary Georgia guardsmen shuffled to the rear of an Army truck in the Mojave Desert for a ration of lasagna and beans. Nearby, a dozen M-1 tanks tossed up clouds of choking dust as they raced across the desert floor. In the shade of a tan Bradley Fighting Vehicle, medics pumped an IV solution into a grimacing guardsman and began treating him for a scorpion sting. Nearly 1,400 members of the Georgia Army National Guard's 48th Infantry Brigade (Mechanized) spent three weeks in the California desert last month, defending the imaginary country of Mojavia against invaders with black berets. The 48th serves as a backup for the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) at Fort Stewart, Ga., which is deploying troops and equipment to the Saudi Arabian desert to defend the oil kingdom against a possible Iraqi attack. I spent a week in the desert interviewing and photographing the part-time soldiers as a staff sergeant in the guard's 124th Public Affairs Detachment. At the same time, my 23-year-old son, Emory, was halfway around the world, training in a Middle East desert with combat engineers. That mission was halted after Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait. Despite a regimen of pushups, situps and six-mile runs, I found it difficult to walk very far in the desert heat with a 70-pound rucksack, a Kevlar helmet, a gas mask, two canteens, a first-aid pouch and two ammo pouches stuffed with plastic bags containing powdered milk and Slim-Fast, a concession to my own battle of the bulge. The importance of water, shade and portable toilets quickly became apparent. We drank water constantly to avoid dehydration. Many guardsmen carried insulated water bottles and larger containers were placed in key locations and lashed to nearly all vehicles. I drank about a quart of water every hour and never passed up an opportunity to top off my canteens. The desert heat was oppressive, but a constant breeze was blowing, and we were fairly comfortable in the shade. We were surrounded from horizon to horizon by sand and rocky peaks. Small creosote bushes dotted the landscape. I saw a coyote ambling across the desert one morning, but no other wildlife. I shook my boots each morning for scorpions. Pfc. Dawn Doyle, an operating room technician with a Macon medical unit, had some definite plans for her return. ``I'll spend three hours in the shower and then sleep for about 24 hours,'' she said. ``Then I'll think about going out for a pizza.'' The medics stayed busy treating the guard members for heat exhaustion, cuts and kidney stones. Georgians are susceptible to kidney stones because of high calcium levels in their water.
