Doctors said dehydration and possibly the rough ride across the desert triggered dozens of painful kidney stone attacks. A common greeting in the Mojave was, ``Hey, I passed my stone.'' The Army placed portable toilets in the Mojave for the convenience of soldiers and to protect the desert environment. The portable johns had the word ``Leroy'' stenciled on the door. When one got crushed by a tank, someone put up a sign that said, ``Who killed Leroy?'' The guard members were issued sunscreen and goggles to protect their eyes from the sand and sun. They had to keep their sleeves rolled down to avoid sunburn. Unaware of the sleeve policy, I kept mine rolled up for half a day and wound up with arms as red as boiled lobsters. I also lost my goggles and my eyes became irritated while riding in a truck with no windshield. I eventually had to go to an aid station to have them flushed out and treated. During lulls, the medics, nurses and doctors catnapped in the shade of truck. When patients arrived, they examined them on canvas litters set up beneath a camouflage net. Everyone wore sensors that sound an alarm when hit by a laser beam. The sensors also were attached to vehicles. The soldiers' M-16 rifles and cannons fired blanks for a realistic sound, but also shot safe laser beams that triggered the sensors. ``Dead'' and ``wounded'' soldiers had to sit in a ``bone yard'' for up to 12 hours and their units had to send replacements and fill out war casualty forms. During the 48th's desert sojourn, its members traveled through such places as Port-A-Potty Pass, John Wayne Pass, the Valley of Death, Coyote Canyon and Dead Man's Pass. During the exercise, we dined on T-rations, which are packed in large metal containers that are heated before serving, or ``MRE's'' _ Meals, Ready to Eat _ which come in brown plastic pouches and contain not only food and a plastic spoon but accessories such as instant coffee, salt, sugar, chewing gum and toilet paper. One day, I hitched a ride with members of the 848th Engineer company from Douglas, a small farming town in south Georgia. They were camped at the foot of a small mountain. The engineers let me use a cot and we all went to sleep beneath a clear sky studded with millions of stars. The next day, they packed their gear into tan trailers and trucks and disappeared in a cloud of dust. As he bumped along in the heat, Staff Sgt. Roy Butler was overcome by the Mojave's beauty and vastness and began to sing an old Baptist hymn. ``We need a savior. In times like this, we need an anchor,'' he intoned.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Koreans Baptized in Mass Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Korean Christians wearing white robes were baptized Saturday in a ceremony officiated by hundreds of Korean and foreign pastors as part of the 16th Baptist World Congress. The ceremony, at the Olympic Regatta Arena in eastern Seoul, drew about 5,000 Koreans and 1,000 foreign spectators. Thousands of Christians lined the arena's embankment and were led into the water by about 500 Korean and foreign pastors for the baptism. The ceremony culminated a six-day congress that was attended by about 10,000 Baptist church leaders, including 156 delegates from the Soviet Union. On Monday, 2,000 Koreans were baptized. The congress was sponsored by the Baptist World Alliance, which claims 36 million followers in 145 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Soldiers Get Windfall in West German Marks
DOC.TEXT: The 370,000 Red Army soldiers in East Germany have few military duties these days, so they spend a lot of time deciding what to buy with the windfall West Germany just handed them. Like East Germans, the Soviet troopers were allowed to trade savings in East German marks for West German money when the currencies merged July 1. Since then, they have been paid in West German marks. Several recruits walking along a road outside Potsdam on a hot summer day spoke with a Western reporter about their new wealth, and their plans for it. Dmitri wants a tape deck, Valery prefers a video recorder and Alexei has his mind set on a car. Vladimir said he bought his niece ``really good'' gifts. ``Things are better for us now because we have West German marks and there are many things to buy,'' said Dmitri, a 20-year-old sergeant from the Ukraine. East Germany pays the cost of keeping Soviet troops in this former cornerstone of the Warsaw Pact. The only difference now is that the money is paid in West German marks instead of the now-defunct East mark. A Red Army private gets only the equivalent of $15 a month. A sergeant earns twice that and officers' pay starts at about $625, a fortune in Soviet terms. At the black market rate in the Soviet Union, even a private's pay is worth about 154 rubles, more than half the average Soviet monthly wage of 250 rubles. In Potsdam, however, it doesn't buy many $2.50 plates of herring washed down with 60-cent colas, and the first flush of spending has passed. ``They are buying a lot less now,'' said Clark Brutler, who sells socks in the outdoor market. ``They just don't have as much money anymore.'' Many have their eyes on luxury electronic goods or cars, but even used cars are far beyond the means of low-ranking soldiers. Some have sold weapons to raise cash for high-priced items. So far this year, West Berlin police have confiscated 90 rifles, pistols and revolvers; 135 pounds of explosives; 165 grenades, and four grenade launchers. They said most were of Soviet origin. Among the places weapons were seized was a park in East Germany just outside West Berlin, where police said Soviet soldiers were selling arms to West Berliners. Soviet military hats, coats and badges are peddled to tourists at the Brandenburg Gate and the former U.S. Checkpoint Charlie along the Berlin Wall. The Soviet military dismisses reports that ordinary soldiers can barely survive on their pay. ``Soldiers get everything _ medicine, free cigarettes _ taken care of by the Soviet state,'' said Major Karen Streltschemnya, a political officer at the Soviet mission in East Berlin. ``Deutsche marks are for snacks, not to live on.'' Soviet officers can afford to eat well in their villas on their wooded base, surrounded by a high white wall. Their wives return from shopping trips with heaping baskets of West German hams, cheeses and other delicacies. Most of the thousands of Soviet soldiers assigned to Potsdam live in barracks that wind along a two-lane road leading west from the city. Their lives are relatively spartan, but probably better than they can expect as civilians back home, where unemployment is growing and housing is scarce. Several Red Army soldiers have deserted their units and gone to West Germany, whose liberal asylum laws may apply to them. Red Star, the Soviet military newspaper, declared recently that fleeing to West Germany was ``desertion with all its resulting consequences.'' Asylum ``is an issue each one of us thinks about, but it is up to each soldier to make his own decision,'' said Oleg, a Ukrainian private. Potsdam has not experienced the kind of antagonism toward Soviet troops seen elsewhere in East Germany since that country's Stalinist government collapsed in November. In many communities, signs like ``Russen Raus'' (Russians Out) are common. Renate Kern, who has lived next to Soviet military personnel for 22 years, said: ``They are the best neighbors. We've never had any trouble. They stay for a few years and then go home.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Appoints Envoy to Romania
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Saturday appointed the Vatican's first envoy to Romania in 40 years. The Rev. John Bukovsky was named apostolic nuncio in Bucharest, a move made possible after diplomatic relations were re-established between the Holy See and Romania three months ago. The pope elevated Bukovsky, 66, to the rank of archbishop. Bukovsky was born in Czechoslovakia and traveled to the United States in 1947 to study theology at the Divine Word Seminary in Techny, Ill. He was ordained a priest in 1950 and spent two years studying at Catholic University in Washington, D.C. Bukovsky also spent several years in the 1950s and 1960s teaching at the seminary in Techny. He has held Vatican posts since 1973 and in recent years he has worked at the Vatican's Secretariat of State. Romania's former hard-line Communist regime broke relations with the Vatican in 1950. The Communists were overthrown in December. Earlier this year, the pope appointed 12 bishops to restore the church to its previous strength.

DOC.HEAD: Westerners' Fate Uncertain; Arabs Flee by Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with today's statement on foreigners, Britain summoning Iraqi ambassador. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `In Paris...'
DOC.TEXT: Tension mounted today over the fate of Westerners trapped in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, and a record number of Arabs fled into Jordan. Today, Iraq warned that foreign nationals would be among the first to feel the pinch as the international embargo created shortages of critical supplies. Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. In a televised statement, Iraq called military enforcement of the international embargo against it an ``act of war'' and demanded an end to it. European and American diplomats expressed anxiety in the wake of Friday's announcement from Iraq that foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' would be kept in Iraq as long as the threat of war persisted. By midday today, an official at the Jordanian border post of Ruweishid said 4,000 foreigners had crossed from Iraq, and thousands more were lined up. A day earlier, a record 22,300 foreigners had crossed, he said. Nearly all were Arabs, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Friday's Iraqi threat against the foreign nationals was delivered by Iraq's parliamentary speaker, Sadi Mahdi Saleh. He said the foreigners not allowed to leave Iraq would be housed in civilian and military institutions around Iraq. ``The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' he added. The statement, carried by the official Iraqi news agency, was monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. Britain today called threats against foreigners by the Iraqis ``unlawful and inhuman.'' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the Iraqi ambassador had been summoned to the Foreign Office ``to underline our grave concern and to relay to his authorities the need for immediate clarification.'' In Paris, France summoned the Iraqi ambassador to warn that ``serious consequences'' would result if steps are not taken to protect the 560 French nationals in Iraq and Kuwait. A Foreign Ministry source said it was not whether French nationals would fall under the Iraqi directive concerning citizens of ``aggressive'' nations. No orders have been given for French people in Kuwait to assemble at hotels, as were given on Thursday for American and British nationals, the source said. The French Foreign Ministry said that about 290 French citizens are being held in Iraq and another 270 in Kuwait. Today was the third time in two weeks the Iraqi ambassador to Paris has been summoned to the Foreign Ministry to discuss their fate. Italian newspapers reported today that more than 300 Italians trapped in Iraq say they are being held against their will and have appealed for help from the Italian government. In a telex sent via the Italian Embassy in Baghdad, the Italians described their situation as ``grave'' and asked the government to help get them out. ``We are blocked in Iraq against our will, help us return to Italy,'' newspapers quoted the telex as saying. Italy's Foreign Ministry said it was doing all it could to work for the release of Italian citizens and was turning to the United Nations and the Red Cross for help. On Friday, the United Nations Security Council expressed concern about the fate of the trapped foreigners and asked Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to take steps to help them. The White House was silent about Iraq's threat on Friday, and President Bush refused to answer reporters' questions this morning. But the State Department has consistently expressed concern about the Americans. Fear mounted again Friday after 35 U.S. citizens were removed from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad and taken to an undisclosed location, most likely another hotel. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We consider it a matter of serious concern.'' Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, said on Friday that approximately 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait would not be harmed. Meanwhile, the exodus by Arab nationals from Iraq swelled to its highest levels yet. The Jordanian border official at Ruweishid said Friday's crossing of 22,300 was the biggest in a single day since the exodus began, prompted by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The border official said those who crossed today were Arab nationals, mainly Egyptian, except for two Indians with British passports. A group of 225 Soviet citizens from Kuwait were among the thousands who crossed into Jordan late Friday. The group was driven from the border to Amman's airport and boarded a plane for Moscow early today. The crush at Ruweishid is so great that there are not enough buses to transport the evacuees across Jordan on the way to their countries. Associated Press photographer Martin Cleaver, in Ruweishid, said hundreds of trucks had been commandeered to help in the evacuation. The continuing influx of Egyptians into Jordan indicated that they were not considered by the Iraqis as being citizens of an ``aggressive'' nation, even though Egypt has sent troops to help defend Saudi Arabia against any Iraqi attack. The official at Ruweishid said out of 4,000 Arabs who crossed today, 3,300 were Egyptians. He said another 7,000 Egyptians had crossed the previous day. The Egyptians are moving south to port of Aqaba after crossing the border. Thousands are reported to be waiting there for ferries to carry them home across the Red Sea. Many other foreigners, Arabs and a handful of Westerners, were escaping via the Saudi border. On Friday, thirteen carloads of American and other refugees made a dramatic escape from Kuwait through the desert, a Californian member of the convoy said. ``It was a hectic, rather perilous drive past Iraqi checkpoints and through uninhabited desert regions between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,'' Stephanie McGehee, 37, said after the group made it over the border Friday. The total number of people in the 13-car convoy was not immediately clear, although the nine people in Ms. McGehee's car included two other Americans, a Canadian, a Briton and four Indians, she said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Says Embargo of Food, Medicine Hurting Foreign Captives Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. Deletes reference to U.N. Security Council meeting today, as session now in doubt. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TEH1,CIA2
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad today condemned the U.S. economic blockade on Iraq as an act of war and said that the thousands of foreigners it holds will suffer along with Iraqis as shortages of food and medicine develop. Iraq, which imports three-fourths of its food, said Iraqi and foreign babies and elderly people will be the first to feel the effect as the nation makes sure that its food goes to its hundreds of thousands of soldiers first. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. There was no indication in today's statement that the foreigners would be allowed to leave Iraq or Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Instead, it focused on how the foreigners would face deprivation if the embargo is maintained. Iraq has raised the stakes in the Persian Gulf crisis by saying it will hold captive Americans as a shield, and by diverting troops pulled back from the Iranian frontier to focus on its confrontation with U.S. and Arab forces. Iraq's army newspaper today reiterated earlier threats to use weapons of ``mass destruction'' against any attacker. Iraq's arsenal is known to include chemical weapons and long-range missiles. The United States today planned to step up its mobilization against the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait by calling up military reservists and ordering U.S. civilian airlines to help fly troops and cargo to Saudi Arabia. Today's statement on Iraqi television was made by Iraq's Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs. It suggested that some of the European nationals were already feeling the effects of the near-total cutoff of supplies. ``Because of the embargo, food cannot be secured for aged persons in the manner that we wish,'' the statement said. ``This experience has already affected the British people particularly.'' There are children among the foreigners, and Iraq suggested they would be treated the same as Iraqi children in shortages. ``If there were to be any reduction in the necessities of babies, then the same calamity affecting the Iraqi newborn will affect similarly the foreign babies,'' said an Iraqi statement. It said the United States and its allies have surpassed the U.N.-mandated sanctions against Iraq by enforcing a ``military embargo, including food and medicine, and that is considered an act of war.'' The statement was read by an unidentified announcer and translated by Cable News Network and The Associated Press. In Egypt, Suez Canal personnel picked up radio signals indicating that an American warship in the Mediterranean Sea was checking the itineraries of commercial vessels approaching or leaving Egypt's Port Said, at the canal's northern entrance, a canal official said on condition of anonymity. The report came a day after U.S. Navy commanders operating under new orders to intercept ships to or from Iraq stopped two Iraqi vessels off the coast of Bahrain. The ships were allowed to proceed after U.S. forces determined they carried no goods and they were not boarded, the Pentagon said. Washington also joined with the four other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council in an unprecedented meeting to discuss an expanded U.N. military role to stop any further advance by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who sent forces into Kuwait 16 days ago in a dispute over oil, land and money. The U.S. move to interdict ships has drawn criticism, the latest coming from Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. The official Libyan news agency JANA said Gadhafi wrote to the U.N. secretary-general to protest the move as illegal. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said today he saw no prospects for a diplomatic solution unless Iraq withdraws its troops from Kuwait and reinstates the emir who was deposed in the invasion. ``That is the only way it can be resolved. There is absolutely no other way,'' Prince Saud said in an interview with Western and Saudi journalists. On Friday, the speaker of Iraq's Parliament said Iraq would hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against his country ends. He said they would be spread throughout the country, housed in military and civilian targets. The White House refused comment Friday on Baghdad's announcement, and President Bush refused to answer reporters' questions this morning. Before Friday's announcement from Iraq, Bush said Iraqi attempts to move American civilians around Iraq and Kuwait violated international law. In an editorial the Iraqi army daily, al-Qaddasiyah, said ``all weapons at Baghdad's disposal,'' including those of ``mass destruction,'' would be ``awaiting anyone who is thinking of aggression and turn him into fragments.''Iraq used chemical weapons during its war with Iran. Iran said today it freed 1,000 Iraqi prisoners of war, reciprocating for an Iraqi move a day earlier. The Baghdad government this week made peace overtures to Iran with an eye toward switching troops from the Iranian border to occupied Kuwait and the Saudi border. It began withdrawing some of the 300,000 Iraqi soldiers there Friday. The Al-Qaddasiyah editorial also said today the 30 divisions facing Iran _ an estimated 300,000 troops _ would now be used to bolster Iraqi formations in the south. It was the first word from an official publication that Baghdad would redeploy forces freed from the Iranian border. Iran and Iraq fought a bloody war from 1980 to 1988. But peace talks have foundered since then, and this week's initiative by Iraq is aimed at reaching a permanent settlement.

DOC.FIRST: r w AM-WalterMear 50 percent of U.S. consumption. It's too late, of course, as Bentsen noted.
DOC.SECOND: Imports were running at about 50 percent before the latest
DOC.TEXT: Persian Gulf crisis erupted with Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. As in 1973 and in 1979, the United States faces rising oil prices. And though there's no immediate prospect of those kinds of shortages, they could come eventually. The earlier oil shocks were major factors in triggering recessions. The economy already is slowing, and the current turmoil in the Persian Gulf can only make it worse. Despite what happened before, and despite the virtual certainty that something similar would happen again, U.S. efforts at energy discipline were shelved for most of a decade. Ronald Reagan's energy policy was to leave it alone, and let the market rule. That sufficed while Middle East oil was plentiful and relatively cheap. Now the problem is back. ``We have spent the last decade basking in the glow of falling real energy prices,'' Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., said before the Senate passed its energy policy bill early this month. ``We have been lulled into a complacency that cannot last.'' During the Reagan administration, the Department of Energy's conservation budget was slashed by two-thirds. When imported oil prices fell in 1986, U.S. production fell, too. At those prices, many domestic producers couldn't compete, and there was no incentive to keep going. U.S. oil production is down by about 20 percent since 1985. At 7.1 million barrels a day, June production was the lowest on record. Remnants of the emergency programs that grew out of the crises of the 1970s have put the United States in better shape to deal with the impact of the Persian Gulf situation. One of those legacies is the emergency petroleum reserve, a big enough stockpile to temporarily cushion against shortages. It could be a lot bigger if the government hadn't stopped buying during five of the Reagan years, a budget-cutting move that could prove expensive. The 1987 tanker war in the Persian Gulf threatened oil supplies, and U.S. warships were sent to protect the supply lines. That costly operation isn't calculated into the price of oil, nor is this one. They go onto the tax bill, not the price at the pump. Sen. Frank H. Murkowski, R-Alaska, calculated that counting the cost of earlier military operations, the true price of imported oil comes to $52 a barrel. That hypothetical price tag doesn't include the cost of the massive U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. Figured that way, the price is soaring with the U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf. ``This is not a freebie out there in terms of the expenditure,'' President Bush said Tuesday, saying he could not estimate the cost or the duration of the operation. But people don't count those costs the way they count the cost of a gallon of gasoline. Oil imports are a major factor in the U.S. trade deficit. James Schlesinger, a former secretary of energy and of defense, says the price will hit $75 billion next year, swelling to over $100 billion a year by the mid-1990s if past trends continue. Through it all, U.S. energy policy has shifted and drifted. Richard M. Nixon's Project Independence made little headway toward the goal in its name. Jimmy Carter said the quest to curb energy dependence was the moral equivalent of war. His program of conservation and production incentives, fees, taxes and penalties didn't last long. The Reagan administration relied on the marketplace. The Bush administration still is at work on its energy strategy, due later this year. And as Carter notes, the Arab oil suppliers know only too well that ``we now have no effective national energy policy, nor any commitment to adopt one.'' Legislation to declare that oil imports of 50 percent represent a ``peril point'' for U.S. security, and to require emergency action to keep them lower is part of a new National Energy Security Act passed by the Senate just before its August recess, two days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The timing was coincidental; the bill was drafted primarily to deal with global warming, not oil wars. A measure seeking to restrain oil imports was defeated by the Senate in 1987 after the last Persian Gulf crisis had subsided. Conservation, production incentives, and new technologies to develop alternative energy sources all have been components in the successive strategies that were shaped and shelved after the earlier oil shocks. The Department of Energy put together a quick-hit package of steps to boost production and promote conservation, to offset the loss of imports from Kuwait and Iraq. But between oil crises, the tendency has been to act as though there wouldn't be another one.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Shakes Northeastern Iran
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 5.4 on the Richter scale shook northeastern Iran Saturday, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. There were no immediate reports of casualties or destruction, said the report, monitored in Cyprus. The quake was felt in two northeastern cities, Gorgan and Bojnourd, which are about 120 miles apart. Gorgan lies 240 miles northeast of the capital, Tehran, near the Caspian Sea. Bojnourd is 211 miles northwest of the provincial center of Mashhad in Khorasan province. Scores of sharp aftershocks have rolled through Iran since the June 21 earthquake that destroyed a large swath of northwestern Iran, killing almost 40,000 people and wounded tens of thousands. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake, measured by a seismograph as ground motion. An earthquake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage, while one of 6 can cause severe damage. The June quake in Iran registered above 7.3.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Won't Answer Serious Questions While `Recreating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Take any more comments' in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A testy President Bush, brushing off reporters' questions, said Saturday that he no longer will discuss ``serious matters'' like the Persian Gulf crisis while playing golf. The president displayed clear misgivings about the image he was projecting by juggling his annual end-of-August vacation with a massive U.S. military build-up against Iraq in the Middle East. Bush cut off reporters' inquiries on the first tee as he set out on an early morning round of golf. Asked if he had been in touch with the White House situation room, the president snapped, ``I talk to them every morning at 5:30 and I'm not going to take any more comments up here, though.'' ``Let's go,'' said Bush to his golf partners, including son George W. Bush, who chided reporters for talking during his back swing. Bush's ire may have been sparked by footage shown on television networks of some lighthearted remarks the president made on the golf course Friday. Asked then if he had signed rules of engagement for U.S. naval forces in the gulf, Bush quipped, ``I haven't done anything yet. I just got up.'' He then sped off in his golf cart. When he finished Saturday's speedy round on the Cape Arundel Golf Course, a reporter asked the president if he was still ``mad'' at the media. ``I've never been mad at you. I just don't like taking questions on serious matters on my vacation,'' he said. ``It's just not a good thing to keep doing it like this. But I'll try to be available,'' said Bush, who has held two formal news conferences and two informal ones since he came to Maine Aug. 10 on a 25-day vacation. One of those news conferences was at the White House when the president returned to Washington for a Pentagon briefing on the gulf crisis. He is also returning to Washington Sunday night for a meeting Monday with Energy Secretary James Watkins to discuss the impact on U.S. energy reserves and to address the Veterans of Foreign War convention in Baltimore. ``I think we've been readily available to the press, probably more so than most, and I'll try to continue that,'' said Bush. ``But it just doesn't seem appropriate and so I hope you'll understand if I, when I'm recreating, will recreate, and then when we're working, which I'm trying to do up here also, I'll work hard,'' the president said. Bush regularly has answered reporters' questions from the first tees during his golf outings. A media pool of about 15 reporters, photographers and broadcast crews travels in his motorcade and is escorted out to watch his performance at the first tee, the ninth green and 10th tee, and the 18th hole. When reporters persisted in asking questions Saturday, Bush's eldest son rose to his father's defense. ``Hey, hey! Sir! Could you wait until we finish hitting at least? My game is really bad. But when you're talking in the back swing, it gets even worse,'' said Bush, a part-owner of the Texas Rangers.

DOC.HEAD: Up To 38 Commercial Planes May Be Used To Carry Troops, Cargo To Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An unprecedented Pentagon move to press civilian aircraft into service for the military buildup in the Middle East should not disrupt commercial air traffic, a federal transportation official said. However, some airlines' representatives expressed uncertainty on the effects of the decision, announced Friday. Although there have been charters, this is the first time part of the U.S. civil air fleet has been diverted under a plan conceived in the 1950s. The planes are owned by 16 airlines, which also will be providing the crews to operate them. The airlift support is expected to be needed for several weeks, the Pentagon said. Air Force Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, commander of the U.S. Transportation Command and Military Airlift Command, announced Friday that he would activate the first stage of the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet to meet the ``growing airlift requirements'' for U.S. forces. His decision enables the call-up of as many as 38 aircraft to carry soldiers and cargo to the Persian Gulf region. Stages two and three, if activated, could deploy as many as 300 commercial planes for military use. The aircraft would come from passenger and cargo airlines. Stage one is not expected to disrupt civilian air traffic, said Elaine L. Chao, U.S. Deputy Secretary of Transportation. Chao and Johnson were in St. Louis to attend a transportation meeting. Johnson said activation of the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet was necessary because an insufficient number of commercial airplanes had been volunteered for the Middle East effort. The armed forces have been using as many as 24 civilian planes daily _ 10 volunteers and 14 that were previously under government contract, Johnson said. Bob Gibbons, director of media relations for Eagan, Minn.-based Northwest Airlines, said Saturday: ``We've been asked to provide airplanes, and we will.'' He acknowledged that the decision ``takes our airplanes out of circulation,'' but added, ``We'll do our best to provide our scheduled service.'' Pam Blase, a spokeswoman for Trans World Airlines, said she did not know how TWA might be affected by the new call. ``I can only comment that it is a military matter, and it's not appropriate for us to comment at this time,'' she said Friday. United Airlines is one of the largest participants in the U.S. fleet program, with 62 planes committed, company spokesman Rob Doughty said. He could not confirm whether United had been called on to provide any planes for the stage one call-up, but added: ``We do not anticipate disruptions to our schedule.'' T. Allan McArtor, a senior vice president for Federal Express Corp., said his company had the largest fleet participating in the Civil Reserve Air Fleet, but he would give no specific numbers. Federal Express planes flew passenger and cargo missions this week for the Middle East operation, dubbed Operation Desert Shield. ``It was a limited number. It did not disrupt normal service at all,'' said McArtor, who served as administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration from 1987 to 1989. The company uses only pilots and crew members who wish to go. ``Naturally, there's an element of risk,'' he said. ``We don't feel it poses risk that can't be managed well.'' McArtor said the armed forces and the private transportation sector had ``a successful partnership, but there's a need for continued improvement.'' ``The military can't expect companies so highly integrated and complex to respond on short notice indefinitely. Naturally, we respond to a national emergency, but we need to plan together,'' he said. Transportation Command coordinates all transportation of soldiers and equipment for military operations. A branch of the Transportation Command, the Military Airlift Command, handles passenger and cargo airlift. Scott Air Force Base near Belleville is the headquarters for both commands. The transportation meeting _ which focused on cooperation between the military and private industry _ was scheduled months ago. With the Middle East trouble, ``the timing and the topic could not be more relevant,'' Chao said. ``Our global responsibilities are too great and too diversified to depend on the military alone,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Demands End to Embargo, Says Foreign Nationals Will Suffer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6-9 pvs, `It suggested... The Associated Press' with 4 grafs to CORRECT reference to Britons feeling effects of food shortages, which in reference to their earlier wartime experience. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Iraq demanded...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today the economic embargo against it is ``an act of war'' and that foreign nationals it holds will suffer along with Iraqis if shortages of food and medicine develop. Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Saddam sent forces into the small oil state on Aug. 2. There was no indication in today's statement, carried on Iraqi television, that the foreigners would be allowed to leave Iraq or Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Instead, it focused on how the foreigners would face deprivation if the embargo is maintained. Food supplies in Iraq will be distributed to the military on a priority basis because they are ``the shield of the nation,'' the statement said. The Iraqis suggested that foreigners whose countries had experienced wars would understand the Iraqi decision to reserve needed supplies for its military. ``The peoples of Europe, in particular the British, have gone through such an experience, or something resembling it, before,'' the statement said. Children and the elderly among the foreign nationals would feel the effects of shortages along with their Iraqi counterparts, it said. ``Because of the embargo, food cannot be secured for aged persons in the manner that we wish,'' the statement said. ``If there were to be any reduction in the necessities of babies, then the same calamity affecting the Iraqi newborn will affect similarly the foreign babies.'' Iraq demanded an immediate end to the embargo, which was approved by the United Nations Security Council in the wake of the invasion. It also accused the United States of being largely responsible for the sanctions. ``The right solution is for the embargo to end which the United States deliberately imposed on the Iraqis,'' it said. President Bush has authorized the interdiction of shipments to Iraq, a move that has drawn criticism from some other nations. ``The military embargo, including food and medicine, is considered an act of war in accordance with international custom and international law,'' the statement said. Iraq blamed the United States and its allies for the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``Iraq did not attack the West,'' it said. ``Iraq is a peaceful nation.'' Today's statement came one day after the speaker of Iraq's Parliament said Iraq would hold all foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' until the threat of war against his country ends. He said they would be spread throughout the country, housed in military and civilian targets. The Iraqi parliament speaker, Sadi Mahdi Saleh, said Friday the foreigners would be held as long as the threat of war persists. A multinational force of thousands of troops, spearheaded by the United States, has been deployed in Saudi Arabia to defend it against possible Iraqi attack. ``The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' the Iraqi official said then. Friday's Iraqi statement drew a strong response today from France and Britain. France summoned Iraq's ambassador to warn of ``serious consequences'' if French citizens were not protected, and Britain denounced threats against foreign nationals as ``completely unacceptable.'' Also, the United Nations Security Council expressed concern about foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait, and asked Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Friday to take action to help them. The White House kept silent about Baghdad's announcement regarding the foreigners on Friday, and this morning, President Bush refused to answer reporters' questions about the Persian Gulf crisis. Before Friday's Iraqi announcement, however, Bush had said Iraqi attempts to move American civilians around Iraq and Kuwait violated international law. Fears for the safety of Americans was heightened after 35 U.S. citizens were removed from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad and taken to an undisclosed location, most likely another hotel. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday: ``We consider it a matter of serious concern.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Activate Reserves, White House Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 11th graf, bgng, `The vacation,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Bush meeting Sunday night with national security advisers at White House; picks up 12th graf pvs, `The actions'
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today that Iraq's holding American and other foreign citizens is ``totally unacceptable.'' The administration decried the use of ``innocent civilians as pawns'' in Saddam Hussein's stand against international sanctions. President Bush called on Iraq to immediately reconsider its refusal to let the foreigners, including an estimated 3,000 Americans, leave. The White House, in a statement by press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, also said it was ``deeply concerned'' by today's announcement from Baghdad that the Iraqi government may withhold food from the foreigners. Fitzwater said Iraq's announcement that it would not allow citizens from ``aggressive nations'' to leave is ``totally unacceptable.'' He said Bush ``is deeply troubled by the indication that Iraqi authorities intend to relocate these individuals within Iraq against their will.'' ``The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct,'' the spokesman said. Fitzwater said, ``We urge that Iraq immediately reconsider its refusal to allow any foreign national desiring to leave to do so without delay or condition.'' He said Iraq should ``take note of (Friday's) statement by the (United Nations) Security Council president expressing the council's concern and anxiety over the situation of foreign nations in Iraq and Kuwait, and calling upon the secretary general to take all appropriate steps.'' Fitzwater did not specify what action the United States was prepared to take if the Iraqis do not reverse course. But he added, ``The United States intends to consult with other governments, with citizens being held in Iraq and Kuwait, to determine what additional measures ought to be taken.'' Bush will return to Washington earlier than planned Sunday to meet with his national security advisers over dinner, the White House said. He is returning to the White House for the night and will meet with Energy Secretary James Watkins Monday morning to review the impact of the crisis on U.S. oil reserves. The vacation White House issued Fitzwater's statement shortly after a spokesman for Saddam Hussein appeared on Baghdad television calling the U.N. economic embargo ``an act of war'' and warning that foreign nationals it holds will suffer along with Iraqis if shortages of food and medicine develop. Fitzwater said Deputy National Security Adviser Robert Gates called Bush on his speedboat Fidelity at 11:30 a.m. EDT to discuss the Iraqi statement and the administration's response. The actions came as Bush is readying a call-up of U.S. military reserves and the Pentagon launched an unprecedented diversion of civilian aircraft to bolster the U.S. military presence in the Middle East. Bush, teeing off at golf before 7 a.m. today, refused to answer reporters' questions about the gulf crisis. Asked if he had been in touch with the White House situation room, Bush replied crisply, ``I talk to them every morning at 5:30 and I'm not going to take any more comments up here.'' Although Bush has decided to use reservists to fill in the ranks of military doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists, he is still weighing how many are needed to meet the Persian Gulf crisis, White House officials said. An Army source today said the Pentagon's recommendation to call up reserves did not include a specific number, but that as many as 80,000 armed services reservists and National Guardsmen could be activated. The 80,000 figure is ``a tentative upper limit planning figure,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The source said the actual number of reserves called up ``surely will be less than that.'' The source said also that the Army has not received the go-ahead from the White House to begin any activation of reserves, but that if the order came today, the first group of reservists could be processed for action within 24 hours. Bush has the authority to activate up to 200,000 reservists for 90 days, with the option of keeping them on active duty for another 90 days. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney refused to give a timetable for the U.S. commitment, saying en route to Saudi Arabia, ``Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate.'' It is Cheney's second trip to Saudi Arabia since Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. In the tense gulf region, Navy commanders stopped two Iraqi vessels Friday, but let them proceed after U.S. forces determined they were not carrying supplies for Iraq, an economic pariah since the occupation of Kuwait. The ships were not boarded. The United States is acting under criticism from United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. He said Thursday that this country's naval barricade to enforce U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq was undertaken without the authority of the U.N. Security Council ``We believe it's fully authorized,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater countered Friday. In another announcement, the Pentagon on Friday said up to 38 commercial airliners were being turned over to the military to haul troops and cargo. Although there have been charters, this is the first time part of the U.S. civil air fleet has been diverted under a plan conceived in the 1950s. The decision was made by the commander-in-chief of the U.S. Transportation Command and Military Airlift Command, Gen. H.T. Johnson, to meet the ``growing airlift requirements'' for U.S. forces deployed in the Middle East, a Defense Department statement said. The planes are owned by 16 airlines, which also will be providing the crews to operate them. The airlift support is expected to be needed for several weeks, the Pentagon said. Fresh concerns were raised about the safety of Americans after 35 U.S. citizens were removed from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad and taken to an undisclosed location, most likely another hotel. American diplomats in Baghdad believe the Americans may have been taken to the Melia Monsour, a hotel where British citizens are also quartered. But Iraqi authorities prevented the embassy officials from entering the hotel to check, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in Washington. Bush also plans to address the Veterans of Foreign War convention in Baltimore Monday and make a campaign trip to Rhode Island before returning to Kennebunkport.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Broke His Back Parachuting From High-Rise Won't Be Charged
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have decided a broken back is punishment enough and decided against filing charges against a man who parachuted from an unfinished high-rise. John Carta, a 44-year-old former Green Beret whose hobby is parachuting from skyscrapers and bridges, fractured his back in three places when his parachute failed Thursday. He was originally cited for trespassing, but the Alameda County district attorney's office decided not pursue charges in light of his injuries, Sgt. Jay Crawford said Friday. Carta was listed in stable condition after undergoing surgery for his injuries. His parachute only partly opened when he jumped from the top of the 27-floor American President Cos. building, which will be the city's tallest once it's finished. The daredevil previously has parachuted onto the 110-story World Trade Center in New York City from a low-flying airplane. In 1986, he and another man jumped from an unfinished 500-foot high-rise in San Francisco; they claimed it was the record for a parachute jump from the lowest point.

Here is the text of White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater's statement Saturday on Iraq's refusal to let foreigners leave the country: ``On several occasions since the Iraqi invasion and subsequent occupation of Kuwait, the president has stated publicly his interest in the well-being of American citizens and all foreign nationals in both Iraq and Kuwait. The president thus views yesterday's statement by the Speaker of Iraq's National Assembly that Iraq will `play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war' to be totally unacceptable. ``He is deeply troubled by the indication that Iraqi authorities intend to relocate these individuals within Iraq against their will. The president is also deeply concerned about today's announcement by the government of Iraq that foreign nationals may not have access to adequate quantities of food. The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct. ``We urge that Iraq immediately reconsider its refusal to allow any foreign national desiring to leave to do so without delay or condition. We would also hope that Iraq would take note of yesterday's statement by the U.N. Security Council president expressing the council's concern and anxiety over the situation of foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait and calling upon the secretary general to take all appropriate steps. ``The United States intends to consult with other governments with citizens being held in Iraq and Kuwait to determine what additional measures ought to be taken.''

DOC.HEAD: World's Largest Wooden Ship Makes Rare Trip Through Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: The H.M.S. Rose, the world's largest sailing wooden ship, is trolling through the Great Lakes as it marks its longest journey since being restored in a Connecticut harbor five years ago. The 18th-century British warship replica, a 500-ton wonder with masts reaching 150 feet into the air, docked in Chicago earlier this month and is touring several Wisconsin ports along Lake Michigan before returning to Connecticut in late September. In all the ship will cover 5,000 miles, far fewer than its namesake traveled when it crossed the Atlantic to attack rebel colonies during the Revolutionary War. ``It has been a very huge success at the ports that it's been in,'' said Ron Sonntag, spokesman for the Milwaukee-based Festival Events Inc., which arranged the tour. ``It's a huge spectacle. People don't have any idea how big it is until they get next to it.'' The vessel measures 179 feet long and 14 stories tall. Hundreds of Midwesterners flocked on Friday to watch the ship as it sailed into the harbor at Racine, Wis. The spectators were rewarded with a full 24-cannon salute. ``It's very impressive. . . . It's something I never thought I'd get the chance to see. I'm bringing the children so they can see it. I don't want them to miss a wonderful vision of the past, said Susan Penn, 40, of Highland Park, Ill., who traveled north to Racine to see the ship. The H.M.S. Rose left the Bridgeport, Conn., harbor June 20, sailing up the Atlantic Coast to the St. Lawrence Seaway. Its stops have included Cleveland, Detroit, and Chicago; it arrives in Milwaukee, its last stop, Aug. 27. ``The history of the Rose is incredible. We have the distinction of having the largest wooden vessel that is operational in the world,'' said its owner, Kaye Williams, of Bridgeport, Conn. The replica was built in 1970, incorporating a cannon and the keel salvaged from the wreck of the original H.M.S. Rose, built in 1757 as the British Navy's main warship. The British had scuttled the ship in the Savannah, Ga., harbor at the end of the Revolutionary War to avoid capture by the French. But the replica was allowed to decay. Williams bought it for $70,000 in 1985 and spent $1.3 million to restore it as part of his development of a marina and restaurant. Festival Events Inc. paid $250,000 to bring the ship to Milwaukee for the fourth annual Maritime Festival, scheduled Aug. 30 through Sept. 3. Organizers expect 600 visitors to tour the ship every hour as part of the 200,000 people expected at the event. The H.M.S. Rose and its crew of 28 are expected to return to Bridgeport Sept. 20. Williams said he hopes to take the ship to Puerto Rico in 1992 and then to the Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, the same year. Such long trips are rare for wooden vessels in modern times, but Williams is confident there's no better duty for his ship. ``She had to go to sea. The quote that comes to mind is `only men and ships rot at the dock,''' Williams said. ``A vessel will come back in better shape than when she left.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Reopens Question of Holy Shroud
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican said Saturday it would consider proposals for new scientific tests on the shroud of Turin to determine whether the linen is Jesus' burial cloth. The announcement by Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro cast doubt on earlier test results indicating the shroud was only about 700 years old. Cardinal Anastasio Ballestrero, archbishop of Turin and custodian of the shroud, said in 1988 that carbon-14 tests by U.S., Swiss and British laboratories showed the cloth dated to between 1260 and 1390. He said then that the tests were 95 percent accurate and he saw no reason for the church to dispute the results. But on Saturday, Navarro described the 1988 results as ``strange'' and said they conflicted with previous tests which indicated the cloth could date back 2,000 years. ``In the future, as in the past, the church will take into consideration all serious and competent operative proposals'' for tests on the shroud, Navarro said. He said the church would attach no conditions to any new tests, other than that they should not damage the shroud. Navarro said the shroud raises questions ``far beyond'' scientific and technical findings, adding that it remains a mystery how the cloth came to bear the image of what appears to be a whipped and crucified man. Navarro announced that Pope John Paul II had named Monsignor Giovanni Saldarini as new custodian of the shroud. Saldarini succeeded Ballestrero, who retired last year, as archbishop of Turin. Navarro said Ballestrero had acted with ``prudence and impartiality'' and had fostered ``a tradition of open, rigorous and objective research.'' For centuries, the shroud has been revered by some as Jesus' actual burial cloth, although the church has never claimed it was a holy relic. Others have described it as a clever forgery. The shroud measures 14 feet, 3 inches long and 3 feet, 7 inches wide. It bears a faint image of the front and back of a man with a thorn mark on the head, lacerations from flogging on the back and bruises on the shoulders _ suggestive of accounts of Jesus' crucifixion. Despite the 1988 findings, Ballestrero and other church officials disputed claims that the results proved the shroud was a fraud, fake or forgery _ words indicating the cloth was meant to deceive people. They said the shroud remains a venerated object and powerful symbol of faith. For years church officials refused to let scientists study the cloth. Pope John Paul II in 1986 gave approval for testing. The laboratories involved were the University of Arizona, Oxford University and the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology at the University of Zurich.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Withdraws Troops From Iran, POWs Come Home
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Iraqi troops withdrew Saturday from occupied Iranian territory, and Baghdad said those forces would be redeployed in the escalating confrontation with the United States. Iran sent home 1,000 Iraqi prisoners of war as a sign of its confidence that Baghdad's repatration of POWs, which began Friday, will continue. The troop withdrawal and prisoner exchange followed an offer by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Wednesday to bring a formal end to the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. A cease-fire halted the fighting two years ago. Iraqi troops, flying white flags, began pulling out of Iranian border areas Friday night. Iraqi forces had already pulled out of more than half the occupied areas in the southern Shalamcheh and Kushk regions, Iran's Islamic republic News Agency said Saturday. Saddam has said the pullout will take five days. Iran says Iraq occupies more than 773 square miles of its territories. But the United Nations says the size of the occupied area is half of that. The Iraqi army daily newspaper al-Qaddasiyah declared in an editorial Saturday that the 30 divisions which have been facing Iran would now be used to bolster Iraqi formations in the south. That was the first official Iraqi word that Baghdad will redeploy forces freed from the Iranian border in Kuwait, occupied by Iraq on Aug. 2. The forces ``which are leaving Iran's borders ... and the high readiness of our air force will be an additional might to what we had already prepared against the aggressive forces,'' the daily said. It was not known how many of the 30 Iraqi divisions _ more than 200,000 troops _ would be moved to Kuwait. The Iraqis have about 10 divisions in to the occupied emirate and have more than 120,000 troops massed on the border with Saudi Arabia. Iranian newspapers ran huge headlines Saturday welcoming the prisoners, some of whom were captured soon after the outbreak of war in September 1980. The Farsi-languge Jomhuri Eslami called their return ``a major victory for Iran.'' The site of the prisoner exchanges, Qasr-e-Shirin, a sleepy, dusty town inside the Iranian border, was decked with flowers, flags, and colored ribbons. At Tehran's Mehrabad airport, a 10-year-old girl named Nahid waited anxiously for the arrival of her father. She knew him only from a framed photograph on the mantel and from her mother's stories. In a message to the International Committee of the Red Cross, Iranian Red Crescent head Vaheed Dastjerdi urged that the prisoner repatriation be boosted to 5,000 a day ``with regard to the sensitive and dangerous conditions in the Persian Gulf.'' The Red Crescent said it could handle that many. But the International Committee of the Red Cross has said that for now, it can only handle daily 1,000 mandatory interviews to make sure the prisoners want to go home. It said it hoped to increase that number. The Red Cross has registered about 19,000 Iranian POWs in Iraq and about 50,000 Iraqis in Iran. But the United Nations estimates that both sides actually hold more than 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Steady Link to Magellan Restored; Pictures Show Quake Faults, Lava Flows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with mapping likely expected to be delayed, Magellan unloading its memory banks. Pick up 5th graf pvs: ``Engineers today ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Magellan sent information to Earth today to help engineers learn why they temporarily lost contact with the spacecraft after its first pictures displayed quake faults, volcanic cinder cones and plains made of lava flows on Venus. ``After steady contact with the spacecraft was re-established Friday night, engineers commanded the spacecraft to transmit all of the information in its computer memories back to Earth. This will continue throughout the weekend,'' said Mary Beth Murrill, spokeswoman for NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. She said it might take days to figure out why Magellan lost contact with Earth on Thursday night after it sent back its first test pictures of Venus _ images that had scientists marveling. ``The radar works far better than we ever dreamed it would,'' said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist. ``The kind of faulting we see would certainly mean there are `Venusquakes.''' The pictures will be released Tuesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in a statement issued Friday night. Before the problem developed, Magellan was scheduled to start its formal mapping mission Aug. 29, using its radar to peer through Venus' thick clouds. Murrill said a delay is likely, but engineers haven't yet announced their plans. Engineers today continued the process of returning Magellan to normal operation. It lost touch with Earth for almost 15 hours starting Thursday night, then continued to go in and out of radio contact over the next eight hours. A computer command sent to Magellan on Friday night restored steady radio contact at 7:11 p.m. PDT. ``We jumped up and clapped,'' said Tommy Thompson, Magellan science operations manager. `It was just like the home team scoring a touchdown.'' Thompson said engineers expected to remain in touch with Magellan except when it swings behind Venus, when it normally is unable to send or receive signals from Earth. As of today, the two planets were 147 million miles apart. Engineers will spend the coming days diagnosing the cause of the communications breakdown and deciding how to prevent it from happening again, Thompson added. Magellan was deployed May 4, 1989, from the shuttle Atlantis on its $744 million mission to make the best maps and pictures yet of Venus. The spaceship went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a looping 948-million-mile voyage. Less detailed radar pictures of Venus from other U.S. and Soviet spacecraft and from a radio telescope at Arecibo, Puerto Rico, revealed signs of faults on Venus and also found tens of thousands of volcanoes, although scientists still don't know if any are active. Magellan's first pictures showed in much better detail regions that intensely faulted, and also ``clear indications a lot of plains are (old) lava flows'' fractured by younger faults, Saunders said. ``What we're seeing is some of the lava flows that came out of large volcanoes, but we haven't seen any large volcanoes yet,'' he added. Saunders said volcanic cinder cones in the pictures have craters on top, and the cones range from three-fifths of a mile to 1 mile wide. Their height hasn't yet been calculated. Magellan must pass over the same area twice to detect landscape changes that would indicate volcanoes are erupting. It takes 243 Earth days for Venus to spin once beneath the nearly polar-orbiting Magellan, so it will be at least eight months until Magellan will be able to look for signs of active volcanoes. When Magellan first lost contact with Earth on Thursday night, its sophisticated computer programs automatically put it into a protective state of semi-hibernation called a ``safing mode,'' turning its solar panels to the sun to make sure it drew adequate power, laboratory spokesman Jim Doyle said. Magellan automatically entered an even deeper hibernation Friday morning, shutting down crucial systems to protect them but also making the spacecraft start rotating as it beamed radio signals into space. That assured some of the signals would reach Earth, but also meant radio contact was intermittent throughout the day. The command sent Friday night stopped the rotation and kept Magellan's secondary antenna pointed toward Earth to maintain contact. Communication through the secondary antenna is slower than through Magellan's main antenna. But the secondary antenna broadcasts a much broader, cone-shaped radio beam, allowing contact to be maintained more easily. NASA said controllers will switch back to the main antenna sometime next week. Magellan's radio signals are tracked by 230-foot-wide, dish antennas at Goldstone, Calif., and in Australia and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Photographer Tells Of Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait and Escape Across Desert
LaserPhoto BAH8
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Stephanie McGehee, a native of Leucadia, Calif., lived in Kuwait for 13 years and worked as a photographer for The Associated Press. She witnessed the Iraqi invasion, hid out for a week and led a convoy of Westerners in a dash across the desert to Saudi Arabia. This is her diary:

We made it! We made it! I jumped out of the car when the Bedouin guide told me we were in Saudi Arabia. My companions whooped and hugged each other. But most of us were sad for Kuwait, its people and the friends we left behind. My joy could not erase the memories of recent days, starting with that awful Thursday morning of Aug. 2 when the bomb blasts shook me out of bed. It was actually happening. The Iraqis were invading and their tanks were rumbling brazenly into Kuwait city. I told my Canadian flatmate, Kathy McGregor, that the Iraqis were there and ran to the roof. There was gunfire. The T-72s were rolling through the streets. The Iraqi soldiers stopped all motorists and pedestrians at gunpoint. They yanked the mobile phones out of cars and threw them away. They shot at motorists who didn't stop. I called the AP with the news, then rushed back to the roof. Iraqi army vehicles were heading to the oil area of al-Ahmadi. Helicopter gunships swooped low over the city. There was no sign of Kuwaiti troops. The Iraqis were shooting indiscriminately. It was frightening. At mid-afternoon, the Iraqis shelled the Sief Palace, the interior ministry and the parliament building. People were scared and confused. No one knew what to do. The shelling shifted later to the residence of the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and the palace of the Crown Prince, Sheik Saad Abdullah al-Sabah. The Iraqis set up headquarters at the nearby Sheraton Hotel after kicking everyone out. Kathy and I had a sleepless night. Aug. 3 _ Iraqi soldiers were on the rampage, looting, raping and murdering. Some stranded British Airways crewmembers called Kathy. They said an Indian flight attendant with British Airways was raped in a bus at a parking lot by Iraqis who threatened her with knives. They said they saw her running into the SAS Hotel lobby and asking for a doctor. Women panicked. The British Airways crewmen complained to an Iraqi general. He wanted the Indian girl to identify the rapists and promised to shoot them on the spot. The girl couldn't identify anyone. The general claimed the rapists were Iranians disguised as Iraqi soldiers. Aug. 5 _ The looting intensified. Car showrooms, auto spare part shops, the Central Bank, jewelry shops, private villas and palaces were all ransacked. The radio, now under Iraqi control, denounced the royal family and claimed the invaders were saving Kuwait from its corrupt rulers. They said they would install a new regime. Kuwaitis wept. Aug. 6 _ People were asking about the royal family. Were they safe? Had the Iraqis murdered them? We knew that the emir's cousin, Sheik Fahd al-Ahmed al-Sabah, was killed by an Iraqi tank shell outside the royal palace, which he tried to defend with a rifle. We were really scared. We left our beloved house and took refuge at an embassy. I can't say which one for fear the Iraqis might harm the people who are still there. Aug. 7 _ We moved to the SAS Hotel. Iraqi soldiers came and demanded a list of everyone in the hotel and their nationalities. The list was taken to an Iraqi major at the Royal Club Suite. We decided the hotel was no longer safe. We left. I spoke Arabic to the Iraqis and they thought I was Arab. We hid our passports in our shoes and sought refuge at another place, which I won't name. We stayed underground for eight very long, very boring days. Aug. 8 _ We started practicing self-defense _ karate, how to stab with a knife if attacked, how to kick and disable an adversary. Survival was the keyword. Aug. 9 _ We were glued to the radio. Practically cut off from the world, we wanted to know what was going on in Kuwait. We knew the Americans were out to save Kuwait and defend Saudi Arabia. That was good to know. We knew that the U.S. Embassy was telling Americans to pack and be ready to leave. Was there any chance of evacuating safely? No one seemed to know. Aug. 10 _ (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein pledged to wage a jihad, or holy war, against America. Oh Saddam, give us a break! Radio newscasts reported that most Islamic countries scoffed at this call. The radio said that Saddam claimed the United States didn't have enough military muscle to confront Iraq and alluded to chemical weapons as its ultimate means to crush America. Kuwait radio, operating clandestinely, came back on the air. It said Iraqi soldiers were fighting each other and deserting. There was more looting. The Iraqis were filling buses, trucks and cars with stolen radio and television sets, furniture, chandeliers, everything they could lay their hands on. We saw one truck with about 15 washing machines being unloaded in the basement of a house occupied by Iraqi residents. The gold souk, or market, was stripped clean. Aug. 12 _ Food was scarce. Kuwaiti women were selling jewelry for cash. Rumors were rife about Palestinians aiding the invaders. Kuwaitis denounced them as a fifth column. Aug. 13 _ The Iraqis said all Western embassy personnel should leave for Baghdad. We were scared. The Iraqis apparently wanted to keep us hostage. Aug. 14 _ I sneaked out for some fresh air. There were signs of Kuwaiti resistance and hit-and-run attacks. The underground was gathering money and food, distributing it to anyone who needed them. Grafitti on the walls reviled Saddam, told him to swallow his chemical weapons. MORE

DOC.HEAD: MANAMA: chemical weapons.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 15 _ I was seriously thinking of escaping. But we needed a foolproof plan, a four-wheel drive vehicle, water and food _ plus a guide to get us across the desert. Aug. 16 _ The Iraqis called U.S. nationals to gather at the International Hotel, the British at the Regency. There was no way we were going to just give ourselves up to be transported to Baghdad. A British woman, married to a Kuwaiti, called and offered to help with an escape. We got a Bedouin guide. We contacted a number of friends _ two Americans, a Briton, a Canadian and four Indians. They agreed to join us. Pretty soon we had more than 60 people ready to go. Aug. 17 _ Lebanese friends filled our jeep with gasoline from their cars. Kuwaiti friends provided black chador robes and veils for disguise. Almost everyone put on Arab robes. All the cars gathered at 10 a.m. and the great escape was on. We gave our dog a sleeping pill to keep her quiet and took the asphalt highway past Iraqi troops. We were scared, but the guide reassured us. We were stopped at one checkpoint and the soldiers told us to go back. We drove into the desert. But the Iraqis were there too. They stopped us, demanded our identity cards and told us to go back. We turned around, but tried another desert track. We played hide-and-seek with the Iraqis, dodging around troop camps without being spotted. We saw many cars abandoned by people who had tried to get away. We never knew what happened to them. Tanks were everywhere. We'd get through one sector, then regroup for the next dash. We passed scores of armored vehicles, some abandoned. Our guide said some Iraqi tank crews had deserted to the Saudis by joining refugee convoys. We thought our luck had run out when we ran right into a tank formation. But we slipped through. We discovered one of the cars was missing. The guide found it stuck in the sand _ and Iraqi soldiers helping the Kuwaiti occupants pull it out. The guide said two of the Iraqis were generals who apologized to the Kuwaitis for the invasion. We headed off again. After several hours, we hit a solid road. Our guide turned to me, beaming, and said the most wonderful words I've ever heard: ``No more dangers. You're now in Saudi Arabia.''

DOC.HEAD: Town Plants Claim to Banana Capital Of Nebraska
DOC.TEXT: It was a town looking for appeal and no monkey business. Civic boosters on Thursday bought the makings for 50 banana plants in a campaign to make this community of 1,100 the ``Banana City'' in the Cornbelt of America. ``This is the beginning of the big banana groves in the central region of the United States,'' said businessman Gene Brooks Sr. ``The Banana Belt has come to the Republican Valley.'' The banana belt idea took root about a year ago when Brooks began running radio ads for his car dealership, attempting to draw attention by advising listeners to ``Come to Banana City.'' One person called and asked if he was actually going to grow bananas. ``I said, `We certainly are,''' Brooks said, ``even though the idea had not occurred to me yet.'' Brooks researched bananas and ordered the banana ``corms,'' or starts, from Mexico. The corms, planted in half whiskey barrels, will grow to 8 feet and could produce edible bananas within a couple of years. The barrels, lined along city sidewalks, will be brought indoors during the winter. Businessman Lowell Harms said it is a positive way to promote the community. ``The next thing we have to do is find the monkeys,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Radiation Treatments Resume for Republican Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Doctors treating Lee Atwater have resumed radiation therapy to treat the Republican National Committee chairman for brain tumor ``progression,'' a spokeswoman said Saturday. However, the spokeswoman, Leslie Goodman, did not respond directly when asked about reports that physicians treating the 39-year-old South Carolinian had discovered a second brain tumor. She replied only that physicians ``were not specific on that.'' Saturday editions of two South Carolina newspapers quoted unidentified sources as saying doctors had discovered a new growth. But Goodman said doctors stated only ``that there has been tumor progression and that's about as much as we know and about as far as they intend to go in their description.'' She described Atwater's condition as unchanged from Friday. ``He's alert, seeing visitors and did undergo radiation treatment yesterday,'' she added. Goodman said the visitors had included family, friends and some Bush administration officials. A statement issued Thursday by the Republican National Committee had said a biopsy performed on Atwater ``indicated tumor progression requiring additional treatment.'' The statement said also that Atwater began receiving radiation treatment Wednesday. He was diagnosed March 6 as having a non-malignant tumor on the right side of his brain. The discovery of the second tumor was reported by The State newspaper in Columbia, S.C., which cited close friends of Atwater, and The News & Courier of Charleston, which quoted a source close to the situation. Responding to those reports, Goodman said Atwater's doctors ``aren't sure whether it's a new tumor or part of the old tumor.'' Atwater underwent brain tumor surgery on April 3 and has been in and out of the hospital repeatedly for treatment of ailments ranging from a blood clot in his leg to a nagging fever. Until this week, however, doctors believed the tumor was virtually gone. A friend described Atwater, who managed President Bush's 1988 campaign, as ``very, very weak.'' The controversial Atwater was President Bush's 1988 campaign manager. He has described himself as a nuts and bolts politician, but he enraged Democrats with his hard-ball brand of politics. Democrats were especially incensed when Atwater was credited with effectively injecting black Massachusetts prisoner Willie Horton, accused of raping a white woman while on furlough, into the 1988 presidential campaign against Democrat Michael Dukakis. Because of the Horton matter, Atwater's later efforts to woo black voters into the Republican fold were hampered. Born in Atlanta, Atwater was 9 years old when his parents moved to Columbia. In high school, he gained a passion for music, and even after he attained national prominence in politics, Atwater often performed as a rhythm and blues guitarist.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Threats to Western Civilians Pose New Headaches for Bush
DOC.TEXT: The White House denounced Iraq's use of ``innocent civilians as pawns'' in the Persian Gulf crisis Saturday as new threats to the safety of Americans posed what one analyst called ``a tremendous, painful dilemma'' for President Bush. Once again, the specter of hostages is forcing an American president to confront delicate issues of life and death in the Middle East. The 3,000 Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq may be an Achilles Heel in Bush's campaign to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his invading army from Kuwait and return exiled leaders to power. ``He's (Bush) in a classic bind,'' said Colorado College political scientist Tom Cronin. ``He's now invested militarily so much in it that he would look like a weak leader if he backed down or compromised because of the hostages.'' Bush was silent Saturday, but was described by aides as ``deeply troubled'' that Americans and foreigners were being moved against their will in Iraq. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said it was ``totally unacceptable'' that Baghdad said it will hold captive Americans as a shield as long as their was any threat to Iraq. Iraq also warned that all foreigners will suffer if shortages of food and medicine result from sanctions and the U.S.-led embargo. The White House said Bush was ``deeply concerned'' by that news. ``The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct,'' Fitzwater said in a statement. ``We urge that Iraq immediately reconsider its refusal to allow any foreign national desiring to leave, to do so without delay or condition,'' Fitzwater said. Brookings Institution analyst Judith Kipper said Iraq's use of the foreigners was ``blackmail.'' She said Saddam had created ``a tremendous, painful dilemma'' for Bush but that the United States still might have to use force, even if innocent Americans were killed. ``It's not because we're so cold-hearted and mean but because it's such a major crisis,'' she said. ``If we wait it's not going to get better, only worse.'' While confronting Iraq with a massive buildup of American combat forces, Bush had hoped that Saddam would not use U.S. citizens as an insurance policy against any U.S. strike or to force a rollback of sanctions. Trying to keep the stakes low, Bush has refused to call the Americans ``hostages.'' He referred to them last Friday as ``inconvenienced people who want to get out.'' Hostage situations in the past have embroiled Presidents Carter and Reagan. Bush inherited an ongoing, six-year hostage situation in Lebanon. Saddam clearly recognizes that captive Americans can be used as important bargaining chips _ expendable if necessary. His past practices indicate he clearly plays for keeps. Saddam has used chemical weapons against his own citizens and has repeatedly demonstrated a ruthless disregard for the lives of innocent civilians. There are fears that Americans and other foreigners might be positioned around military and industrial centers in Iraq to deter attack from the United States and its allies. Fitzwater, in his statement, said he hoped Iraq ``would take note'' of Friday's statement by the U.N. Security Council expressing concern and anxiety over the plight of foreign nations in Iraq and Kuwait. ``The United States intends to consult with other governments with citizens being held in Iraq and Kuwait to determine what additional measures ought to be taken,'' Fitzwater said. The White House announced that Bush would break away from his vacation Sunday earlier than anticipated to return to Washington to meet over dinner with his national security advisers. The president was piloting his high speed boat, ``Fidelity,'' when Iraq declared that the economic embargo against it was an act of war and warned that Westerners would suffer if Iraqis did. Bush was notified of the developments in a ship-to-shore call from Robert Gates, his deputy national security adviser.

DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA: ``grave consequences.''
DOC.TEXT: The warning that foreigners would starve came in a statement from the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs, also carried by INA. It singled out the United States for blame in blocking food supplies, and accused Washington of going beyond the mandatory U.N. sanctions in denying Iraq food and medicine. The United Nations imposed the embargo Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait. The United States ``proceeded with applying an economic seige by military force against Iraq ... and such an act by international law is known as an act of war,'' said INA. It emphasized that the blockade would deny children their milk, medication and other necessities. ``Because the children of the world are beloved of God and of Saddam Hussein and in compliance with our humanitarian principles...we have decided to place the children of foreign families which Iraq has decided to host in equality with the children of Iraq and...what affects the children of Iraq will equally effect them,'' said the statement. It said adult Westerners will also be affected. ``Due to the circumstances of the boycott and economic siege which have been imposed by the United States by military means food will not be available for all adults in the amounts we would wish,'' the statement said. The ministry noted that Europeans, especially Britons, will understand the measures due to their previous experiences. It said the food supplies in Iraq would be distributed to the military and in Iraq's extensive military industries on a priority basis because they are ``the shield of the nation.'' The solution to the problem was to end the blockade, said the statement. On Friday, Iraq's parliament speaker said Iraq would ``host'' all foreigners from nations taking what he called an aggressive stance against Iraq. It said they would be released only when the threat of war was lifted. There are two million foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait, which Iraq annexed after its Aug. 2 invasion.
