DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With AM-Gulf Rop, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
A U.S. frigate fired warning shots across the bow of an Iraqi oil tanker in the Gulf of Oman and U.S. forces briefly went to battle stations over the incident, a Navy official said. Iraq said two Iraqi oil tankers were fired on after refusing to be searched, and warned of ``grave consequences'' if case of another such incident.

Iraq called the U.S.-enforced economic blockade against it an act of war, and said thousands of foreigners stranded in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait will starve along with Iraqis if shortages occur. Baghdad has refused to let 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and 14,000 other Westerners leave.

The United States kept pouring thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia, trying to build a force that could withstand an invasion by Iraqi soldiers massed on the Saudi-Kuwait border. U.S. troops conducted their first night maneuvers in the Saudi desert in temperatures that hovered around 95 degrees.

U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the U.S. military commitment to defend Saudi Arabia is ``long-term,'' adding: ``Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate.'' President Bush prepared to call up some military reserves.

Saudi Arabia said it plans to increase its oil output by up to 2 million barrels a day to help offset the 4-million-barrel shortfall caused by the Iraqi invasion. That may not be enough to halt soaring gas and oil prices, however.
Arab refugees by the tens of thousands kept crossing into Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait. Only a few Westerners in private cars managed to get out.

DOC.HEAD: Tourist Trade Off After Yosemite Fires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeffery in 16th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: For merchants in the gateway communities of Yosemite National Park, business has been no business at all since fires closed the popular park to tourists. Three major fires and dozens of smaller ones in the 725,000-acre park since Aug. 3 scarred more than 22,000 acres, felled timbers and destroyed 66 buildings. More than a week ago, the park was closed to visitors, and most of the park is due to stay closed until Monday. Cool weather washed over much of fire-scarred California by the weekend as firefighters further tamed the last in a deadly siege of 1,300 blazes. But a National Weather Service expert, Milo Radulovich, said thunderstorms, which ignited nearly all the fires by spawning more than 37,000 lightning strikes in less than two weeks, are likely to recur after the cooling spell ends Monday. For those who make their living in communities near Yosemite, closing the park during the height of the summer tourist season has taken a financial toll, and its aftermath will probably be felt through the leaner winter months. Hotels and motels were hit hard. ``We can't recoup,'' said Joan Gloor, owner of the 37-room Mariposa Lodge off Highway 140, a major southern gateway to Yosemite, about 180 miles east of San Francisco. The motel was only 18 percent occupied Friday night during a month in which anything less than completely full is a rarity. Summer revenue ``is what we count on. We save up for the worst months of the year,'' Gloor said. ``It's going to be tough.'' The 61-room Gold Rush Inn in Mariposa also expected low occupancy during the weekend. ``It's pretty dead,'' said hotel clerk Jill Francis, adding that the hotel was more than 50 percent booked for Monday, the day the park's most popular destination, Yosemite Valley, is scheduled to reopen. Some small stores and restaurants in Mariposa County were closed over the weekend, but merchants that remained open said business was simply ``OK.'' Jean De Young, executive director of the Mariposa County Chamber of Commerce, described the situation as ``just a lot of quiet chaos.'' ``Everyone looks to August and early September as being the last real blast,'' she said. ``But people are canceling reservations as far away as September.'' Hotels and motels were busy this weekend contacting people with reservations and encouraging them to go ahead with Yosemite vacation plans. Though a segment of the park was open, all roads into Yosemite Valley remained closed this weekend, with the Highway 140 entrance scheduled to reopen Monday. And the road linking Coulterville, a historical gold mining town, with Yosemite will be closed until damaged timber is cleared. That made tourism in Coulterville ``almost nonexistent,'' said Karin Fielding, co-owner of the 20-room Hotel Jeffery. ``We get a lot of drop-in traffic, and that's what totally died,'' she said. ``We think (Coulterville) has a lot of attractions, but there's no doubt Yosemite is our main draw. ... The majority of our visitors are headed there.'' The fire has also affected employees of the park's biggest concessionaire, Yosemite Park and Curry Co. The company runs the 495-room Yosemite Lodge, the 123-room Ahwane Hotel, several lodging and tent sites, tour buses, every restaurant and almost every store in Yosemite National Park. Several hundred of the company's 1,500 employees worked during the fires, said company spokesman John Poimiroo. He didn't expect layoffs because summer employees are leaving. The National Park Service lost an estimated $50,000 in entrance fees each day the park was closed, said Pat Tolle, fire information officer for Yosemite Center. The park, however, will not be directly affected by the loss because those funds go into the service's general treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Girl In Baby Swap Case Meets Biological Parents and Siblings
DOC.TEXT: Kimberly Mays, an 11-year-old at the center of a two-year baby-swap controversy, has finally met the couple who proved she was switched with another baby in a maternity ward, according to a report published Saturday. But a relative says the girl is still confused by the legal tug-of-war and all the attention from a family she never knew. Meanwhile, the man who raised the girl has joined the girl's natural parents in a lawsuit against the hospital where the switch apparently occurred. The long-awaited meeting between the Sarasota girl and her biological parents, Ernest and Regina Twigg, took place quietly this spring at a miniature golf course in Sarasota, the St. Petersburg Times reported Saturday. The couple and Robert Mays, who raised Kimberly as his only daughter, agreed to keep the visit secret to avoid the crush of reporters and photographers who have followed the high-profile case through the courts. During an initial rendezvous and two subsequent meetings, Kimberly, an only child in the Mays family, also was introduced to her seven brothers and sisters in the Twigg family. ``Apparently, with the kids it went very good. But when you ask about the parents, she just puts her hands up in the air and shakes them,'' said Velma Coker, one of Kimberly's grandmothers. ``She's still mixed-up,'' Mrs. Coker told the newspaper. Kimberly, born at a tiny rural hospital in Central Florida, went home with the wrong parents _ Mays and his wife, Barbara, who died of cancer in 1981. Ms. Mays and Ms. Twigg delivered blond-haired girls within a couple days of each other in late 1978 at Hardee Memorial Hospital in Wauchula. The Mays baby and the Twigg baby were the only two white girls born around the same time at the hospital. Both mothers went home on Dec. 5, 1978. It wasn't until genetic tests a decade later that the families learned they had raised each other's daughter. The girl the Twiggs named Arlena and raised as their own died of a heart defect two years ago, never knowing that doubts about her parentage had been raised shortly before she died. The Twiggs set out to find their natural daughter. The path led to Sarasota. Mays and the Twiggs feuded in court over genetic testing and custody rights. Mays won a promise from the Twiggs that they wouldn't seek custody no matter what the tests showed. Genetic testing confirmed last fall that Kimberly was born to the Twiggs, who now live in Sebring. Attempts to reach Mays and the Twiggs for comment were unsuccessful Saturday; each family has an unlisted number.

DOC.HEAD: Four Soldiers Who Were To Join Gulf Forces Killed in Accident in Kentucky
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Four soldiers who were to join U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf were killed Saturday when their pickup slammed into a toll booth, state police said. A fifth soldier was critically injured in the accident at the Hopkinsville toll plaza on the Pennyrile Parkway, about 15 miles north of Fort Campbell on the Kentucky-Tennesee line. Two toll collectors said the truck was going between 75 and 80 mph when it slammed into the cushion in front of one booth, according to Trooper Mack Brake. The collector working that booth had just left his post and was not injured, Brake said. Brake said all three men riding in the bed of the truck were killed, as was the driver. The survivor was riding in the cab. Authorities declined to release other details of the 5:15 a.m. accident. The soldiers were part of the 101st Airborne Division, of which 17,000 are being sent to Saudi Arabia, said Bill Harralson, spokesman at Fort Campbell. The names of the five soldiers were being withheld until relatives were notified, Harralson said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Official: Iraqi Troops Making Forays into Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops have made forays, believed to be for reconnaissance, along the Saudi-Iraqi border, a top Saudi official said Saturday. In an intelligence assessment of the Persian Gulf crisis, the official said the Iraqis are thought to have 170,000 men and 1,000 tanks in Kuwait. Because of the flat desert terrain, tanks are easily moved around the region, he said. ``At the moment, all the indications are that they are digging in,'' the official said of the Iraqi troops. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The Iraqis in Kuwait are remaining at least 25 miles from the Saudi border and have set up a command center at al-Wafrah in southern Kuwait. Meanwhile, Iraqi forces have been spotted on the Saudi-Iraqi border near Kuwait, the official said. The troops have been few and their forays have been brief, the official said. He speculated they are reconnaissance missions along the 520-mile Saudi-Iraqi border. The only way to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait at this point would be to deal ``significant blows,'' both economic and military, to Saddam Hussain, the official said. He said it was impossible to predict how long Saddam could keep his country fed during the international boycott because there is no estimate of how much food Iraq has stockpiled. Iraq imports more than 70 percent of its food, and the Saudi official said he knows ``they had orders for foodstuffs which have not reached Iraq.'' One shortage that Saddam does not face is military hardware, the official said. ``They are well stocked, and they have spare parts, and they have manufacturing capabilities,'' he said. At the same time, the official said, the Saudis will work to encourage the local resistance to Saddam in Kuwait and Iraq. In Kuwait, there are reports of people buying tanks from Iraqi troops to blow them up, the official claimed. He said Kuwaitis are broadcasting anti-Saddam radio programs into Iraq. The official said the Saudis are convinced that if Saddam is deposed, his government will crumble. But Saddam's moves are hard to predict because the Iraqi president discusses his plans with only a small coterie of advisers.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead In Oil Storage Tank Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Four people apparently climbing on an oil storage tank were killed when the tank exploded, authorities said Saturday. The victims, including two teen-age sisters, were apparently climbing a ladder to the top of the tank Friday night when a spark ignited the explosion, said Lt. Robert Davidson of the DeSoto Parish Sheriff's Office. ``Places like these are gathering places for teens,'' he said. ``At most of these places, the gates are unlocked or broken. They are a pretty good place to get out of town. Hopefully after this that will end.'' The powerful explosion shook house windows in the area and threw one of the girls 65 feet from the tank, he said. The dead were identified as Becky Wall, 16, and Heather Wall, 14, both of Keatchie; David Price, 21, of Logansport; and Tony Walker, 21, of Flatwood, Texas. No one else was injured, Davidson said. Authorities hadn't determined the cause of the spark, Davidson said, but it might have been a cigarette lighter. The about 30-foot tank held about 20 gallons of oil, far below its capacity of several thousand gallons, he said. It was destroyed and a similar tank nearby was damaged. A sheriff's investigator was inspecting he tank site Saturday. It was not immediately known who owned the tank, which was about five miles north of this west Louisiana town near the Texas border.

DOC.HEAD: Solzhenitsyn Invited By Russian Premier To Return Home
DOC.TEXT: Russia's prime minister on Saturday invited exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn to return home, and Tass reported that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has restored the citizenship he stripped from a dissident poet. Irina Ratushinskaya, whose stirring poems from the gulag won her international acclaim and persecution at home, was one of 23 people who lost their citizenship between 1966-88 and had it restored by Gorbachev last week, the official news agency said. Eleven of the names, including those of Ms. Ratushinskaya and her dissident husband, Igor Gerashchenko, were first disclosed Saturday. Another was Natalia Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate's wife. Restoration of Alexander Solzhenitsyn's citizenship was announced Thursday. In a letter published on the front page of Saturday's Sovietskaya Rossia newspaper, Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev urged Solzhenitsyn to accept his restored citizenship and return home as Silayev's guest. Solzhenitsyn's homecoming was ``one of those moves that are needed as much as air by our homeland,'' Silayev wrote. ``The interests of the state and its future destiny compel me to ask you and your family to accept an invitation to be my personal guests at any time you choose.'' Some of those rehabilitated were stripped of their citizenship by previous leaders such as Leonid I. Brezhnev, but at least three of those named Saturday lost theirn citizenship after Gorbachev came to power in March 1985. Ms. Ratushinskaya and Gerashchenko lost their citizenship in 1987 while in London. She had sought medical treatment for heart trouble and other problems she says she developed in labor camps. She was released from captivity a few months after Gorbachev took office. Soviet authorities had accused her of spreading ``deceitful propaganda intended to win the West's trust.'' Ms. Ratushinskaya has said she would return home only if greater democratization took hold. Another former dissident on the latest list was psychiatrist Anatoly Koriagin, who spent six years in labor camps. Gorbachev stripped him of citizenship after he criticized authorities for using psychiatry as a political weapon. Mrs. Solzhenitsyn, whose citizenship was taken away in 1977, said last week her husband demands that expulsion orders and treason charges against him be lifted before he would consider accepting any Soviet citizenship offer. Solzhenitsyn, 71, was arrested for treason in February 1974, forced onto a plane to Germany and stripped of his citizenship. He lives in Cavendish, Vt., and says he won't return unless all his books have been published in the Soviet Union and are widely available. His works include ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' about the horrors of Josef Stalin's prison camps, ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich,'' ``Cancer Ward'' and ``August 1914.'' Others on the latest list of those whose citizenship has been restored were: Georgy Vins, a former leader of the Soviet Union's Baptist sect; Raisa Orlova, the late wife of Solzhenitsyn's prison friend Lev Kopelev; Igor Shelkovsky, a sculptor and journalist; Mykola Rudenko, a dissident writer and a founder of the Ukrainian Helsinki Group; I. Shakhnazorova; Mikhail S. Voslensky, who wrote the book, ``Nomenklatura,'' an inside account of the lives and structure of the Soviet bureaucracy; I.S. Glagoleva; Yu. Novikov; and M.H. Rezmetz. Those announced Thursday were Solzhenitsyn; chess champion Victor Korchnoi; writers Vasily Aksyonov, Vladimir Voinovich, Lev Kopelev, Georgi Valdimov and Valeri Tarsis; scientists Yuri Orlov and Valeri Chalidze; and artist Oskar Rabin.

DOC.HEAD: First Group of Soviet Evacuees From Gulf Arrive in Moscow
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM2
DOC.TEXT: The first Soviets to be evacuated from Kuwait, mostly oilfield construction workers, arrived home Saturday after a long trek along desert highways clogged with thousands of other refugees. ``We were not caught in the middle of the fighting, thanks be to God!'' Maya M. Nagayeva said. She was standing on the tarmac of Sheremetyevo-1 Airport next to the Aeroflot jumbo jet that flew her and about 240 other Soviets home from Amman, Jordan, following the overland journey from Kuwait through Iraq. The Soviets said they were well-treated by Iraqi soldiers following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but were happy to be home. A few were greeted with hugs, tears and flowers by about two dozen anxious relatives who had gathered to meet the Ilyushin-86. Most aboard the plane were rugged-looking construction workers from the oilfields in Siberia. They would stop over briefly in Moscow before returning to their home towns, said Sergei K. Arakelyan, an official of the Ministry for the Oil and Gas Construction Industry who formally greeted the workers. The Soviets all had lived in Kuwait. They traveled for three days from the overrun sheikdom: via bus and car to Baghdad in 113-degree temperatures, across Iraq on a highway jammed with other refugees heading for the Iraqi-Jordanian border, and then on to Amman for the flight home. They said the conquering Iraqi soldiers provided them with an escort to the Iraq border on the first phase of their evacuation to Baghdad. ``We were welcomed in a friendly way with no problems from the Iraqi side or the Kuwaiti side,'' said Antonina V. Bluzkina, a secretary who was given a huge bouquet of flowers by her tearful daughter. Telman Alkataev, senior executive of a construction sector and head of the group, told Tass news agency that ``none of us was harmed or humiliated'' by the Iraqi troops. ``Soldiers came to our apartments many times, but there was not a single case of theft,'' he said. Mrs. Nagayeva said the Soviet community in Kuwait was unaware of the invasion until after Iraq had already occupied the country. ``At 8 a.m. (on Aug. 2), we were told that there was a war,'' she said. ``We were afraid, worried. Everyone was. But when we learned that the Soviet government was doing everything to evacuate us, we calmed down. Now we are just happy to be home.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Threats to Western Civilians Pose New Headaches for Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Changes slug to conform to item listed on AM-News Digest. Trims final 2 grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The White House denounced Iraq's use of ``innocent civilians as pawns'' in the Persian Gulf crisis Saturday as new threats to the safety of Americans posed what one analyst called ``a tremendous, painful dilemma'' for President Bush. Once again, the specter of hostages is forcing an American president to confront delicate issues of life and death in the Middle East. The 3,000 Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq may be an Achilles Heel in Bush's campaign to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his invading army from Kuwait and return exiled leaders to power. ``He's (Bush) in a classic bind,'' said Colorado College political scientist Tom Cronin. ``He's now invested militarily so much in it that he would look like a weak leader if he backed down or compromised because of the hostages.'' Bush was silent Saturday, but was described by aides as ``deeply troubled'' that Americans and foreigners were being moved against their will in Iraq. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said it was ``totally unacceptable'' that Baghdad said it will hold captive Americans as a shield as long as their was any threat to Iraq. Iraq also warned that all foreigners will suffer if shortages of food and medicine result from sanctions and the U.S.-led embargo. The White House said Bush was ``deeply concerned'' by that news. ``The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct,'' Fitzwater said in a statement. ``We urge that Iraq immediately reconsider its refusal to allow any foreign national desiring to leave, to do so without delay or condition,'' Fitzwater said. Brookings Institution analyst Judith Kipper said Iraq's use of the foreigners was ``blackmail.'' She said Saddam had created ``a tremendous, painful dilemma'' for Bush but that the United States still might have to use force, even if innocent Americans were killed. ``It's not because we're so cold-hearted and mean but because it's such a major crisis,'' she said. ``If we wait it's not going to get better, only worse.'' While confronting Iraq with a massive buildup of American combat forces, Bush had hoped that Saddam would not use U.S. citizens as an insurance policy against any U.S. strike or to force a rollback of sanctions. Trying to keep the stakes low, Bush has refused to call the Americans ``hostages.'' He referred to them last Friday as ``inconvenienced people who want to get out.'' Hostage situations in the past have embroiled Presidents Carter and Reagan. Bush inherited an ongoing, six-year hostage situation in Lebanon. Saddam clearly recognizes that captive Americans can be used as important bargaining chips _ expendable if necessary. His past practices indicate he clearly plays for keeps. Saddam has used chemical weapons against his own citizens and has repeatedly demonstrated a ruthless disregard for the lives of innocent civilians. There are fears that Americans and other foreigners might be positioned around military and industrial centers in Iraq to deter attack from the United States and its allies. Fitzwater, in his statement, said he hoped Iraq ``would take note'' of Friday's statement by the U.N. Security Council expressing concern and anxiety over the plight of foreign nations in Iraq and Kuwait. ``The United States intends to consult with other governments with citizens being held in Iraq and Kuwait to determine what additional measures ought to be taken,'' Fitzwater said. The White House announced that Bush would break away from his vacation Sunday earlier than anticipated to return to Washington to meet over dinner with his national security advisers.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger, his biceps bulging amid the corn dog and fried dough vendors at the Illinois State Fair, declared Illinois the nation's leading example for physical fitness Saturday. The former bodybuilding champion turned Hollywood actor came to the fairgrounds in the starring role of chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. He said Illinois was the only state to impose a daily physical education requirement in its public schools. ``Illinois still isn't perfect and I've talked to Gov. (James) Thompson about that,'' he said after presenting the governor an award for his work on behalf of physical fitness. Schwarzenegger, who had breakfast with the governor at the Executive Mansion, said many schools may not be following through on the physical education requirement because of budgetary problems. Schwarzenegger was present as honorary race director for the sixth annual ``Kids Fun Run'' featuring more than 500 kids from kindergarten through sixth grade in a half-mile run from the fair's main gate to ``Kid's Corner.'' ``Remember this is not a race where we just try to win and push everyone aside,'' he warned the kids as they lined up. Adults, with their cameras and videorecorders at the ready, seemed more interested seeing the international film star than watching the kids race. ``It's the team work of the schools and parents that can save our children today,'' Schwarzenegger told parents, urging them to avoid being ``couch potatoes'' and to join their kids instead in sports and other activities.

Hank Williams Jr., the often rowdy country music star, has written a song suggesting that Iraq take its poison gas and ``stick it in your sassafras.'' Williams said he wrote the song Thursday after watching television news reports about the critis in the Middle East. ``I was mad,'' he said Friday. The song, called ``Don't Give Us a Reason,'' warns Iraq against pushing the United States to war. Williams called his band together, rehearsed the song Friday and recorded it. The tune could be ready for release in a few days. Williams is known for his hit songs like ``All My Rowdy Friends (Are Coming Over Tonight)'' and ``Born to Boogie.'' He was the Country Music Association's entertainer of the year in 1987 and 1988.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: A former publicist for boxer Mike Tyson's ex-wife is suing the former heavyweight champion for sexually assaulting and threatening to kill her, her attorney said Saturday. Phyllis C. Polaner filed the lawsuit Friday in Superior Court, seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages from Tyson, his ex-wife, Robin Givens, and Ms. Givens' mother, Ruth Roper, attorney Howard E. Brechner said. The lawsuit accuses Tyson of abusing the three women between Aug. 28 and Oct. 2, 1988, while Tyson and Ms. Givens were involved in a divorce case. The suit alleges that Ms. Givens and Ms. Roper ``maliciously failed'' to stop the abuse, which the former publicist says caused ``severe temporary and permanent personal and emotional injuries.'' Ms. Polaner also claims Tyson sexually assaulted and threatened to kill her. The suit refers to a Sept. 20, 1988 incident in Moscow in which an angry Tyson chased the three women from their hotel suite and held them in a glass-enclosed elevator against their will. Ms. Polaner contends that on that day, Tyson ``assaulted, battered, menaced, threatened and detained her against her will.'' There was no answer Saturday at the office of Tyson's lawyer, Howard Weitzman of Los Angeles. Howard Weitzman was quoted in Friday's editions of The Star-Ledger of Newark as saying the allegations were ``absolutely false.'' He said Ms. Polaner was only after money from Tyson.

DOC.HEAD: Author of Parapsychology Books Stabbed to Death
DOC.TEXT: A well-known author of books on parapsychology and near-death experiences phenomenon was found stabbed to death in his home, authorities said Saturday. Police found the body of D. Scott Rogo, 40, in his Northridge home on Thursday after a concerned neighbor called to say Rogo's backyard sprinkler had been running for two days. No arrests have been made and police had no motive for the killing, Detective Michael Brandt said. Rogo's mother, Winifred Rogo of North Hollywood, said she doubted the murder had anything to do with her son's work. ``He investigated strange phenomena, but it wasn't dangerous,'' she said. ``I think it was a prowler, someone off the street.'' Rogo lived alone and worked from his home. He had written 30 books and conducted investigations into telepathy, clairvoyance and extrasensory perception. Raymond Bayless, a former president of the Southern California Society for Psychical Research, said Rogo had a good reputation among experts on the paranormal. ``He was top-rank,'' Bayless said. ``This is a tremendous loss to the field.'' Rogo's books included ``The Poltergeist Experience,'' ``Beyond Reality,'' ``Phone Call From the Dead'' and ``NAD: A Study of Unusual Other-World Experiences.'' The latter was published when Rogo was a 19-year-old student at California State University, Northridge. He also published articles in Parapsychology Review and the Journal of the Society for Psychical Research, and had lectured on the topic at John F. Kennedy University in Orinda, Calif.

fyi, alerted richmond buro that air force is offering ``media opportunity'' tomorrow at langley air force base, va., to see the F-117A stealth fighters that have arrived there for deployment to Saudi Arabia and to talk with the base's wing commander and director of operations. richmond said it would make arrangements to cover either with norfolk correspondent d.w. page or a richmond staffer. told here that the langley folks want to talk about the plane's capabilities but won't talk details on deployment to saudi. all in all, seems a bit curious. guess they looking for a little ink. WX-burns.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Destroys 13th-Century Monastery
DOC.TEXT: A fire destroyed a 13th-century Dominican monastery Saturday, causing an estimated $1.9 million in damage and leaving little standing but the stone outer walls. The fire broke out shortly after midnight and was probably caused by a short-circuit, firefighters said. The 30 Dominican sisters living there were evacuated safely. The monastery was founded in 1209 by St. Dominic. It lies in the Pyrenees region, 465 miles southwest of Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Report Cites East German Secret Police in West German Killing
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's now-disbanded secret police may have been behind the deaths of several West German businessmen who dealt with East German firms, a West Berlin newspaper said Saturday. The Berliner Morgenpost said some cases involved West Germans who managed firms that were fronts for East German operations. The paper quoted Karl-Heinz Schlurmann, a former East-West commerce expert, as saying links existed between the unexplained deaths of several West German businessmen who had dealings with the former Communist government. The paper cited the case of Hamburg businessman Uwe Harms, who was found shot to death in his apartment on April 26, 1987. It quoted Schlurmann as saying Harms was involved in shipping weapons from East Germany to Third World countries, balked at the business and was killed because he knew too much. The newspaper also cited the September 1981 death of Karl-Heinz Noetzel, who it said was chief of an East German cover firm in Essen, West Germany. It said Noetzel was found dead in a Leipzig hotel bathroom, apparently having suffocated. It quoted Schlurmann as saying a possible motive for his death may have been corruption. It said Noetzel's successor, J.F. Bruns, died on Aug. 20, 1982, in the East Berlin hotel Metropol after he was suspected of being an agent for the West. It also cited the death in a car accident of trade expert Horst Busse in March 1972. The newspaper report follows recent allegations that the secret police may have tracked down and killed prominent East German refugees who fled to the West, and that they also harbored notorious left-wing terrorists wanted in Western nations. Sensational disclosures have been coming out ever since East Germany threw off its hard-line Communist rulers and elected a democratic government.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix category to `p'
Wilder Budget Cutting Seen As Political Move
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's announcement that he would impose broad spending cuts without raising taxes is seen as further evidence he plans to run for national office, possibly as early as 1992. ``Anybody who thinks the governor is not looking at 1992, in spite of what he's said, is extraordinarily naive,'' said Sen. Dudley J. Emick Jr., a fellow Democrat. Wilder, who has received widespread publicity since he became the nation's first elected black governor in January, has said he has no plans to seek national office before his term ends in 1994. But his cost-cutting plans are seen as a way to contrast his record with that of President Bush, who is considering a tax increase to balance the federal budget. Wilder thinks if he can ``contrast himself with both George Bush and with so-called tax-and-spend Democrats, he's well positioned for a national race,'' said Robert Holsworth, a Virginia Commonwealth University political analyst. ``He's positioned himself for the kind of race he would have to run whether it's in '92 or '96, that of a fiscal conservative,'' said Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist. In a statewide televised address Thursday night, Wilder said he would freeze state employee salaries, slash state agency spending, eliminate some minor agencies and cut aid to schools to make up a projected $1.4 billion budget shortfall. He blamed an economic slump for the expected drop in tax revenues to fund the state's $26 billion, two-year budget. The governor said he would propose no new taxes and would maintain services for the poor and medically needy. ``That plays well among the pragmatists of the Democratic Party,'' Sabato said. Holsworth said the speech was Wilder's latest success in portraying himself as a fiscal conservative while still holding on to his core black and liberal constituency. But he said Wilder may have jeopardized his relationship with state legislators, some of whom were angry about not being consulted on the cuts. Holsworth also said Wilder could be hurt in the long run by cutting education funding, which is particularly needed in poor, rural schools that he has pledged to improve. Holsworth likened Wilder to Democrat Jimmy Carter, who launched himself to the presidency by emphasizing his budget cutting and social compassion during one term as governor of Georgia. Sabato said he saw similarities to Republican Ronald Reagan, who blamed Carter for the fiscal problems that he inherited in the early 1980s. Sabato said Wilder has taken the same approach by blaming his Democratic predecessor, Gerald L. Baliles, for leaving behind fiscal problems. Wilder took his latest dig at the former governor by saying he would abolish the Department of World Trade that Baliles created. Despite his denial of national ambitions in 1992, Wilder may have betrayed himself when he announced the revenue shortfall at a news conference Aug. 1. The governor said he wanted to reveal the budget problems to ``the American people'' before quickly correcting himself.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Serbs Set up Roadblocks on Eve of Referendum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Croatian presidency saying tension amounts to armed insurrection, other details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Serbs with shotguns and hunting rifles sealed roads into southwestern Croatia on Saturday in what the state presidency said amounted to an armed insurrection. The Serbs planned a referendum Sunday on their autonomy within the republic and set up road blocks to keep police from intefering. The Croatian government has declared the vote illegal. A statement by the Croatian presidency, reported on Croatian radio, said tensions had ``assumed the form of an armed insurrection.'' Both sides appeared to be trying to avoid an armed conflict, however. Police did not try to move into the region. Radio Knin reported earlier after a conversation with local Serbian leader Milan Babic that contacts were under way with Croatian President Franjo Tudjman and the head of Croatian police to defuse the dispute. Babic appealed over local radio to Serbs manning roadblocks to let traffic pass. On Friday, Yugoslav air force fighters intercepted a flight of police helicopters before they could reach this region near the Adriatic coast. The increasingly bitter disagreements between Yugoslavia's two largest ethnic groups threatens to tear the fragile federation apart. ``If the police come try to break through in their armored cars, we will fry them like chickens in a pan,'' said a Serbian man armed with a double-barrel shotgun standing guard at a roadblock nine miles north of Knin. He refused to identify himself. Other armed Serbs felled trees and dumped rocks on the main highway south of the Croatian capital, Zagreb, to seal off the area. In a village near Knin, some Serbs were seen armed with light machine guns. The roadblocks sealed off resorts on the Adriatic coast, and left carloads of German and Italian tourists stuck facing armed village men. Serbs, the largest Yugoslav ethnic group, make up 11 percent of Croatia's 5 million people. Serbs charge Tudjman's new, reform-minded government with fostering nationalism. Tudjman's administration advocates turning the country into a loose federation of six nearly independent states. Serbia's hard-line Communist president, Slobodan Milosevic, and the Communist-dominated armed forces oppose this and favor greater centralization and federal control. Official Croatian radio said earlier that tensions started to ebb Saturday. It accused the Serbian minority of trying to secede and join the Serbian republic. Croatian officials fear that would foster domination of Yugoslavia by the Serbia. In its statement issued later, the Croatian presidency asked the federal government to take measures to prevent ``extreme nationalists from Serbia'' from coming to Croatia with reinforcements. It did not elaborate. Croatian radio said use of national air force jets to stop the police helicopters amounted to an effort ``to overthrow the state's new government . . . and to put a stop to democratic processes in Yugoslavia.'' The Croatian presidency called on the federal presidency to determine ``the responsibility of senior army commanders'' in the incident. The state news agency Tanjug said the Yugoslav army chief-of-staff informed Croatian Premier Stipe Mesic the army would not intervene as long as ``there are no casualties.'' But the statement also said the army's tasks included preventing ``fratricidal war'' and the army would ``perform this task unconditionally'' according to the constitution and the law.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soviet Troops to Start Withdrawing From East Germany
With AM-Germany-Soviet Troops, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union plans to start withdrawing its troops from East Germany ahead of schedule, a West German newspaper reported Saturday. The Hamburg-based newspaper Bild am Sonntag said in an article released to other news media that the withdrawal of some of the estimated 370,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany could begin as early as next week. The newspaper said the withdrawal of Moscow's largest military force outside the Soviet Union could be completed by the end of next year. Bild am Sonntag did not identify its sources, and the duty officer at the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin had no comment. A West German Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn denied that the pullout would be completed by the end of 1991. The official, Juergen Chrobog, said the timetable would follow the agreement reached last month by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They agreed that the withdrawal would be spread out over three to four years. However, Bild quoted Horst Teltschik, a top aide to Kohl, as saying that he would not exclude that the withdrawal would take place at a faster tempo than agreed upon earlier. Bild said that according to NATO reports, about 10,000 trains with 50 cars each are needed to take all the troops home. East Germans have already begun to express impatience with the Soviet troops' continued presence. Graffiti saying ``Russen Raus'' (Russians Out) is not uncommon in towns where Soviet soldiers are stationed. Soviet troops have already started pulling out of Czechoslovakia and Hungary as the once formidable Warsaw Pact disintegrates in the face of democratic changes in Eastern Europe. Moscow will be losing its most important Warsaw Pact ally once East Germany unites with West Germany, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. That is expected to occur by the end of this year.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility For Killing Construction Worker
DOC.TEXT: A bomb placed on a mechanical digger killed a construction worker Saturday, and the Irish Republican Army reportedly claimed responsibility. Police said the 43-year-old married man, who was not identified, died when the bomb exploded as he was preparing to climb aboard the digger in a construction yard in Castlederg, County Tyrone. The man worked part time for a local contractor. A Belfast radio station said the IRA claimed responsibility and warned that anyone working on contracts for the Northern Ireland security forces would continue to be ``legitimate targets.'' Police said they had no information on whether the construction company was involved in work for the security forces. The man was the 38th person to die in political and sectarian violence in the province this year. More than 2,800 people have died since the strife began in 1969. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Fear Grows Among Relatives of `Detainees'
DOC.TEXT: Pessimism enveloped relatives of American expatriates as Gulf tensions moved up another notch and Iraq said foreigners there and in Kuwait would be the first to suffer if a U.S. economic blockade makes food and medicine scarce. The latest Iraqi statement about the detainees could be just ``more chest-thumping,'' said Donnita Cole, of Odessa, Texas, whose 50-year-old husband John Henry Cole was working for an oil company in Kuwait. She added: ``I think we've got a big problem on our hands, and I don't think protocol is going to work anymore. I think we're going into a war.'' ``This is, I guess, what we thought about and hoped it wouldn't be a problem,'' said Bob Nickman of Pleasonton, Neb. Nickman, whose son Mike is stranded in Iraq, said he feared Americans and other foreigners might suffer more than Iraqis from any shortages. ``The Iraqi people would probably favor themselves,'' he said. ``That's natural.'' Iraq, which imports three-fourths of its food, said Iraqi and foreign babies and elderly people will be the first to feel the effect as the nation ensures that food goes to its soldiers first. The Baghdad government is detaining 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, invaded Kuwait. In a television interview broadcast Friday on ABC News, Mike Nickman said he would like to leave Iraq ``as long as there's anything possible that could happen here.'' ``I would rather be out of here,'' the blond-haired Nickman said calmly, adding, ``I miss my kids.'' In Brockton, Mass., Dennis Trundy, husband of Mary Trundy, whose twin brother is in Kuwait, said of the Iraqi statement: ``How do you react to that, it's just insane. This whole thing is mess. I dont know how they're going to get them out. I have a feeling it will come to a conflict. . . . They're not free to go.'' Mary Trundy's brother, 43-year-old John Stevenson, had been working as a computer systems analyst for a bank in Kuwait. For the Trundys the tense wait is familiar. In 1979 they waited several days as Stevenson escaped from Iran, just hours before militants took over the the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Stevenson had been working for a computer firm in Iran. ``It's like history repeating itself,'' Trundy said. Mrs. Cole, whose 50-year-old husband John Henry Cole is among the detainees, said she has two sons in the Army, one on his way to Saudi Arabia and the other on standby, and a son-in-law in the Air Force who's also on standby. ``I'm worried to death,'' she said. ``I've known they were serious all along. This has been serious since the day it started, because you have to remember who you're dealing with.'' A tearful Marjorie Walterscheid of Jacksboro, Texas, said she is very upset about the statement, but it hasn't changed her opinion about the outlook for her husband Rainard Walterscheid, 52. ``Well, I don't know that it's made a big change in my attitude because I've considered them hostages from the beginning,'' she said. ``I'm angry today, because there hasn't been anything done to get them out. I want my husband out without bloodshed. I think it should have been negotiated. ``I want my husband home. I have loved this country for 49 years, and I think my country should love me enough to bring my husband home.'' Even before Saturday's announcement, people like Patricia Heath of Farmington Hills, Mich., were getting pessimistic. Her brother, Kevin Bazner, his wife, Dawn, and their children, Elizabeth, 6, and David, 6 months, were stranded after their plane stopped in Kuwait to refuel during the Aug. 2 invasion by Iraq. After Iraq announced Friday that it was detaining the Americans, along with citizens of other Western countries, Heath was dismayed. ``When I first heard that, I was real negative and it was probably the worst day I've had,'' Heath said. ``This is the hardest thing. Up to this time, we knew their routine and now that is gone, we don't know where they are,'' said Virginia Bazner, Kevin and Patricia's mother, from her home in Palms Desert, Calif., home. ``Our strength is beginning to wane, but we've got to remain strong.''

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Alaska-Inspired Oill Cleanup Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday signed a bill, prompted by the Alaska oil spill, setting tougher standards for ship construction and authorizing a $1 billion fund to cover cleanup costs and damages not paid by the spiller. Bush complained that the measure contained a `highly objectionable'' moratorium on exploration for oil and natural gas off the coast of North Carolina's Outer Banks. ``Such a moratorium is ill-advised in view of recent events in the Persian Gulf where I have found it necessary to deploy American soldiers 7,000 miles from home to protect our vital national interests,'' the president said. He said his administration would seek repeal of the ban. Saying that gas exploration carries little environmental risk, Bush said, ``It is shortsighted to restrict exploration for this relatively clean energy source.'' The bill, spurred toward passage by the 11-million-gallon spill by the Exxon Valdez in Alaska, requires double hull construction of oil tankers and sets new crew licensing and manning requirements for oil ships. Bush said the act ``addresses the wide-ranging problems associated with preventing, responding to and paying for oil spills.'' ``It does so,'' he added, ``by creating a comprehensive regime for dealing with vessel and facility-caused oil pollution.'' The president said a $1 billion trust fund will be available to cover cleanup costs and damages not compensated by the spiller. However, he said the spiller's ``financial responsibility requirements are greatly increased.''

DOC.HEAD: Schoolboy Refugees from Nazism Reunited 52 Years Later
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, David ``Dufschi'' . . . CORRECTING second reference to Dufschi, not Duschi. Picks up 10th graf, The pact . . .
DOC.TEXT: In 1938, as Hitler's army swarmed into Vienna, 10 Jewish youngsters in their last year of high school met to say their goodbyes and made a pact. This was no ordinary class farewell, but a somber one against a backdrop of anti-Semitic violence and the knowledge that if they stayed, they were doomed. They knew they were about to become refugees, so they promised one another they would meet again if they survived. On Friday night they did. They traveled to London from homes in Australia, Israel, the United States and England to dine on champagne and Wiener schnitzel and resurrect long-forgotten childhood memories of soccer matches and Monopoly games at Affi Aufrichtig's house on Heinzelmanngasse, where they met for the last time. Each dinner place had a card with a nickname _ Affi, Dufschi, Kiwi, Mond _ and a yellowing photo, their last group portrait before they fled. One chair remained empty. Mandel ``Mandi'' Haber disappeared during World War II, his refugee boat apparently torpedoed by a German submarine. His name was by his plate all the same, at the head of the table. They were 70 years old now, with wives and grown-up children. They had been friends since the age of six, and still retained their old-world Central European manners and Viennese accents, laced with an American or Australian twang. Leo Sherwin fled to Shanghai, then settled in Melbourne, Australia. George Kane made it to Sydney, Australia. Ken Hurst, Ken Miller and Bert Binder reached England. Affi Aufrichtig, Otto Neugasser and Bobby Postman settled in Israel. David ``Dufschi'' Rosenbluth, now living in South Nyack, N.Y., didn't even know until last June that the others were still alive. ``I had completely lost track of them,'' he said. The pact stipulated a reunion outside the Tel Aviv post office on July 17, 1948, and the three who had reached Israel turned up. Then, through newspaper ads and the International Red Cross, others were gradually located. Finally, only Rosenbluth remained to be traced. Hurst finally tracked him down through the Austrian government pension fund, telephoned him in South Nyack and invited him to London. ``When Ken Hurst phoned me, all these things that I hadn't thought of for 50 years started coming back to me,'' he said, sitting in the Czechoslovak Club where the dinner was held. ``The street we lived on, where we went to the opera, to soccer games... And now it seems to me as though no time has elapsed at all, because I can see how they were, not how they are. They're still little boys.'' Hurst became a toolmaker, then a manufacturer of Christmas crackers. Sherwin was an electrician. Rosenbluth opened a watch-repair store in Manhattan, while his parents emigrated to Israel. Someone at the reunion remarked that Hitler was dead and the youngsters he had driven into exile had survived and prospered. Rosenbluth exclaimed: ``And we have a state!'' (Israel). ``It's great, unbelievable. Sometimes I just can't fathom the things that are happening,'' he said. Some of the men have visited Vienna since the war, but say they felt no connection to the place. Rosenbluth said he felt an undercurrent of anti-Semitism. Hurst went back in 1980, having been offered a job there. He revisited his old house, and the street where the Nazis forced him to clean graffiti off a sidewalk with a toothbrush. ``I felt like a stranger who spoke the language. I went to school and grew up there. But I just felt that I didn't belong,'' he said. After six weeks he moved back to England.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Pay Tribute To Slain Candidate
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Colombians marched in the streets of the capital Saturday to mark the anniversary of the assassination of a leading presidential candidate who was shot and killed by drug traffickers. The slaying of Luis Carlos Galan led to a major escalation in fighting between the government and the Medellin drug cartel. The fighting has claimed hundreds of lives. President Cesar Gaviria, who had served as Galan's campaign manager, attended a morning Mass Saturday along with his Cabinet and the slain candidate's family. Afterwards, thousands of people, many in tears, marched through downtown Bogota to the Central Cemetery where Galan is buried. Marches were planned in cities throughout Colombia. Radio stations said they would stop broadcasting for one minute at 7:45 p.m., the time Galan was killed by gunmen working for drug traffickers. Newspapers dedicated long articles and columns to the life and death of the assassinated leader. Galan was shot at a political rally near Bogota on Aug. 18, 1989. Polls indicated that the charismatic 46-year-old senator would have won a landslide victory in the presidential elections. Immediately following Galan's death, the government of former President Virgilio Barco began a major crackdown on drug traffickers. Since then, drug lords have killed about 500 Colombians, officials say. Among the dead were 200 police officers in Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, and two other presidential candidates. Gaviria has said his government will continue the hard-line stance Galan advocated against drug traffickers. Following Galan's death, the United States sent Colombia $65 million in emergency aid to fight cocaine smugglers. The assistance included 20 helicopters, bullet-proof vests and communications equipment. Authorities have said the government's anti-drug offensive has severely weakened the cartel. Security forces have seized some 41 tons of cocaine so far this year, compared to 33 tons during all of 1989. U.S. officials say the price of cocaine has risen dramatically, and supply is down. The government has extradited 22 suspected drug smugglers to the United States. Colombia's Medellin and Cali drug cartels supply an estimated 80 percent of the cocaine used in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: First Serviceman to Die in Saudi Arabia Remembered
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: WEST COVINA, Calif. _ The first U.S. soldier to die in the troop buildup in Saudi Arabia was remembered Saturday as a patriot and a peacemaker. About 300 people attended a funeral for Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi, who was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia last Sunday. Campisi, 30, was an aircraft mechanic at Offutt Air Force Base, Neb. ``He's the one we called the peacemaker. His patience and caring always got everyone through the hard and difficult times,'' said Mark Rizkowsky, a friend of Campisi's for 25 years and best man at his wedding. Another longtime friend, David Saldana, finished the eulogy when Rizkowsky, overcome with emotion, was unable to continue. He spoke of Campisi the career soldier and his dedication to the military. Monsignor Helmut Hefner told the mourners at St. Christopher Catholic Church that he hoped others would not die in the Persian Gulf. Iraq leader Saddam Hussein invaded neighboring Kuwait and vowed to wage a holy war against nations that intervene. ``We must not let some madman, who cries for holy war, as if there were such a thing as holy war, stampede us,'' Hefner said. Later, an honor guard saluted Campisi as he was laid to rest at Queen of Heavens Cemetery. After a bugler played taps, the American flag draped over the soldier's casket was folded and presented to his wife, Charlene, who wept as she stood arm-in-arm with her 9-year-old daughter, the eldest of their four children. Campisi was from West Covina, a Los Angeles suburb.

DOC.HEAD: 50,000 Turn Out For Pro-Democracy Rally in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: About 50,000 people cheered Saturday as pro-democracy activists called for the end of nearly two decades of one-party rule. It was the first such rally in 17 years. The rally was the biggest political gathering since Zambia's independence in 1964, organizers said. Pro-democracy leaders chose Kabwe for their first display of mass support because President Kenneth Kaunda's ruling party was founded in this provincial mining center 112 miles north of the capital, Lusaka. Frederick Chiluba, head of the powerful Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, told the thousands of cheering supporters that their presence showed that Kaunda's United National Independence Party had been abandoned by its followers. ``I have come to Kabwe with an open invitation to ask you to board the ship going to democracy,'' Chiluba said, holding up his index finger as the symbol of the multiparty campaign. ``The hour has come for you to divorce the one-party system,'' Chiluba said. More than 300 police and troops, some of them armed, surrounded the 5{-hour gathering, which dispersed peacefully. Organizers said scores of supporters were bussed to the rally from most parts of the country. In a carnival atmosphere, buses, trucks and cars heading to and from Kabwe honked their horns as drivers and passengers exchanged greetings. Chiluba and fellow officials of the National Interim Committee For Multiparty Democracy were carried shoulder-high by supporters who sang Zambia's national anthem. Many wore T-shirts bearing the heart-shaped legend ``I Love Multiparty.'' Addressing the rally, campaign chairman Arthur Wina, a former finance minister, accused Kaunda of bankrupting this southern African nation of 7.5 million people. Zambia ranks among the world's poorest countries. ``We are confident nothing can be worse than the present system,'' Wina said. Kaunda, 66, led the British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence. The colony was then renamed Zambia. One-party rule was imposed in 1973, and Kaunda has been unchallenged as president virtually ever since. In June, however, police opened fire on people rioting over a dramatic increase in food prices. At least 27 people died in the rioting, mainly in police and army gunfire. The bloodshed and price increases sparked demands for Kaunda's ouster. Kaunda responded by freeing political prisoners, ending a night curfew and allowing opponents to campaign for a referendum on Zambia's political future that is scheduled for next August. The pro-democracy committee is backed by trade union leaders, businessmen, students and former politicians. Kaunda has said he will campaign vigorously to maintain one-party rule and has accused pro-democracy activists of waging a political war against him financed by foreigners. Pro-democracy leaders have denied receiving foreign funds.

DOC.HEAD: Catalog Shopper Charged With Theft Over House Full of Orders
DOC.TEXT: A man caught up in a mail order frenzy used phony names to order about $200,000 worth of merchandise _ up to 50 boxes a day _ and simply threw the bills away, police said. Thomas J. Hoffmann, 35, used five post office boxes and 227 aliases to receive the catalog merchandise, said Sgt. Randy Crowe. He was charged Thursday with three counts of theft. Police recovered enough goods from Hoffmann's home and two storage rooms to nearly fill an 8,000-square-foot postal service warehouse, Crowe said. Sixteen officers spent six hours Thursday sorting through the orders so they could be returned. Among them were books, magazines, clothes, porcelain plates, globes, videotapes and more than 600 compact discs. ``He told us this was kind of something that snowballed on him,'' Crowe said. ``He did it for a little while and then he kept getting more packages in and he got to the point where he didn't know what to do with the stuff.'' Hoffmann placed his first order about a year ago, said Crowe. Packages poured in from about 60 companies across the country. Other charges were possible, but only three companies were verified as victims Thursday, Crowe said. Hoffmann was released Thursday night from East Baton Rouge Parish Prison on a $20,000 signature bond. The investigation began when one of the mail-order firms notified a postal inspector of a problem at one Hoffmann's post office boxes.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Keeps Mum on Stock Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Executives of the St. Petersburg Times said settlement of a stock dispute left them weighing a professional commitment to tell all against a corporate decision to keep mum. ``We may have to wrestle with the fact that we're being attacked for not doing what we wish we could do, but there it is'' Times Publishing chairman Andrew Barnes said. The Times Publishing Co. and a minority investor group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass announced on Friday the settlement of a bitter months-long stock feud involving the state's second-largest paper. The parties put out a joint statement on the agreement, but significant details were not addressed _ such as the amount of money exchanged and the percentage of ownership Bass maintains. In the three-page statement, they said they agreed not to comment further on terms of the settlement. Barnes told the newsroom Friday that most details of the settlement were kept secret and must remain so under the pact. ``It puts the Times, a newspaper that crusades for openness, in an awkward, even embarrassing position. But Barnes said this consideration is outweighed by something more important: ensuring the newspaper's independence,'' the Times reported Saturday. Both sides said they were pleased with the agreement, which Barnes said ensured long-term journalistic control of the newspaper. The Bass group, called the Poynter-Jamison Ventures Limited Partnership, dropped its federal suit. In return, the Times agreed to call in stock that was at the center of the dispute. The Bass group bought 200 shares in the paper's parent company, Times Publishing Co., two years ago from the nieces of the late Nelson Poynter, longtime publisher. The Bass partners sued the Times in February, claiming that their 200 shares, which represented 40 percent of the publishing company's common stock, brought only 6 percent of the company's dividends. Most of the publishing company's dividends have gone to the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, a not-for-profit journalism school set up by Poynter. The institute holds controlling interest in Times Publishing which owns the newspaper, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. Times attorney George Rahdert, who usually argues for openness on behalf of the newspaper, said he doesn't see where the secrecy agreement should have any bearing on the paper's pursuit of information about court settlements in other cases. ``I don't foresee this being a problem. This is a private business transaction,'' he said, adding that the company was not a public body. But clearly Rahdert didn't view the settlement as any big conquest for the Times. ``I wouldn't really characterize this as a victory,'' he said. ``It's a resolution of a thorny problem.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO CORRECT CATEGORY CODE
Pressure Builds for Quick German Unity
DOC.TEXT: Two West German political leaders on Saturday urged East German lawmakers to decide this week to merge with West Germany, saying overwhelming economic and political problems make quick action essential. ``Every day that it is delayed, the crisis is worsened and the costs of unity are driven upward,'' said Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, deputy chief of the Social Democratic faction in the West German Parliament. She told the West German newspaper Bild am Sonntag that the historic decision should be made when the East German Parliament meets on Wednesday. Erwin Huber, general secretary of the West German Christian Social Union, also said in an interview with the newspaper that his party supports rapid unity. Huber's party is the Bavarian sister party of the Christian Democrats of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The left-leaning Social Democrats are the second-largest party in the broad governing coalition of East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. The Social Democrats are the opposition in the West German parliament. The East Geman Social Democrats are to vote on Sunday whether to leave the coalition, following the latest of many threats it has made to break up the nation's first democratically chosen Cabinet. The Social Democrats are angry that de Maiziere unilaterally fired four Cabinet ministers on Wednesday. Even if the Social Democrats left his coalition, de Maiziere would still be able to run the government and German unity still would likely take place by year's end. All the major parties are committed to German unity and single German elections are tentatively set for Dec. 2. However, the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats of de Maiziere and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl still differ over a state treaty that is to spell out the details of a political merger and reconcile the differing laws of the nations. The two parties also have been trying to use the timing and pace of unification to their best political advantage. The prolonged political dispute has virtually paralyzed the unification debate. However, pressure appeared to be building Saturday for East Germany to end its political squabbling and move quickly on unification. Joblessness has been rising as East German factories struggle against competition from the West since the nation converted to a free market on July 1. United German elections are tentatively set for Dec. 2. Kohl failed in his attempt to get the elections moved up to Oct. 14, when East Germany is to hold state elections. East Germany must enact a clause in the West German Constitution in order to unify with West Germany. The Christian Democrats want unity and elections to take place almost simultaneously. The Social Democrats say they want unification to take place quickly but that it doesn't have to be tied to elections.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Study Suggests Race Influences Justice
DOC.TEXT: Killers and rapists whose victims were white got more severe punishment than those whose victims were black or Hispanic, in a newspaper survey of sentencing in Dallas County in 1988. A story in Sunday's Dallas Times Herald said a review of cases that year showed a conviction for the murder of a white person resulted in an average prison sentence of 30 years. That compared with 20 years for the murder of a black person and 12{ years for a Hispanic. The rape of a white resulted in a median sentence of 10 years, compared with two years for the rape of a black and five years for a Hispanic. The punishment almost doubled when the attacker and victim were of different races, the newspaper reported. Except for such interracial crimes, sentencing disparities were much less pronounced for attempted murder and aggravated assault, the newspaper said. David Baldus, an Iowa law professor who has studied race effects in death penalty cases, said the study suggests that white-victim crime, particularly rape, is treated ``quite differently'' in Dallas. Scott Anderson, president of the Dallas County Criminal Bar Association, was more blunt. ``The system's racist,'' he said. ``Most people are struggling to overcome it, but it exists. It starts all the way down in the police department and goes all the way to the top of the district attorney's office.'' District Attorney John Vance said Texas should follow the lead of Congress and 31 states that have reformed the sentencing process to eliminate unjustifiable disparities. ``I think we need to take a real serious look at the federal system (of sentencing guidelines), and that's the only time I've ever said that in my life,'' said Vance. Through plea bargaining, his office effectively sets punishment in more than 90 percent of such felonies. In the study, the Times Herald noted legal factors that affect punishment, including previous felony convictions, aggravating circumstances and multiple offenses punished by the same sentence. Judges, prosecutors and legal experts propose numerous theories for the sentencing inequities, including the quality of legal aid for indigent defendants, the reluctance of minorities to testify, and jury-imposed sentencing. A University of New Mexico sociologist who has studied the criminal justice system's handling of rape says the unequal punishment in cases involving black and white victims is a vestige of slavery days. ``At one point in our history, rapes were treated differently by law if a black man raped a white woman. And I think you still have lingering effects of that,'' said Gary LaFree, author of the 1989 book ``Rape and Criminal Justice.'' State District Judge Pat McDowell said the victim's social status also was a factor in sentencing. ``A prosecutor can make a much stronger argument in favor of severe punishment when the victim is an upstanding, contributing member of the community, than he can if the victim is a street person,'' McDowell said. ``It really shouldn't be that way,'' he said. ``But unfortunately, that's part of our society.'' Jury sentencing disparities reflect ``the kind of jurors we have in Dallas County,'' said lawyer Adelfa B. Callejo. ``Subconsciously, I think the attitude is that the life of a white person is worth more than the life of a black or Hispanic,'' she said. ``But it's not just in the courts; it's apparent in every aspect of life in Dallas.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Oil Minister Indicates Output Increase
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia is ready to increase its oil output by up to 2 million barrels a day to help offset the world shortfall caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the oil minister indicated Saturday. Oil Minister Hisham Nazer told a news conference in Jiddah that his country would have ``no alternative'' but to increase oil production unilaterally if OPEC does not convene an emergency meeting requested by Saudi Arabia. If the OPEC session fails to get off the ground, ``then it will be left for each member state to decide alone'' on the increase in output, he told the Western and Saudi journalists. ``Immediately means immediately,'' he said when asked how long the Saudis will wait for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to schedule a meeting. He said that Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, could increase its output by up to 2 million barrels a day within days. But he said Saudi Arabia alone cannot make up for the 4 million barrels of oil a day that international markets lost by the removal of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. By invading and annexing Kuwait, Iraq gained control of about 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, and the withdrawal of its crude from the market has caused oil and gas prices to soar. Most nations have declared support for U.N. sanctions against Baghdad, including an oil embargo. Nazer said Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates each could increase output by 500,000 barrels a day, but ``this would leave us with 1 million barrels less.'' In Georgetown, Guyana, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez told reporters Friday he favors convening an OPEC meeting soon, but did not indicate when it might take place. He said OPEC has an obligation to maintain stability in the oil market. Nazer said the Saudis are awaiting responses to their request for an OPEC meeting. He criticized some OPEC members such as Nigeria which have resisted holding another meeting less than a month after the oil exporters' last session in Switzerland. The last meeting on July 26-27 in Geneva came after Iraq accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the market with oil and driving down prices. At that meeting, OPEC fixed a production ceiling of almost 22.5 million barrels a day for the 13 member nations to defend a $21-a-barrel price. Saudi Arabia agreed to a production quota of 5.38 million barrels a day. Nazer commented, ``Now this has all been changed. The price now stands at $28 per barrel, and the daily production figure is far less than 22.4 million. The shortage of 4 million barrels a day can increase if the tension continues. ``All OPEC members together should make up for this shortage. ``We will not let the Third World countries down, and so will increase production.'' Nazer said failure to stabilize oil prices and production would not only devastate developing nations, but also hurt OPEC in the long run. Less oil would lead to higher prices in the marketplace, trigger a recession among industrial nations, and spur them to develop alternative energy sources, he said. He suggested that the oil situation could improve if the United States and other industrialized countries open their strategic stockpiles to the market. The reporters were invited by the Saudi government to travel to the Red Sea city of Jidday, about 1,000 miles from where thousands of U.S. troops and other members of a multinational force are deploying on the Persian Gulf. Oil industry sources in Saudi Arabia told The Associated Press on Friday that the kingdom would increase its output. Saudi Arabia is the dominant OPEC state, with a quarter of known world reserves. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted that the OPEC session called by Saudi Arabia would convene Monday or Tuesday in Geneva. They did not say what might happen if not all OPEC members agreed to participate. Iraq has criticized Saudi Arabia for calling the meeting, saying the Saudis created the shortfall by blocking Iraqi oil exports from the trans-Saudi oil pipeline. In Saudi Arabia's first direct official comment, Nazer confirmed that his country had turned away two Iraqi tankers that tried to load oil from the pipeline terminal. He said it did so ``after the U.N. Security Council resolution on sanctions.'' Meanwhile, the turmoil in the Middle East, where thousands of U.S. troops are being deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack, continued to create havoc on world markets. Unleaded gasoline hit a record high Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as crude oil prices shot up and speculators kept betting that the Middle East standoff would curtail supplies. September wholesale unleaded gas futures soared to as high as 96.25 cents before settling at 95.97 cents per gallon, up 8.5 cents from Thursday's record close. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, finished up $1.27 at $28.63 per barrel. For the week, September crude rose $2.40 per barrel, while unleaded gasoline was up 16.5 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Fish Swim In Chicago Street As Midwest is Drenched
DOC.TEXT: Flooding and heavy rain swept Midwest states Saturday while rain was scattered in the East and the weather was generally mild in the West. Heavy rains were recorded in Minnesota, South Dakota, northern Nebraska, Indiana and Wisconsin. Tomah, Wis., got five to eight inches of rain late Friday and early Saturday, causing flooding that forced hundreds to leave their homes and threatened the Tonah Lake Dam on the Lemonweir River. Several large carp were seen swimming across the street at a Chicago office of the National Weather Service after nearly three inches of rain fell overnight, leaving a foot of water on Higgins Road. A small tributary of the Des Plaines river overflowed onto the road, the weather service said. Two to five inches of rain fell in west-central and southeastern Minnesota and across northern and east-central Indiana late Friday and early Saturday. Aberdeen, S.D., got a total of 3{ inches a rain Friday. Lake and Porter counties, in northwestern Indiana, were drenched early Saturday, with some areas reporting seven inches of rain. There was widespread flooding. Elsewhere around the country, rain was scattered along the Gulf and Atlantic coasts Saturday. A few thunderstorms were also over the upper Ohio Valley and the lower Great Lakes region. In the West, Washington, Oregon and Northern California saw scattered rain. Temperatures there were in the 60s and 70s. Dry weather prevailed elsewhere, with sunny skies in the Southwest and the central Mississippi Valley. Temperatures were generally in the upper 80s and 90s east of the Rocky Mountains Saturday, with temperatures near 100 degrees in the central Gulf Coast states. It was cooler from upper Michigan to the northern High Plains region, with afternoon readings in the the 50s and 60s. The low for the nation Saturday morning was 37 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Prisoner Says `Kuwait 15' Escaped Jail
DOC.TEXT: A Lebanese Shiite Moslem who claims he escaped from prison in Kuwait during the Iraqi invasion said Saturday that 15 convicted terrorists linked to kidnappers in Lebanon also fled from jail. A Shiite fundamentalist group, Islamic Jihad, which has been holding Americans Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland for more than five years, had demanded the release of the 15 prisoners in return for freeing the two Americans. The Lebanese who said he escaped, Abdel-Aziz Krayyem, said Saturday he was imprisoned in 1985 on charges of cooperating with the 15, mostly Iranian and Iraqi Shiites, convicted in the 1983 bombing of the U.S. and French embassies, as well as Kuwaiti installations. Krayyem said he was among 1,600 prisoners who overpowered their guards and escaped when they heard about the invasion. He said the 15 were among those who got out. ``I saw them climbing into taxicabs with Kuwaiti plate numbers,'' Krayyem said and the cars sped away. ``That's all I saw.'' However, the report could not be independently verified. Earlier, unconfirmed reports speculated that the 15 had either been taken to Baghdad or executed. Krayyem said he had no idea of the current whereabouts of the 15. He said he hid out for 10 days with Kuwaiti inmates who got their families to collect them after the jailbreak. The Lebanese Embassy issued a new passport for him and he joined a car convoy sponsored by the embassy that passed through Saudi Arabia, then Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, he said. Krayyem, 35, arrived Friday in his hometown of Yater, 56 miles south of Beirut. He said he was first jailed for a few days with the convicts, then numbering 17, before he was placed in isolation at Kuwait's central prison. Two of the 17 original prisoners were released in February 1989 after serving five-year sentences. The Kuwaitis refused to free any of the others before completion of sentences, most ranging to 15 years. Kuwait's emir had not signed several death sentences, effectively commuting them to life. Kuwaiti interrogators linked Krayyem to the 15 for having explosives in his house but he said he was framed. ``Believe me I had nothing to do with them,'' he Krayyem said Kuwaiti prison guards told the inmates about the invasion. ``Chaos broke out immediately and the prisoners started shouting at the guards. The guards fired at them, killing an Iraqi and an Afghani prisoner,'' Krayyem said. ``After a few hours of fighting with the guards, the prisoners were able to occupy the prison and overthrow the guards,'' he said. There are 14 Western hostages held in Lebanon, including six Americans. The longest held is Anderson, 41, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.
