Iraq Accuses United States of Firing on its Tankers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 15 grafs to ADD details from military sources in Dubai, including name of second U.S. Navy frigate, number of shots fired, background, Iraqi ships under surveillance; pickup 8th graf pvs `Chalabi said...'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. warships fired shots in an effort to stop two Iraqi tankers Saturday, the first such confrontation in the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraq warned of ``grave consequences'' if it happens again. The United States said the gunfire involved only warning shots, but Iraq said U.S. ships had shot at the Iraqi vessels. Also Saturday, Iraq called the economic embargo against it an ``act of war'' and said thousands of foreigners it holds will go hungry along with Iraqis. The embargo was imposed in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Baghdad also threatened to use weapons of ``mass destruction'' against any attackers. The weapons were not specified, but Iraq has chemical weapons and long-range missiles. In the confrontation on the high seas, Oil Minister Issam Chalabi said U.S. warships had fired on two Iraqi oil tankers: the Baba Karkar in the Persian Gulf and the Khanaqin in the Gulf of Oman. A U.S. administration source with President Bush in Kennebunkport, Maine, confirmed U.S. forces had fired to stop two Iraqi ships, one in the Persian Gulf and the other in the Gulf of Oman to the south. In each case, ``warning shots were fired after bridge-to-bridge communications,'' the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The shots were the first fired in the 2-day-old interdiction effort ordered by Bush to halt goods leaving and entering Iraq. Military sources in Dubai, the United Arab Emirates, said the two incidents occurred about an hour apart around dusk. The two 3,600-ton guided-missile frigates involved, the USS Reid and USS Robert G. Bradley, are both part of the Navy's regular Gulf task force and had been on duty in the region before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The two ships also saw service escorting U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tankers in 1987-88 during the Iraq-Iran war. A U.S. Navy official who briefed reporters traveling with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that in the Gulf of Oman incident, the Reid fired warning shots across the bow of an Iraqi oil tanker. The official said U.S. forces briefly went to battle stations during the incident. The Khanaqin, which was loaded with oil, refused repeated requests to halt, and the Reid fired six warning shots across the tanker's bow, the military sources said. The weapon used could not be immediately confirmed, but was believed to be the 76mm gun located amidships on the top deck, the sources said. In the next incident, the USS Robert G. Bradley, homeported in Charleston, S.C., intercepted another Iraqi tanker inside the Persian Gulf and fired three warning shots across its bow when it refused to stop, the sources said. ``Both tankers are continuing under way, but are under close U.S. surveillance,'' said a U.S. military official on condition of anonymity. U.S. military officials have indicated that if Iraqi ships ignored warnings to stop, the next move might be to attempt to disable them by shooting at their rudders or propellers. Chalabi said the shots came after the ships refused to allow themselves to be searched, according to a statement carried by the official Iraqi news agency. He said the shots did not strike the ships and they proceeded without stopping. ``The Oil Ministry of the Iraqi republic therefore warns that any interception of its tankers and their crews will result in grave consequences which the American authorities bear responsibility for,'' he said. The threat that foreigners held in Iraq would suffer the same shortages of food as the Iraqi public came in a statement from the ministry of labor and social affairs, also carried by the Iraqi news agency and monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait after the invasion. Iraq singled out the United States for the blame in blocking food supplies, accusing Washington of going beyond the mandatory U.N. sanctions in denying Iraq food and medicine and in acting militarily to prevent shipments. ``Such an act by international law is known as an act of war,'' said the Iraqi statement. The Iraqis said the blockade would deny children their milk, medication and other necessities, and said foreign children would be subject to the same restrictions. ``We have decided to place the children of foreign families which Iraq has decided to host in equality with the children of Iraq and ... what affects the children of Iraq will equally affect them,'' said the statement. Iraq said its military would be given priority in the distribution of supplies because they are ``the shield of the nation.'' The latest statement came a day after the Iraqi parliament speaker, Sadi Mahdi Saleh, said the foreigners would be held as long as the threat of war persists. A multinational force of thousands of troops, spearheaded by the United States, was deployed in Saudi Arabia to defend it against possible Iraqi attack in the wake of the invasion. ``The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' the Iraqi official said then. The Iraqi government later said the statement did not apply to Egyptians. More than 1.5 million Egyptians make up the bulk of guest workers in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz warned that Arabs could follow a U.S. precedent to intercept shipping, and hinted at a blockade of the Red Sea. About 10 percent of the world's oil flows through the sea up to the Suez Canal. Yemen, which controls the Mandab straits at the southern end of the Red sea, is sympathetic to Iraq. Traffic through the Suez Canal, the other end of the Red Sea from the Mandab straits, averages 50 ships daily. About one third of the annual traffic is oil tankers, both from the Persian Gulf and eastern Saudi ports. The oil going through the canal counts for about 10 percent of the world's seaborne oil trade. The threat regarding use of weapons on mass destruction came in the Iraqi army daily newspaper al-Qaddasiyah. It said ``weapons of mass destruction and strategic deterrence possessed by Iraq will be lying in wait to turn those who contemplate committing aggression into scattered pieces.'' Iraq has used poison gas against Iran during their eight-year war and against its own Kurdish minority.

According to prosecutors, the woman was jogging through the northern end of the park at about 10 p.m. at night when she was attacked. DOC.HEAD: Text of Statement from Iraqi Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs
DOC.TEXT: This is a statement issued Saturday by the Iraqi Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs. It was monitored and translated by The Associated Press: In light of the decision taken by the representatives of the Iraqi people and announced by the president of the National Council yesterday, which asserted that the Iraqi people are a peaceful people who want peace and refuse war and those who call for it, and in light of the fact that the Iraqis have not attacked the West and its legal interests, and because some Western countries have declared enmity to the Iraqi people through U.S. provocation, and because the U.S. and whoever cooperates with her are pushing towards war against Iraq, in addition to its occupation of Arab land and the sanctities of the Moslems in Hijaz and Najd (Saudi Arabia), and because the presence of Westerners in Iraq is probably one of the means which will achieve peace and prevent aggression and war and make the American president and his allies reconsider their aggressive policies, therefore the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs announces the following: 1) America and its allies have surpassed the economic boycott which in its core means no exchange of buying or selling only. Instead, they proceeded with applying an economic seige by military force against Iraq, which includes food and medication. And such an act by international law is known as act of war, and has led and will lead to a shortage in imported food and goods including children's milk. And because the children of the world are beloved of God and of Saddam Hussein and in compliance with our humanitarian principles, we have decided the following: To place the children of foreign families which Iraq has decided to host in equality with the children of Iraq and if the children's milk, medication and other necessities should become scarce due to the boycott, what affects the children of Iraq will equally affect them (foreign children). 2) Due to the circumstances of boycott and economic seige which have been imposed by the United States by military means, food will not be available to all adults in the amounts we would wish. The peoples of Europe, in particular the British, have gone through such an experience or something resembling it before. Therefore they understand the circumstances and the arrangements. It's natural in such a situation to give priority in terms of quality and quantity of food to the armed forces because it is the shield of the nation and the people against aggression and to the workers in war-related factories and industries and give others a different level of attention. Also because foreigners will not be in the armed forces or any of the activities related to that, therefore their share of food in terms of quality and quantity with other Iraqis will be affected by our import of food in one way or the other. 3) Based on number 2 and in order to ensure the level and quantity of food needed for both foreigners and Iraqis, the right solution is to put an end to the sanctions which the United States have imposed on Iraq and the economic siege which (President) Bush and his allies are working on implementing by military force and in an individual manner and as a fast and advanced procedure not to boycott everything related with food, medication and goods of humanitarian nature. We call on families of foreigners in Iraq and all those who are in solidarity with them, humanitarian societies in the West and the world to raise their voices to achieve these noble humanitarian goals. May God bless those who call for peace and love and refuse war and aggression.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Aug. 2.
DOC.TEXT: In its latest statement Saturday, Iraq made clear that it hopes to use those foreign captives to force the lifting of economic sanctions imposed on it it and to prevent U.S.-led forces from invading Kuwait or Iraq. Saturday's statement, which referred to the U.S. quarantine as a ``blockade'' and ``an act of war,'' said that as food and medicine become scarce in Iraq, supplies will be set aside for the military, Iraq's ``the shield of the homeland.'' The statement referred specifically to U.S. military moves to enforce the international embargo on Iraqi goods and oil. Bush has authorized the interdiction of shipments to Iraq, a move that has drawn criticism from some U.S. allies and also from U.N. Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar, who approved the economic sanctions. The United States has refused to use the word ``blockade.'' Iraq, which imports three-quarters of its food, suggested in the statement that foreigners whose countries have experienced wars in the past will understand the Iraqi decision to reserve needed supplies for its military. ``The peoples of Europe, in particular the British, have gone through such an experience, or something resembling it, before,'' said the statement, which was carried on Iraqi telvision and read by an unidentified announcer. Children and the elderly among the foreign nationals would feel the effects of shortages along with their Iraqi counterparts, it said. ``Because of the embargo, food cannot be secured for aged persons in the manner that we wish,'' the statement said. ``If there were to be any reduction in the necessities of babies, then the same calamity affecting the Iraqi newborn will affect similarly the foreign babies.'' ``The right solution is for the embargo to end which the United States deliberately imposed on the Iraqis,'' the statement said. The White House said on Saturday that Iraq's holding of American and other foreign citizens is ``totally unacceptable.'' Bush, who was vacantioning in Kennebunkport, Maine, called on Iraq to immediately reconsider its refusal to let the foreigners leave. ``The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``We urge that Iraq immediately reconsider its refusal to allow any foreign national desiring to leave to do so without delay or condition,'' he said. Britain called Iraq's threat to detain Westerners ``unlawful and inhuman'' and said it would not be deterred from helping defend Persian Gulf states against Iraqi aggression.

DOC.SECOND: Defendants Found Guilty of Rape and Assault In Jogger Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new details, tightens; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers were convicted Saturday of raping and assaulting a woman jogger who was brutalized and left for dead in Central Park by a marauding gang of youths. The defendants _ Antron McCray, 16, Yusef Salaam, 16 and Raymond Santana, 15 _ were found innocent of sodomy and of attempted murder, the most serious charge in the much-publicized case. The 30-year-old jogger was found lying senseless in a pool of blood after the April 19, 1989, attack. In a coma for two weeks, she later recovered and returned to her job as an investment banker. The case engendered enormous local concern for the victim, who hasn't been publicly named. The defendants' supporters demonstrated outside the courthouse regularly, charging racism because the victim was white and wealthy, the youths black. Prosecutors said the three defendants were part of a gang of as many as 30 youths who rampaged through the park, harassing at least nine people. Three other teen-agers charged in the assault on the woman are free on bond. Salaam, McCray and Santana also were convicted of charges stemming from an attack on two male joggers in the park. The three were ordered remanded to jail without bail. Each faced from to five to 10 years in prison on the rape count alone. They were to be sentenced as juvenile offenders on Sept. 11. The woman was jogging through the northern end of the park when she was attacked. She was dragged about 70 feet into the woods, gang-raped and bashed repeatedly with a brick and pipe. She battled back from her near-fatal injuries, returned to work and to jogging within eight months of the attack, and is currently a vice president for Salomon Brothers, a Wall Street firm. The jogger trial had become controversial for unexpected reasons. While the woman's recovery from near-total paralysis was inspirational to some New Yorkers, a few activists, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, claimed police had arrested the youths because they were black. The defense attorneys said Salaam and McCray had made their videotaped confessions under duress. The defendants showed no emotion at all when the verdict was read. The jurors looked tired and haggard on their 10th day of deliberations. Earlier Saturday, the jurors had asked for the fourth time since they began deliberations to see the videotaped statement of McCray, in which he told police he kicked the jogger and feigned sex with her to impress his friends. McCray's father, Bobby McCray, testified he had encouraged his son to give false testimony of his involvement because he was led to believe there was an agreement. The detective who took the testimony said no such deal was offered. Another detective testified that Santana told him he counted 33 youths who entered the park shortly after 9 p.m. on the night of the attack to ``beat up and rip off joggers and cyclists.'' When the group saw the female jogger on her nightly six-mile run, ``We all charged her,'' McCray said on the videotape. She struggled and screamed as several teens dragged her from the paved drive down a wooded slope into the darkness, he said. The defendants told detectives the naked woman was struck with a metal pipe, bashed in the head and face with a brick, cut on the legs with a knife and sexually attacked in a frenzy of violence, assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer said. The rampaging youths went on to attack several other people _ teacher John Loughlin, hospitalized for two days with his injuries; banker David Lewis, who escaped serious injury because of his speed; and John Goode, a British Airways employee who was punched. Medical workers testified the woman had lost about three-quarters of her blood by the time she arrived at a hospital. She spent two weeks in a coma, a doctor said, and later was transferred to a Wallingford, Conn., rehabilitation center.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Pearl Bailey Won Hearts With Song, Love
LaserPhotos NY9, NY10
DOC.TEXT: Pearl Bailey was 15 when she sang ``Poor Butterfly'' in an amateur contest and won a $5 prize. She went on to win the hearts of millions as a singer, actress and America's ``ambassador of love.'' Bailey, 72, died at a Philadelphia hospital Friday night. ``She was a rare Pearl,'' her road manager E.B. Smith said Saturday. Bailey was known for playing matchmaker Dolly in the black version of the musical ``Hello, Dolly!'' on Broadway from 1967 to 1969. Others loved her throaty, expressive versions of ``Bill Bailey, Won't You Please Come Home,'' ``St. Louis Blues,'' ``Row, Row, Row,'' and ``That's Good Enough for Me.'' But Bailey's favorite role was that of ``ambassador of love'' and special delegate to the United Nations, where she could spread her warmth to the world. ``You may agree or disagree, but most of all, I think we love, and we're never quite sure why we love or how we love,'' she said in an interview in July. ``We just love. And that's it.'' ``The entertainment world has lost one of the most creative performers of our time,'' said Carol Channing, who played Dolly on Broadway in 1964. ``Her talent was unique and enduring and her warmth was felt by everyone in the audience.'' Her co-star in ``Hello, Dolly!,'' veteran song-and-dance man Cab Calloway, said, ``I have lost one of the greatest friends I've ever had in my life. From Philadelphia, Pearl Mae Bailey's career took her to music halls in small Pennsylvania coal towns, and then to vaudeville, Broadway, movies and television. She performed with some of the greatest singers, dancers and comedians of her time. Bailey had returned to Philadelphia in July for surgery to replace an arthritic knee. Officials at Pennsylvania Hospital said her surgery was without complications and her recovery was normal. She was staying at a hotel with her husband, jazz drummer Louis Bellson Jr., to undergo physical therapy and see her two sisters when she collapsed Friday night. She died later at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Kellyann McDonnell. The cause of death wasn't known and an autopsy was planned. She had a history of heart ailments. Bellson said Bailey was sewing a piece of needlepoint for one of her doctors when she said something was wrong with her hands. He said she asked him to call her doctor and the paramedics. Then, he said, ``the kind of look you never want to see'' crossed her face and she slumped in her chair, Bellson told the Philadelphia Daily News. ``I just lost my best friend,'' he said. Bellson said that although everyone was devastated by the death, it was important not retreat into a shell. ``It will be hard, but you just have to try and adjust to a new life. You have to keep on going while you're living, '' he said. ``I know Pearl would have wanted me to forge ahead and do what I want to do.'' Bailey had returned to Philadelphia for knee surgery at the recommendation of her friend, publisher Walter H. Annenberg, former U.S. ambassador to Britain. Annenberg told The Philadelphia Inquirer that the singer was in ``great spirits'' when he saw her after the surgery. ``She was dancing around the room to show me how successful it was,'' he said. ``She wanted to get back to her work at the United Nations.'' In 1970, President Nixon named her America's ``ambassador of love'' to the world. She was a special delegate to the United Nations under the Ford, Reagan and Bush administrations. ``Pearl Bailey was the mother of the world,'' said Stan Irwin, her manager for 25 years. ``She was a very spiritual woman and she never recognized color. Her ideology was, `We are humans.''' Songwriter Sammy Cahn said Bailey was unique. ``She came as advertised. When you said Pearl Bailey, it was a spirit, a talent,'' he said. Bailey's direct and forthright manner carried over to her throwaway style of singing. ``I'm more of a philosopher than a jazz singer,'' she said in a June interview with The New York Times. ``When people say, `Pearl, where did you get your style?' I tell them: `I have no style. I just sing songs.''' On Broadway, she appeared in ``House of Flowers'' and ``Bless You All,'' and enjoyed a long film career, with her movies including ``Carmen Jones'' and ``Porgy and Bess.'' The entertainer also wrote humorous and inspirational books, including ``Raw Pearl,'' ``Talking to Myself'' and ``Between You and Me.'' Born in Newport News, Va., on March 29, 1918, she was the daughter of a minister and the youngest of four children. She moved with her family as a child to Washington and later to Philadelphia. In 1979, she moved from California with her husband of 38 years to the Arizona resort community of Lake Havasu City in 1979. Funeral arrangements were incomplete Saturday night. Smith, Bailey's road manager, said she would be buried in Philadelphia, near family members, Wednesday or Thursday. She also is survived by a son, Tony, and a daughter, Dee Dee.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Announces Official Deployment of Carrier Group
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy and its accompanying battle group have been deployed to the eastern Mediterranean, the Navy announced Saturday. The Navy issued a formal statement confirming earlier acknowledgment from Pentagon sources that the Kennedy, which left Norfolk on Wednesday, was being dispatched to the Middle East. Navy spokesman Maj. Tom Johnston said the Kennedy battle group had conducted training maneuvers off the Virginia coast since leaving port. The battle group includes the cruisers USS Mississippi, USS San Jacinto and USS Thomas S. Gates and the combat stores ship USS Sylvania, all based here. Also with the Kennedy are the destroyer USS Moosbrugger, based in Charleston, S.C.; guided missile frigate USS Samuel B. Roberts, based in Newport, R.I; and fast combat support ship USS Seattle, homeported in Earle, N.J. The Navy also said Saturday that the USNS Denobola, the last of the Navy's eight Fast Sealift Ships, would bring equipment to support operation Desert Shield in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Search Crews Find Utah Attorney General After Nine Hours On Salt Lake
DOC.TEXT: Utah Attorney General Paul Van Dam and a friend were stranded overnight on the Great Salt Lake after their sailboat capsized in rough water, authorities said Saturday. Van Dam and Harvey Van Soolen, 50, were found before dawn Saturday atop a capsized 22-foot sailboat, said county sheriff's Capt. Mike Wilkinson. They had spent about nine hours waiting for help and were ``just real cold and wet,'' he said. The men's wives reported them missing Friday night. About two dozen search and rescue team members and state parks workers joined the search. Van Dam and Soolen set sail under clear skies, but got caught in a thunderstorm Friday night that brought rain, rough surf and high winds to northern Utah, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rival War Bands Battle as Army Deployed to Halt Battle
LaserPhoto JOH2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 20th `No other...' to ADD demonstration elsewhere; pickup graf 21 `The ANC....' NOTE CONTENTS
DOC.TEXT: War bands battled with axes, spears and knives and ritually mutilated the bodies of their enemies Saturday as the death toll from a week of tribal fighting rose to at least 222. Hundreds were injured. Fighting flared in parts of Soweto and Tokoza townships when large groups of heavily armed Xhosas tried to attack hostels housing migrant Zulu workers. Zulus fought back with guns and sharp-edged weapons and went on a rampage in Tokoza, driving off the attackers. ``We were just drinking and being happy,'' said a Zulu called Steven, who was armed with two spears and a cowhide shield. ``They came to kill us. They want to drive us out, but we will kill them.'' The government ordered troops into the townships to support police in trying to halt the fighting. Police and soldiers in armored vehicles fired tear gas and shotguns to break up clashes. Lines of police vehicles drove between rival groups to keep them apart. The fighting appeared to have developed primarily into a tribal battle. Earlier clashes had pitted Xhosas of the African National Congress and Zulus of the more conservative Inkatha movement, but many township residents said people who did not belong to the two groups were fighting along tribal lines. The bloody conflict erupted last Sunday in Tokoza, east of Johannesburg, and spread during the week to four more areas, including Soweto, southwest of Johannesburg. The fighting is the worst in the townships in years, local press reports say. Police officials said at least 222 people had been killed, but the toll probably was higher because some bodies had been removed before police could count them. Zulus at Tokoza ritually castrated the bodies of dead Xhosas and cut off hands, waving the severed parts in victory dances. Zulus believe mutilation robs enemies of their strength and makes the victor stronger. A mob of about 1,500 Zulus in Tokoza beat their axes and spears against shields, chanting war cries. Police in armored vehicles surrounded the fighters to keep them from attacking nearby Xhosa houses. The country's top police official, Gen. Johann Van Der Merwe, announced the deployment of soldiers and more police. ``This strong contingent will do everything possible to stop the senseless violence,'' he said in a statement. But officials would give no details on how many troops were being deployed. ``We will kill the Xhosas! They are rubbish _ we will kill them all!'' declared Richard Zulu, leader of a war band. Xhosas were demanding that all Zulus leave the townships, claiming they had no right to live there and should return to their native Natal Province. They blamed Zulus for starting the fighting. A terrified Xhosa youth armed with several iron bars said, ``We must protect ourselves or they will kill us.'' In Soweto, police with assault rifles and shotguns roared through streets in armored vehicles and trucks. Youths who erected barricades with rocks and burning car tires were dispersed with tear gas. A Soweto city councillor was killed by a mob outside his house Saturday, police spokesman Lt. G. Mariemuthoo said. The man, identified as T.A. Nkina, had his throat slit when he confronted the crowd with a firearm, the police spokesman said. Black officials are seen as turncoats who support the white-led government. Also Saturday, thousands of black protesters marched through the conservative northern Transvaal town of Welkom, and police reported one marcher injured by a crossbow shot. The march was to protest high rents and lack of civic services. No other incidents were reported as the estimated 5,000 marchers walked, danced and sang past police roadblocks and vehicles set up to protect them from threatened violence by right-wing whites. Also Saturday, about 20,000 people marched peacefully through the town of Vereeniging, near Johannesburg, to protest political violence. The African National Congress and Congress of South African Trade Unions organized that march. The ANC accused the government's security forces of plotting to use Inkatha to stir up tribal rivalry in the townships around Johannesburg. More than 5,000 people have died in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in the eastern Natal province in the past five years. Inkatha President Mangosuthu Buthelezi said ANC supporters insult and attack Inkatha members, causing conflict. Many Zulus involved in the fighting in the townships said they would not accept the ANC and its leader, Nelson Mandela, as a future government. Mandela has been negotiating with President F.W. de Klerk on clearing the way for a new constitution to give political power to South Africa's black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Army Asking Medical Reserves to Voluntary for U.S. Hospital Duty
DOC.TEXT: The Army is asking reserve doctors to work in military hospitals around the nation to replace active-duty staff sent to the Middle East, officials said. A severe shortage of medical personnel in Army hospitals prompted the offer, the Los Angeles Times, quoting an unidentified source in Washington, D.C., reported Saturday. The Army asked the reservists to list three hospitals where they would prefer to work, although officials will not guarantee where they would be sent. By volunteering to work for three months to a year in a U.S. hospital, the doctors, nurses and other medical workers could avoid going to the Middle East if President Bush calls up medical reserves later. Army Reserve administrators in Santa Ana, San Bernardino and Riverside began calling about 120 medical personnel on Thursday, asking them to decide within 24 hours if they would work at an Army hospital in the United States. ``What we're doing is developing a contingency plan in the event that the Army medical staff is used up and moved out to the Middle East,'' said Walter Shelton, staff administrator at the 6252nd Army Hospital in Ventura, which oversees local medical reserve units. Shelton said the response has been positive so far, but he declined to say how many people have signed up. One Orange County nurse, who asked that she not be identified, said she decided to accept rather than risk being sent overseas later. ``The thought of winding up somewhere far away, far from my family, is a real fear, and I'm just not sure I'm willing to take that chance,'' said the nurse, an Army reservist for 17 years.

DOC.HEAD: Fleeing From Lap of Luxury to Central Michigan
With AM-Gulf-Escape
DOC.TEXT: The servants at Michelle Tobin-Saud's four-story house in Kuwait City took care of the children while she managed her husband's million-dollar health club. A few days after Iraq invaded Kuwait, however, the family had to abandon everything but the Chrysler New Yorker they drove across the burning Sahara to Saudi Arabia. Tobin-Saud is back in the United States now with her three children, building a much more ordinary life after three years in the Persian Gulf. She plans to enroll the children, ages 2, 5 and 7, in Lansing-area public schools and wants to earn a teaching degree from Michigan State University. Her Kuwaiti husband, Jawad Saud, remains in Saudi Arabia but plans to rejoin the family. ``Kuwait was a paradise on earth,'' she said during an interview at her mother's apartment Friday in East Lansing. ``I was living like the cream of the cream. I was like an American princess.'' Tobin-Saud met her husband, a former Olympic gymnast, in 1981 at Michigan State University. They lived in the Lansing area for six years before moving to Kuwait, where he became a lieutenant colonel in the Kuwait City police academy, she said. Shortly after the Aug. 2 invasion, the family learned that Iraqi soldiers had the addresses of Saud and other Kuwaiti military personnel, she said. Two days later, she and her husband put their children in the car and left their luxurious home, spending a few days sleeping at different relatives' houses. ``When you go to bed at night, you think, `Should I sleep in the basement because of bombs, or should we sleep on the roof because of gas?''' she said. A week after that, running short on food and with the fighting still raging, the Sauds and about 15 other families decided to head for Saudi Arabia on a narrow, pebble-paved road. A wrong turn sent some of the vehicles into a sand pit. ``It must have been 140 degrees,'' Tobin-Saud said. ``The men couldn't push the cars because the sand burned through their shoes.'' A nomad happened along in a truck that he used to free the sinking vehicles. They reached the Saudi capital, Riyadh, after more than 24 hours of travel, she said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Helped Iraq's Chemical Warfare Program, Magazine Says
DOC.TEXT: East Germany helped Iraq develop a secret training ground for chemical warfare, a West German magazine reported Saturday. The Hamburg-based Spiegel magazine said East German army officers supervised construction of a training field that could be used for chemical, biological and atomic weapons. A training ground in East Germany was used as a model for building the top- secret Iraqi facility, Spiegel said in an advance copy of the magazine that will go on sale Monday. The magazine quoted an East German military officer as saying that Iraqi officers traveled to East Germany for consultations, but that East Germany had not delivered chemical weapons. In a separate development, West German police on Friday arrested seven men in connection with the alleged delivery of a poison gas plant to Iraq several years ago. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons in the past, both in the Iran-Iraq war and against Kurds in his own country. Officials in his government have threatened to use them against U.S. forces massing in Saudi Arabia. West German companies were involved in developing a suspected Libyan chemical weapons plant. In June, Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, head of the Imhausen-Chemie company, was found guilty of shipping materials for an alleged chemical weapons plant in Libya. He was sentenced to five years in prison. Prosecutors said earlier this month that Imhausen may have supplied plans for a second chemical weapons facility in Libya.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs AIDS Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Restores list of cities in grafs 7-8 to original as in a0601, which was ^correct as sent. ^By CHRISTOPHER CONNELL
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a $882 million AIDS emergency bill Saturday that for the first time will allow direct federal grants to 16 cities hit hardest by the deadly viral epidemic. Bush affixed his signature without public comment to the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency Act, named for the Indiana teenager widely admired for his courage in face of the disease that claimed his life in April. Congress will still have to pass a separate appropriations bill before any of the funds are distributed to states and cities. But it is the first law ever enacted to provide health grants to states and localities to fight a specific disease. AIDS is spread through the exchange of blood or body fluids or through contaminated needles. It has killed more than 83,000 Americans in the past decade, and an estimated 1.5 million Americans are believed to be carriers of the virus. Many of the victims have been homosexual or intravenous drug abusers. Children can contract the disease in the womb or through blood transfusions, as did Ryan White, a hemophiliac. The measure authorizes $882 million for fiscal 1991 and a total of $4.5 billion over five years. It would provide $275 million in health care service grants in fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1, to 16 major cities. They are: Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Fort Lauderdale, Houston, Jersey City, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Newark, Philadelphia, San Diego, San Francisco, San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Washington, D.C. To qualify, a city had to have at least 2,000 AIDS cases to date or a rate of 25 per 10,000 residents. The money will be allocated based on severity of need. States would also get formula grants to improve the delivery of health care services for people with AIDS. There would be separate grants to states and health care organizations for AIDS prevention efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Demonstrate Against U.S. Mideast Involvement
DOC.TEXT: About 30 people demonstrated Saturday outside City Hall to protest the American military buildup in the Middle East, which they characterized as a war to defend oil companies. ``Bush wants another war, we say no,'' the protesters chanted during the hour-long protest. Jerry Gorden, a spokesman for the Committee Against U.S. War in the Persian Gulf, said U.S. involvement in the region served the interests of oil companies and the wealthy. ``Exxon, Texaco, Gulf, Chevron and Mobil, that's who we're fighting for,'' he said. ``This whole thing is not about freedom, or protecting one country that was attacked by another, it's about oil. ... We don't want to shed a single drop of blood for oil.''

DOC.HEAD: Salvagers Near Mother Lode of One Wreck; Display Gold From Another
DOC.TEXT: Treasure hunters who have spent nearly five years dodging storms and pirates around the Bahamas say they finally may be on the trail of the ``mother lode'' from a sunken 17th century galleon. In the past few weeks, the crew of the Research Vessel Beacon have found dozens of valuable artifacts from the Spanish ship ``Nuestra Senora de las Maravillas,'' which was carrying a cargo worth $1.6 billion. Meanwhile, at another wreck site off the Florida coast, five rare gold ingots raised last week are part of the first big haul from what is believed to be a treasure-laden Spanish galleon from a 1622 fleet. The gleaming ``finger ingots,'' each weighing 1{ pounds, 11 silver coins, 15 ceramic containers, a pair of brass sextons and an emerald ring were among the treasures displayed Saturday. They were discovered during the first two weeks of intensive searching of the 1,500-foot-deep site using a remote-controlled robot. ``We've literally just scratched the surface of the wreck site,'' said Dan Bagley, a director of Seahawk Deep Ocean Technology, the company recovering the nameless wreck, which is about 25 miles south of the Dry Tortugas, west of Key West. In the Maravillas project, one investor said the latest discovery makes the long search worthwhile. Among the treasures recovered so far are nearly 80 gold coins, ivory daggers and a gold brooch decorated with 80 emeralds matching a similar piece found two years ago. ``The thrilling nature of this business certainly hits home when you get to hold an item that has been on the ocean floor for almost 335 years,'' said Gary Skeen. Project spokeswoman Corey Carlson said the crew made the discoveries in a previously unexplored area about 60 miles east of West Palm Beach. Team leaders believe they may be closing in on the main cargo from the Maravillas, which sunk in 1656 after colliding with another vessel. Items from the ship have been found since 1985, but the recent discoveries are the most valuable. ``We've been teased and teased for years,'' she said. ``It looks like we may finally hit the mother lode.'' Crew members speak in code on the radio and keep ``a small arsenal'' on board to guard against pirates, she said. ``We've seen boats anchored off the horizon and it's kind of suspicious,'' said Ms. Carlson. ``Pirates still exist and you have to be very careful.'' The treasures from the Maravillas are stored in a vault in Freeport, Bahamas. The Maravillas was carrying a cargo, valued at $1.6 billion in current prices, which could include artifacts such as a life-size Madonna and child of solid gold, said Beacon owner Herbert Humphreys Jr. of Memphis, Tenn. Some of the artifacts will be auctioned off in London on Oct. 3, he said. The project is funded by Humphreys' company, Marine Archaeological Recovery of the Cayman Islands, and Maritime Capital Group, headed by Jim Kollar and Skeen. The Bahamian government receives 25 percent of profits made from sales of the Maravillas artifacts.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Wait Longer Than Whites For Organ, Newspaper Finds
DOC.TEXT: Black patients wait an average of five months longer than whites for kidney transplants, a newpaper investigation has found. The federal government is investigating the disparity, which stems partly from the fact that most donor organs come from whites, The Pittsburg Press reported Sunday. Because of slight racial differences in blood type and antigens, donor organs are more likely to match those of the same race. Based on a review of 13,888 kidney transplants nationwide in 1988 and 1989, the newspaper found that black patients spent an average 14 months waiting for an organ. On average, white patients waited slightly less than nine months. The study included only transplants using organs from brain-dead donors, not living relatives. Whites accounted for 3,144 of the 3,802 kidneys donated last year in the United States, the newspaper said. It cited data from the United Network for Organ Sharing, of Richmond, Va., which has a government contract to control the national Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. ``We are very concerned about this variance, but we do, and have always, taken every possible safeguard to ensure that race never is an issue in the fair allocation of organs,'' said Dr. James Wolf, UNOS president and director of the kidney transplant program at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Because most kidneys come from white donors, characteristics of the white population appear more often in the donor pool. The pattern of blood types and antigens varies slightly among races, and hospitals always try to match donor to recipient as closely as possible to avoid rejection of a transplanted organ. The newspaper said its study corresponds to preliminary data developed during an investigation by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Although the report is not expected to be released until December, HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan has referred to the findings in speeches this month. Sullivan said the government report will show ``blacks were waiting twice as long as whites ... and these differences remain even when blood type, age, immunological and locational factors are taken into account.'' Details of the HHS investigation are incomplete, but it would call for a close inspection of the differences in waiting times that occur in the 230 hospitals doing kidney transplants nationwide, said Linda Sheaffer, director of the federal Office of Organ Transplantation.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Protocol Chief Traveling With Gorbachev Stayed Behind For Treatment
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's chief of protocol, traveling in the United States with Mikhail Gorbachev in June, remained behind for several weeks to treat a heart condition, a hospital said Sunday. Vladimir Shermyshev, 61, was admitted to Merritt Peralta Medical Center on June 11, discharged two days later and remained in the San Francisco Bay area for about two weeks before returning to the U.S.S.R., a hospital spokeswoman said. The hospital did not announce Shermyshev's stay at the time because of ``security reasons,'' said spokeswoman Gerrie Shields. Shermyshev, who arrived in the Bay area with Gorbachev's entourage on June 3, had been advised by his doctors to have heart bypass surgery. He sought a second opinion from Dr. Nilas Young, a heart surgeon at Merritt Peralta. Young was known to Soviet doctors for his involvement in a program by local doctors to help set up a children's cardiac center in Leningrad. Soviet doctors currently are incapable of surgery on children born with heart conditions. Shermyshev underwent cardiac catheterization, a testing procedure in which dye is fed into the arteries, and doctors here decided he didn't need surgery, Shields said. She said she believed Shermyshev stayed at the residence of the Soviet consul general in San Francisco when he wasn't in the hospital. Calls to the consul Saturday were not answered.

DOC.HEAD: Anxiety Grows As Iraq Says It Has Begun to Move Foreigners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 5th `On Saturday...' to ADD that children and elderly singled out by Iraq; pickup 6th pvs `Meanwhile, the...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: International anxiety grew Saturday over the fate of thousands of Westerners barred from leaving Iraq and occupied Kuwait, as Iraq said it had begun moving some of them to ``strategic'' locations around the country. Thomas R. Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said later Saturday that Iraq's actions make it clear that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is ``going to hold hostage all foreigners.'' U.S. officials had previously avoided using the word ``hostage'' to refer to the Americans and other foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq said Friday it was detaining citizens of ``aggressive countries'' and placing them in areas that would be likely targets in the event of a U.S. attack. On Saturday, Iraq also said the foreigners would suffer any shortages along with Iraqis. It singled out children and the elderly, saying they would endure hardship along with Iraqis. ``Because of the embargo, food cannot be secured for aged persons in the manner that we wish,'' the statement said. ``If there were to be any reduction in the necessities of babies, then the same calamity affecting the Iraqi newborn will affect similarly the foreign babies,'' said an official statement read on Iraqi television. Meanwhile, the exodus of foreigers, mostly Arabs, continued from Kuwait and Iraq. At the Jordanian border post of Ruweishid, officials reported that tens of thousands of Arabs were fleeing into Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait. One official there said 8,100 foreigners had crossed into Jordan by Saturday evening. He said those who had crossed were all Arab nationals, mainly Egyptians, except for 425 Poles and two Indians with British passports. Officials said a record 22,300 foreigners crossed the previous day. This was the largest number since the exodus began following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The White House said Iraq's holding American and other foreign citizens is ``totally unacceptable,'' and denounced the use of ``innocent civilians as pawns'' in Saddam's stand against international sanctions. Anxiety grew following the overnight announcement by Iraq's parliamentary speaker, Sadi Mahdi Saleh, that foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' would be kept in Iraq as long as the threat of war persisted. Mahdi said they would be housed in civilian and military institutions throughout Iraq. In an interview Saturday with Britain's Independent Television News, Iraqi Ambassador to France Abdul Razzak al-Hachimi said in Paris: ``Some of them ... have been distributed in strategic installations in Iraq starting all the way from north of Iraq to the south.'' The British Foreign Office said later it had confirmed that 40 Britons, five Americans, four Germans and one French citizen had been moved from Kuwaiti hotels to undisclosed locations. A department spokesman said Iraq had said the foreigners would get VIP treatment. On Saturday, Iraq also called the economic embargo imposed on it by the U.N. Security Council an ``act of war,'' and said the foreigners it holds will suffer along with Iraqis if shortages of food and medicine develop. Iraq imports about three-quarters of its food. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq invaded the small oil state. The Palestine Liberation Organization said Saturday in Tunisia that PLO chief Yasser Arafat had received ``formal assurances'' that foreigners would be safe and well treated. But it was not clear if that meant all foreigners or only Palestinians, nor was it clear who made the assurances. Britain called Iraq's threat to detain Westerners ``unlawful and inhuman'' and said it would not be deterred from helping defend Persian Gulf states against Iraqi aggression. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the Iraqi ambassador was called in ``to underline our grave concern and to relay to his authorities the need for immediate clarification.'' A West German Foreign Ministry spokesman said in Bonn Saturday his government felt ``great anxiety'' over the fate of 1,000 West German citizens in Iraq and Kuwait after Iraq said it would not let foreigners leave. In Paris, France summoned the Iraqi ambassador to warn that ``serious consequences'' would result if steps are not taken to protect the 560 French nationals in Iraq and Kuwait. No orders were given for French people in Kuwait to assemble at hotels, as were given on Thursday for Americans and British, a French source said. The Iraqi restrictions did not appear to refer to Soviet citizens. A group of 225 Soviet citizens from Kuwait were among the thousands who crossed into Jordan on Friday. The group was driven straight from the border to Amman's airport early Saturday and boarded a plane that left for Moscow. Italian newspapers said Saturday that more than 300 Italians in Iraq say they are being held against their will and appealed for help from Italy. Italy's state-run TV reported Saturday all the stranded Italians appeared safe and were free to move about in Baghdad and Kuwait City. Many foreigners _ Arabs and a few Westerners _ were fleeing across the Saudi border. Mohamed Al-Mashat, Iraq's ambassador in Washington, said in a CNN TV interview Saturday that all foreign nationals were ``safe and well-treated.'' ``I would protest the use of the term hostage,'' he said in response to a question. ``We call them our guests. ... The lives of Iraqis and foreigners are equal. Where is the humanitarian thing when you deny our children and babies the milk for their nourishment and livelihood?'' He likened Iraq's action to U.S. internment of Japanese descendants in World War II: ``It is a temporary measure because we are in a crisis.''

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Houses Evacuated in Wisconsin; More Rain Increases Flood Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with dam reinforced, gates opened, number of residents still evacuated; picks up 12th graf pvs, `Tomah police...'
DOC.TEXT: Waters subsided Saturday night after authorities opened the floodgates of a reinforced dam, but about 700 worried residents stayed away from their homes. They were among about 1,500 people evacuated earlier from 1,000 homes as flood waters threatened to rupture the Lake Tomah Dam on the Lemonweir River. The dam was reinforced with about 20,000 sandbags and its reservoir dropped eight inches by Saturday night after the floodgates were opened, said Tom Flock, fire chief of this central Wisconsin town. ``If we do get a downpour now, it should be able to hold it,'' he said. Dams down river at New Lisbon, Mauston and Lemonweir Mills would be endangered if the Tomah dam collapsed. Residents left their homes in Tomah after the city of about 7,000 received about eight inches of rain during a three-hour period Friday night, said Carleen Pearson of the Monroe County Police Department. About 300 were taken to a junior high school gymnasium, she said. Rain in the area stopped at about 6 a.m. but was expected to resume late Saturday into Sunday, said National Weather Service meteorologist Tom Helman. Early Saturday afternoon, water was flowing over the dam, said Tomah Alderman Wayne Johnson said. No deaths or injuries were reported in Tomah. No damage estimate was available. Tomah police Capt. Don Larson said the city's storm sewers couldn't handle all the extra water, and sewage backed up into several homes. The rains left the city in ``a mess,'' said Assistant Fire Chief Stu Westphall. A wing of Tomah Memorial Hospital was damaged by flooding, but no patients were endangered, officials said. The city's ambulance service, civil defense and police department all were involved in the evacuation, said Donette Gorbet of the Tomah Police. ``It's chaotic,'' she said. ``We're telling everybody to stay away from Tomah.'' Roads in central and southern Wisconsin flooded early in the day, with water forcing cars off the roads, officials said. A 25- to 30-mile stretch of state Highway 12-16 and parts of the 15-mile stretch of Interstate 90 between Oakdale and Sparta were closed, Ms. Pearson said. Other Wisconsin cities that got heavy rain in the 24 hours ending Saturday morning included Cobb, 5.5 inches; Eau Claire, 2.57 inches; Milwaukee, 2.18 inches; Wausau, 1.16 inches.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Accuse Cristiani of Involvement in Jesuit Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD byline; UPDATES with rebel letter accusing Cristiani of involvement in Jesuit slayings; rebel demand for U.N. monitoring of human rights; details and background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran rebels on Saturday accused President Alfredo Cristiani of involvement in the murder of six Jesuit priests. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front proposed a new commission be formed to oversee the murder investigation. The accusations were made in a letter released to reporters during a fourth round of talks between the government and the rebels aimed at achieving a cease-fire in El Salvador's civil war. The discussions were to center on rebel demands to reduce the size of the army and purge officers accused of human rights abuses, including the Jesuit killings. The rebels also have called for immediate U.N. monitoring of human rights in the country. The government has not yet responded to the rebel demand to give the United Nations such authority. Government officials have said discussions on the size of the army and a purge of officers should come only after a cease-fire. The 10-year civil war has cost more than 72,000 lives, most of them civilian. U.N. mediator Alvaro De Soto told reporters in San Jose that substantial progress could be made during the current round of talks, but he said the United Nations could not form a human rights verification commission immediately. ``A series of practical problems exists for installing the U.N. verification commission. ... While the required conditions aren't there, we prefer not to do it,'' De Soto said, without elaborating further. The six-day round of talks are scheduled to run through Wednesday. In the letter addressed to Cristiani, the rebels proposed a joint government-rebel commission to monitor legal proceedings in the Jesuit murder case and report its findings to both peace negotiators and the public. It said the fact the president acknowledged authorizing an army search of the priests' house before the slayings implicated him in the killings. Cristiani has acknowledged authorizing the search of the priests' home, but said it was considered standard procedure. The search took place three days before the killings and came during a major rebel offensive in San Salvador. The six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter were murdered on Nov. 16 at the University of Central America in San Salvador. Nine military men, including a colonel, were charged in connection with the killings, but none has come to trial. The letter said an application to search the priests' house reached Cristiani ``at the moment that the radio and television network of your government said that Father Ignacio Ellacuria should be eliminated.'' It said the search authorization ``implicitly defined him and his Jesuit companions as enemies to be eliminated.'' The rebels charged that the government's sluggishness in prosecuting the accused officers ``is reaffirming and reinforcing the impunity of the armed forces.'' The FMLN letter accused the army of promoting and preventing prosecution of senior military officers implicated in the slayings _ accusations which have also been made by some members of the U.S. Congress. The meetings, which began Friday at a San Jose hotel, were the fourth in a series aimed at ending the war. The previous round last month, also held in San Jose, led to a partial agreement on human rights. It gives the United Nations authority to monitor human rights in the country following a cease-fire.

Brendan O'Rourke, a boy embraced by Pope John Paul II in 1987 in a symbolic gesture of compassion and acceptance of people with AIDS, died Friday of an AIDS-related illness at age 7. Brendan, who was born prematurely and contracted the disease from a blood transfusion at the age of 2 months, died at the University of California, San Francisco Medical Center, the hospital said. The cause of death wasn't given. The boy's mother, Elaine O'Rourke, said Brendan was hospitalized with pneumonia last month. A photograph of the pope reaching through a crowd to embrace the boy during the 1987 papal visit to the United States was printed in newspapers around the world.
DOC.HEAD: George Seabrook Wing_
DOC.TEXT: George Seabrook Wing, an aeronautical engineer who invented the fastener used in nearly all aircraft and some spacecraft as well, died Tuesday at age 74. A self-taught engineer, Wing invented the ``Hi-Shear Rivet'' first used in the P-51 Mustang, the workhorse World War II fighter plane. The rivet was one-third lighter than previous fasteners and has since been used on all types of commercial and military aircraft, as well as NASA's Apollo missions to the moon. A native of Kewanee, Wis., he worked at several aviation companies, designing the fastener while at North American Aviation. In 1943, he left to found the company that became Hi-Shear Corp. in the Los Angeles suburb of Torrance, a maker of fasteners, explosive separation devices, boosters and rivet-making tools. Wing died at Torrance Medical Center after a brief battle with cancer.

Dallas Denver Bixler, who won a gold medal in gymnastics at the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, died Monday at age 80. He was the only U.S. male gymnast to win an Olympic gold medal until 1984, when Peter Vidmar won. Bixler used a new dismount, the reverse giant, in his last horizontal bar routine to pass two Finnish athletes and claim the gold. Bixler carried the Olympic torch for one kilometer before the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. After the Olympic victory, he worked at bank, served in the Merchant Marine and taught school in Los Angeles. He died at a nursing home.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Preserves Independence of Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Times Publishing Co. settled a stock feud with Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass that company officials said Friday preserved independent control of the St. Petersburg Times. The publishing company agreed to recapitalization, including redemption of its preferred stock, the parties announced in a joint statement. In return the Bass group is dismissing its suit against the Times. ``The agreement assures the long-term independence, journalistic control and competitive vigor of the St. Petersburg Times, as well as significant ongoing support for the Poynter Institute,'' said Andrew Barnes, chairman of Times Publishing. David Bonderman, managing partner for the Bass group, Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd., said the settlement was in everyone's best interest. The partnership includes the nieces of the late Eleanor Poynter Jamison, sister of founder Nelson Poynter, who ran the paper for 30 years. ``We always believed this to be a good investment and are happy we could work with Andy Barnes to help end a family dispute that has brewed for years,'' Bonderman said. Earlier this year, the Bass group made a $270 million buyout offer for Times Publishing Co., parent firm of the newspaper, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. The Bass group owned 40 percent of the voting stock but got only 5.7 percent of the dividends of Times Publishing Co. under an unusual stock arrangement. The partnership sought a better return on its investment and maintained directors had an obligation to recall preferred stock, as allowed by bylaws, at $106 a share or $318,000. But the Times defended the stock arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of the Poynter Institute, which essentially controls the newspaper. The institute offers education and national conferences to journalists and students. As a result of the settlement the publishing company is incurring debt, said Barnes, who is editor and president of the Times. The debt should not affect operations, said Barnes. who also is chairman of the Poynter Institute and chief executive officer of the Times Holding Co. as well as Times Publishing. Nelson Poynter, who ran the paper for 30 years, had set up a unique way to keep a profitable daily newspaper in the hands of journalists, free from control of outsiders or even his family. He established the not-for-profit journalism school, which ultimately is the major stockholder of the newspaper. Times Publishing is owned largely by Times Holding Co., which in turn is owned almost entirely by the non-profit Poynter Institute for Media Studies. State Attorney General Bob Butterworth had intervened in the suit on behalf of the Poynter Institute, which he said was threatened by the Bass partnership. Butterworth said he was pleased with the settlement, but disturbed by the agreement by the parties not to comment on terms or related matters. ``This office will take whatever steps are available to ensure that the state has sufficient information to determine that the settlement, in fact does not have an adverse impact on the Poynter Institute's beneficiaries, including the state university system and Tampa Bay-area public schools,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Warship Tranits Suez Canal
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. ship carrying Army, Navy and Air Force equipment sailed through the Suez Canal late Friday bound for the Red Sea, canal authorities said. The motor vessel Advantage was the only warship in a convoy of commercial ships, authorities at Suez and Port Said said _ the third convoy passing through from the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea on Friday. The vessel, known as a prepositioning ship, carries equipment and supplies to sustain combat operations. Its final destination was not available. A massive buildup of U.S. military power has taken place in and around the Persian Gulf to protect Saudi Arabia following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Egypt last week allowed the nuclear-powered U.S. aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower through the Suez Canal. The carrier is now deployed in the Red Sea with other U.S warships to barricade Iraqi trade. The U.S. battleship Wisconsin is expected to transit the Suez Canal Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Execs Say Reebok Using PUSH
DOC.TEXT: Top executives of Nike Inc. said Friday their chief competitor, Reebok International Ltd., was using Operation PUSH to try to gain an advantage in the hotly competitive athletic shoe market. Operation PUSH, a civil rights organization founded in Chicago by Jesse Jackson, called last Saturday for a boycott of Nike products. PUSH said it was dissatisfied with Nike's record in hiring and doing business with blacks. At a news conference, Nike chairman Philip H. Knight and president Richard K. Donahue said Nike would hold no more meetings with PUSH to discuss the subject. ``PUSH is being manipulated by Reebok to the advantage of Reebok and to the disadvantage of PUSH,'' Donahue said. Knight said the boycott had not affected Nike's business. ``Our dispute is not with the black community, it is with PUSH,'' he said. Reebok executives did not return calls Friday. A woman at PUSH headquarters in Chicago answered the telephone with the admonition, ``Say No to Nike.'' Two separate requests for comment were relayed to the executive offices, but the calls were not returned Friday. Nike, based in the Portland suburb Beaverton, made $243 million last year on sales of $2.2 billion. Reebok made $175 million on sales of $1.8 billion. Operation PUSH says blacks comprise 30 percent of the market for Nike's shoes and should got more jobs and business from the company. In the past, PUSH has gotten signed ``covenants'' calling for greater opportunity for blacks from companies including Coca Cola and Burger King. The two executives said 21 percent of the Nike employees hired in the United States since January have been minorities. They refused to break down that figure to show the role blacks play at Nike. Donahue said that would divert the public focus from Nike's efforts to build a culturally diverse company. ``I think it is wrong to target and focus on one segment of the minority community,'' he said. Nike's goals include naming a minority to the board of directors within a year and a minority vice president within two years, the executives said. Nike was the first sneaker company targeted because it is the biggest. But Donahue said Reebok was excluded from PUSH's questionnaires to athletic shoe companies. Nike began providing information to PUSH last month but abruptly stopped after finding that Reebok had purchased an ad in a PUSH magazine, he said. Nike asked PUSH for information on its relationship with Reebok, he said. ``The response was outrage,'' Donahue said. Nike uses prominent blacks in its television advertising campaigns. Football and baseball star Bo Jackson, basketball star David Robinson and Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson are featured in a current series of Nike ads urging young people to stay in school and stay away from drugs. Donahue said several Nike stars, including basketball player Michael Jordan, had issued statements supporting Nike in the face of the boycott. A spokeswoman in New York for filmmaker Spike Lee, who appears in Nike ads, said Lee had no comment.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Bring New Proposal to Salvador Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran guerrillas entering a new round of peace talks with the government said Friday they have a new plan to overcome differences over the future of the armed forces. Representatives of the Salvadoran government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were to meet Friday evening for the fourth round in a current series of talks aimed at ending El Salvador's civil war. ``We bring a new proposal which develops, broadens and specifies what we presented earlier on the theme of the armed forces,'' said Schafik Handal, one of the rebel negotiators. ``The subject of restructuring the armed forces will be the principal point of this meeting,'' said rebel spokesman Miguel Saenz. He said the front is demanding that the army disband its elite U.S.-trained Atlacatl Battalion ``because it is one of those that have committed the most massacres of the people.'' The battalion was the first Salvadoran unit to be trained by the United States, which supports the government and armed forces of President Alfredo Cristiani with about $1 million per day in aid. Rebels and government negotiators earlier agreed to try for a cease-fire in September. But the government has balked at rebel proposals for trimming the armed forces and purging officers implicated in human rights abuses. At least 72,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in the 10-year-old war between the leftist FMLN guerrillas and the Salvadoran military. Many of the victims were killed by right-wing death squads with ties to the military and Cristiani's ARENA party. The third round of talks last month in San Jose led to a partial pact on human rights and a separate agreement to let a United Nations commission monitor human rights after a cease-fire. The army currently has 54,000 soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Keeps Deliberating in Jogger Trial
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the Central Park jogger case ended their ninth day of deliberations Friday without a verdict. Jurors heard testimony read back to them about a ring of fire that some witnesses reported seeing in the park on the night of the attack. Its relevance to the trial was unclear. The jury also reviewed a videotaped statement Antron McCray made to police. In it, McCray said he kicked the victim and feigned sex with her. Two police officers testified that they saw the ring of fire in the same area and at about the same time the woman jogger was attacked April 19, 1989. Defendant Yusef Salaam, the only one of the three defendants to take the stand, also testified that he saw the fire. Justice Thomas Galligan excused the jurors Friday night and told them to resume deliberations late Saturday morning. Also Friday, Galligan denied a defense motion for a mistrial. Michael Joseph, McCray's attorney, said he sought the mistrial because he did not want the jurors to reach a verdict while they were tired. Earlier in the day, the jury finished hearing testimony read back to them from McCray's parents, Bobby and Linda McCray. Bobby McCray testified he told his son to confess to crimes he did not commit in the hope that police would then let the teen-ager go free. Linda McCray said police investigators yelled at her son to coerce a confession. McCray, 16, Salaam, 16 and Raymond Santana, 15, are accused of raping and trying to kill a jogger on her nightly run in Central Park. The jogger eventually recovered and returned to her job as a Wall Street investment banker. She testified that she suffers from impaired balance, vision and smell as a result of the attack and cannot recall what happened that night.

Pearl Bailey, the singer and actress known for her throaty drawl, her wit and warmth, is dead at 72. Her standbys included ``Hello, Dolly!'' and ``Bill Bailey, Won't You Please Come Home.'' Bailey collapsed Friday evening at a Holiday Inn where she had been staying with her husband, jazz drummer Louis Bellson. She was visiting her two sisters, Eura Robinson and Virgie Murray, and undergoing physical therapy. She died half an hour after being admitted to Thomas Jefferson Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Kellyann McDonell. The cause of death was not immediately known. Bailey had a history of heart ailments and underwent surgery last month to replace her arthritic left knee with a metal and plastic joint.

The Energy Department's delay in announcing its revised cost of the superconducting super collider amid reports of a $3 billion jump confirms that the atom-smasher project ``is way out of control,'' a congressional critic charges. The announcement had been expected Friday, but the Energy Department said the four groups making the estimates are still working out differences. The revised figure would be ready by Sept. 7, the department said. In a letter to Rep. Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, Deputy Energy Secretary Henson Moore said the ``reconciliation process is still under way.'' He gave no more explanation. On July 25, Moore said the four groups would try to have a final figure Aug. 17.

Six months after Soviet tanks began rolling out, the Rolling Stones have rolled in, marking a high point for the new cultural freedom long denied by the country's ousted Communist rulers. The band plays for the first time in Czehoslovakia today at Prague's Strahov Stadium, listed in the Guiness Book of World Records as the world's largest, with a capacity for 240,000 people. ``It's a great opportunity for us to play to people who could never hear us before,'' Keith Richards, the band's lead guitarist said in a documentary aired Thursday on state television. Proceeds of the concert will go to the Czechoslovak Children's Foundation, which benefits handicapped children, Romanian refugees and victims of the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, according to media reports in London. The charity is headed by Olga Havel, wife of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel.

The Soviet Union is facing a crime wave, and it's turning for help to the city that gave the world ``Scarface'' Al Capone and the St. Valentine's Day Massacre. The Soviets are hunting down the latest in crime-fighting techniques from lie detectors to fingerprinting networks to communication systems. ``Their interest really kind of shook me up,'' Matt L. Rodriguez, a deputy superintendent for the Chicago Police Department, said Friday. A six-member team will leave for Moscow next month to teach Soviet police how to deal with such antisocial phenomena as bank holdups, restaurant arson, mugging and auto chop shops.

USAir must let 8,000 employees vote again on whether to be represented by the Teamsters union, because the first organizing drive was tainted by illegal anti-union activities, a federal labor board says. The Teamsters had lost their bid to represent workers in a ballot count announced in January. But the National Mediation Board ruled Friday that actions by the airline interfered with the union's organizing campaign. The union may request a rerun election within 30 days. The Teamsters, who were trying to win the right to represent 8,000 workers who load airplanes at 180 airports around the country, had charged that USAir unfairly interfered with their organizing drive.
