For release Monday AMs, Aug. 20, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Some Are, Experts Say, but Not Like Savings and Loans
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: While politicians loudly ask who's to blame for the savings and loan mess, regulators and analysts are quietly asking a much more urgent question: Is commercial banking headed for disaster too? ``The answer is yes,'' said economist R. Dan Brumbaugh of Stanford University. ``We're already there.'' He believes that more banks would be declared insolvent _ and the government fund protecting $2.6 trillion in deposits at 12,500 banks would be broke _ if regulators stopped using outmoded accounting methods to determine when a bank has failed. No, said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which, through separate funds, guarantees both bank and thrift deposits up to $100,000 per account. ``We will be able ... to handle any failures we can currently foresee,'' he said. He vigorously disputes Brumbaugh's methodology and conclusions. But from another perspective, the two sides are not far apart. They are arguing about how bad the condition of the banking system is, not whether it is in bad or good shape. The bank insurance fund is ``in a very much stressed position,'' Seidman conceded at a recent Senate hearing. Because bank deposits are nearly triple the $930 billion held by savings institutions, the bank insurance fund's health has always been potentially even more critical than the condition of the now-bankrupt Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. The funds were established half a century ago to restore confidence in the nation's financial system after a wave of bank and S&L failures swept the nation during the Depression, wiping out the savings of thousands of Americans. For decades, both funds thrived, supported by insurance premiums paid by member institutions. But so many savings and loans failed during the 1980s that taxpayers had to rescue the S&L fund at a cost now estimated as high as $500 billion over 40 years _ $2,000 for every man, woman and child in the nation. The bank fund has so far been able to handle bank failures, though the balance has been dropping for three years now. And if it falls to zero in the 1990s, taxpayers would have to bail out banks, too. The bank fund, which ended 1987 with $18.3 billion, lost $4.24 billion in 1988, when bank failures hit a post-Depression high of 221. That was its first decline ever. When another 207 banks failed last year, it lost an additional $851 million. Failures remain high in 1990 _ 121 through Aug. 16 _ and Seidman has estimated the fund will lose around $2 billion, reducing it to near $11 billion. A key ratio measuring the fund's health has been deteriorating even longer. In 1963, the FDIC had $1.50 for every $100 in deposits. By 1981, that had gradually eroded to $1.24. As failures soared during the 1980s, the ratio plummeted. After this year's loss, Seidman estimates it will be between 50 cents and 60 cents. Last week, his board proposed emergency action to battle the decline, preliminarily endorsing a 62-percent increase in the insurance premium banks pay. It is the maximum increase allowed by law. The move would increase the FDIC's premium income from $2.8 billion in 1990 to $4.8 billion in 1991. Much of the added expense will be passed on to depositors through higher fees for checking accounts and other services. Analysts, however, say the added income would provide only a little extra protection for taxpayers should soaring oil prices trigger a recession and another wave of bank failures. ``The wild card right now in all these forecasts is Iraq,'' said economist Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based, liberal think tank. ``Clearly, right now the fund is skating on the edge. It is conceivable that it could get by if the economy escapes a recession and if oil prices stabilize in the low- to mid-$20s'' a barrel, he said. ``However, Iraq could change all that.'' If the recession was deep, bank troubles in the 1990s could dwarf those of the 1980s, which occurred despite an unprecedented eight years of expansion in the national economy. An additional worry is that bank regulators, like S&L regulators before them, would be tempted to allow insolvent banks to remain open. Then, with federal insurance guaranteeing their deposits, the banks would have every motive to take wild risks. If they win, they avoid bankruptcy. If they lose, taxpayers pay. A few analysts, like Brumbaugh, contend that is already happening. ``The FDIC's behavior is deja vu all over again and it is irresponsible,'' he said. However, others believe that, with the lesson of the S&L mess still fresh, bank regulators would appeal for taxpayer assistance much earlier and Congress would respond more quickly. Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., who made his reputation with early predictions of disaster for the savings and loan fund, said comparisons between banks and S&Ls are overdone. ``Banks are fundamentally sounder institutions. ... And, basically, the FDIC has not been sweeping the problems under the rug to the extent that the (thrift regulators) were,'' he said. The root of the S&L crisis was planted when the institutions were created. They borrowed deposits short-term and lent the money long-term to home buyers. When inflation pushed interest rates past 20 percent they had to pay more interest on their deposits than they were earning on their mortgages. Cures applied in the early `80s _ expansion into new lending areas coupled with lax oversight _ only worsened the problem. The roots of banking's woes are different, but still formidable. In the 1970s, the nation's largest banks had lent billions of dollars to Third World countries, who by the 1980s were defaulting. By the mid-80s, small farm banks began collapsing, along with agriculture commodity and farm land prices. Then came the drop in oil prices, triggering a collapse in real estate values in the Southwest. Now, real estate problems have spread to the Northeast and are threatening the Southeast, Southern California and even a few Midwestern cities. Longer-term, innovations in the financial system are eroding banks' profitability. Their best deposit customers have been lured to money market mutual funds. Their largest and most credit-worthy borrowers raise money by issuing commercial paper, a service that banks are substantially barred from delivering along with other securities underwriting. Banks' defenders point out that the industry earned a record $24.8 billion in 1988 and a respectable $15.7 billion in 1989. Critics, however, say that does little to reduce the potential for disaster. Although commercial banks collectively earned $6.2 billion in the first three months of this year, 10 percent of them lost money and 1,058 were considered ``problem'' institutions by the FDIC. ``Ten percent can easily send you under. Deep under,'' Litan said. ``The 10 percent of the banks that are unprofitable ... hold roughly the same assets that the open, but insolvent thrifts held in the mid-1980s. We saw what they could do.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Aug. 20

DOC.HEAD: American Will to Fight _ Has It Eroded?
DOC.TEXT: In 1945, America had willpower. At a cost of 400,000 lives, with grim determination, it had waged global war for four years, stopping only when Germany and Japan were vanquished. In 1990, does America have willpower? Have 45 years of instant victories _ such as the Dominican Republic, Grenada and Panama _ and long, divisive wars that ended in stalemate or defeat _ Korea and Vietnam _ sapped the resolve of the United States to sustain a fight? As Saddam Hussein gains stature as an American bogeyman, and as the whole of Saudi Arabia becomes an American military base, the questions no longer are rhetorical. Some historians and others suggest that American willpower is and always was conditional. Given a real reason to fight, Americans will fight, they say; given a vague purpose and mounting casualties, they will carp. Militarily, the U.S. strategy has been to play for time. The blockade of Iraq aims to force Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait _ eventually. The troops in Saudi Arabia await an Iraqi invasion that may never come. And if hostilities do break out, no one expects a quick resolution; Iraq is not Grenada. No one knows whether Americans have the will to support a lengthy, costly war in the Middle East over oil supplies. ``I don't think there's any doubt that if there's a clear and present danger, if there's a Pearl Harbor, Americans would fight a 20-year war if they had to,'' said James Reston, retired columnist for The New York Times. ``The United States tends to remain at peace or to go to war wholeheartedly, in a crusade,'' said Robert Maddox, a professor of history at the Pennsylvania State University. ``Americans demand total victory. They want that victory, and then they want to go about their business,'' he said. ``They are no good at dragged-out conflicts, without any resolution, no cities taken.'' Few American wars have been supported across the board. During the American Revolution, Tories fled to Canada. During the War of 1812, several New England states threatened to secede. Abraham Lincoln had to deal with copperheads, as Southern sympathizers were known in the North. The Spanish-American War was short, but the civil war that followed in the Philippines dragged on, spurring American protests led by Mark Twain. Even the American involvement in World War I, which lasted just a year and a half, inspired disapproval _ if only in retrospect. ``By the 1930s, there was a widespread belief among the American people that World War I was a mistake. And we won that war,'' said Tom Smith, director of general social survey at the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. The anti-war attitude _ fostered by reports of war profiteering, and by the sense that the war accomplished nothing _ hindered Franklin Roosevelt as he tried to bring the United States into World War II. ``Pearl Harbor was an enormously unifying experience,'' said John Morton Blum, professor at Yale and author of ``V was for Victory,'' a history of the homefront. ``There was more unity than in any of the other wars.'' Still, there are indications war support was not monolithic, at least when the number of casualties escalated. At the end of 1944, more than 20 percent of those polled favored striking a deal with Hitler. And in its last year, letters and articles were written decrying the cost of the war in the Pacific, where battles with the Japanese on island after island exacted a heavy toll, said Richard Lingeman, author of the homefront history ``Don't You Know There's a War On?'' ``People were screaming about it. When they dropped the bomb, there was some relief, I think,'' said Lingeman. In Korea and Vietnam, too, war support declined as casualties climbed. John Mueller, a professor of political science at the University of Rochester, found that support dropped 15 percent when the number of casualties increased from 1,000 to 10,000; it dropped another 15 percent when casualties climbed from 10,000 to 100,000. The figures for the two wars were identical, though one was conducted under the United Nations flag and one was not; though one was thoroughly televised (a factor often blamed for opposition to the Vietnam War) and one was not. Any democracy is likely to face similar obstacles during wartime, Mueller suggested. But an authoritarian regime, like Iraq's, may be able quash that kind of opposition, at least for a while. What would inspire Americans to accept casualties over the long haul? Another Pearl Harbor, of course. Identifiable enemies help: ``We've always needed a recognizable foe _ a Kaiser Bill who we were going to hang from the old apple tree, a Hitler,'' said Penn State's Maddox. President Bush has taken pains to compare Iraq with the expansionist Germany of the 1930s. Mostly, Americans need a clear and compelling reason. ``Sustained belligerancy with homefront morale is directly related to purpose,'' said Blum, the World War II historian. ``That's what was lacking in Vietnam,'' said Frances FitzGerald, author of the Vietnam history ``Fire in the Lake.'' ``It had nothing to do with national willpower.'' Would a threat to oil inspire such dedication? Oil is vital. ``We're not talking about selling some bolts of calico cloth or cheap trinkets,'' the kind of economic interests that sparked American shows of force in the 19th century, said Maddox. Still, Lingeman recalled that in the months before Pearl Harbor, opponents of intervention said they would not go to war for rubber, a vital commodity that was tied up in the conflict. ``The idea of an economic war, I don't think it will take. I think people would make (economic) sacrifices before they would go to war,'' he said. Reston agreed that barring further provocation, American support for a war with Iraq would wilt in the burning sun of the Saudi desert. ``Once the shooting starts, the tendency is to rally 'round the flag. But for a long, long time? No, I don't think so,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 19

DOC.HEAD: Housing Price Collapse? Not By the Numbers
DOC.TEXT: One of the strangest things about the so-called collapse of housing prices is that you can't detect it in some of the statistics. It's as if the numbers were added up incorrectly. In the second quarter of the year, for instance, the median selling price of existing single-family houses was 3.4 percent above the figure for a year earlier _ in defiance, you might say, of the popular impression. And a National Association of Realtors survey of existing-home sales revealed that second-quarter prices were higher than a year earlier in 70 of 98 metropolitan areas. In some, the price jumps were huge. Topping the list was the Seattle-Tacoma area, where the second-quarter median price leaped 35.3 percent over the previous year; Honolulu, where prices rose 33.2 percent; and Sacramento, Calif., where the rise was 30 percent. Figures such as these prove again that many national averages and medians are hardly sound guides for measuring local markets. Unlike stocks and bonds, where prices really are national, real estate prices are strictly local. What happens in Portland, Ore., where the median rose 15.8 percent, has little bearing on what happens in the Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon, N.J., area, where the median price fell 9.5 percent, steepest in the nation. Only one Midwest metropolitan area recorded a decrease, but four in the West, 10 in the Northeast and 11 in the South posted drops. Even within states there were differences: New York fell 6.1 percent, Albany rose 2.6 percent. What the figures reveal clearly is that there indeed are regions of extreme price weakness, but that these areas do not merge into a national collapse, as so often is stated. Why, therefore, the sense among homeowners that the marketplace is a disaster? For one thing, excessively high hopes that led many sellers to overprice. The inevitable price cut that followed might have left the price higher than a year earlier, but the sense of money lost remains. A lengthening of the time it takes to sell a house contributes to the feeling of a down market. In some areas of the Northeast the median selling time is close to 300 days, vs. a few weeks just four years ago. Adding to the feeling of a dead market is the more critical attitude of buyers. They are more selective, more patient, more inclined to negotiate than to buy immediately. And, of course, lenders are tighter than ever. For those sellers who can bide their time, the selling delay is hardly the disaster it is for those who must sell. These are the sales that provide the anecdotal evidence of a market collapse. They are not easily forgotten. In many communities, for example, real estate agents advertise that they sold houses within a week after listing, the suggestion being that they provided the seller with an extra measure of marketplace expertise. Query them and you find that the seller urgently required a quick sale, and that the listing agent priced the house well below market. Patient buyers learn a lot about pricing, and often act quickly when they spot a steal. No amount of statistical evidence is likely to dispel the notion that there has been a national housing price collapse. Too many people have indeed been hurt financially, and millions of others are unnerved on hearing about them. But so far the national housing disaster you hear so much about has happened more in the mind than in the numbers.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Financial Futures To Debut In U.S. At Last
DOC.TEXT: Chicago's giant commodity exchanges are readying their long-delayed Japanese financial futures products for a September launch, but they concede they have no hope of becoming the world leaders in those markets. That distinction belongs to, and will continue to belong to two Japanese stock exchanges that have been trading futures on the Nikkei 225 and TOPIX stock indexes for nearly two years and on Japanese government bonds for even longer. The Chicago exchanges say they will settle for being secondary markets. It is a role to which they are not accustomed but which will nevertheless reinforce their presence in the global financial marketplace. ``With a Nikkei 225 contract available for trading in North America, investors in the Japanese stock market will have a means of protection after their regular trading day ends,'' said John Geldermann, chairman of the Merc's board of governors. On Sept. 25, the Merc will launch its Nikkei 225 futures and futures-options contracts, followed two days later by the Board of Trade's introduction of futures and futures-options on the TOPIX stock index and Japanese government bonds. The contracts will give investors, mainly large institutional investors, more places in which to essentially buy insurance against losses on Japanese stocks and bonds. The Chicago markets are not likely to generate as much volume as their Japanese counterparts, though, because they will be open for trading mainly during the U.S. business day, which is nighttime in Japan. Spokesman Michael O'Connell said the Board of Trade also will list its Japanese products for trading during the exchange's 2{-hour evening session, which corresponds to the opening of the Japanese trading day. Futures on the Nikkei 225, Japan's version of the Dow Jones industrial average, are traded on the Osaka Securities Exchange. The TOPIX is an index based on all 1,100 stocks listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the world's largest. The Tokyo exchange trades TOPIX futures and Japanese government bond futures. The futures are contracts to buy or sell stocks and bonds at some future date at a price agreed upon in advance. Investors can use the contracts to offset their risk in the underlying cash markets or speculate on market movements. Strategists at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange began designing the new products at least five years ago, at a time when Japanese laws forbade financial futures trading on Japanese exchanges. The Chicago exchanges hoped to capitalize on the situation by creating their own risk-management tools for Japanese investors as well as for others who invest in the Japanese financial markets. The potential rewards were enormous, as the Chicago exchanges already had proven with the remarkable success of their U.S. government bond and stock-index futures. Those products transformed the Merc and Board of Trade from sleepy agricultural commodity markets to world-class financial exchanges. The Chicago exchanges won U.S. regulatory approval for the contracts in 1988 at about the same time that the Japanese government relaxed restrictions on such products at home. The result was that the Chicago exchanges helped the Japanese develop their own markets for financial futures in exchange for the rights to trade those same contracts in the United States. O'Connell said the Board of Trade considers it important to offer the contracts even though the exchange has no expectation of overtaking the Japanese markets in trading volume. ``With the marketplace becoming so international in scope, it behooves us to compete on the international scene,'' he said. O'Connell said the exchange also plans to introduce futures on various European government bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Uncle Sam Vs. Uncle Saddam Makes Bad Economic Numbers Look Worse
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has combined with alarming U.S. economic statistics to make even some upbeat forecasters tilt their outlooks toward the gloomy side. Many now believe the Federal Reserve faces an ever more treacherous minefield in charting a course for U.S. interest rates over the next several months. The key worry is that evidence disclosed this past week on consumer prices, construction and trade depict an economy leaning dangerously toward both recession and higher inflation even before the U.S.-Iraq faceoff in the Gulf, which has sent crude oil prices skyward. ``I think the statistics still point to slow growth, and the consumer price statistic suggested inflation hasn't been contained,'' said Marilyn Schaja, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities Corp. in New York. ``It suggests there was some kind of pre-Iraq problem.'' The most troubling figure came from the Labor Department, which said consumer prices rose 0.4 percent in July, when oil prices were falling. Economists said this means when the full impact of rising oil prices is felt in August and beyond, inflation could surge toward an annualized rate of 7 percent or more for 1990. That would be the worst in nine years and underscore the growing U.S. addiction to foreign oil, which now accounts for half the country's consumption of 17 million barrels a day. ``Oil is in every product and the price will be reflected in every single good,'' said James Chessen, deputy director of policy development at the American Bankers Association in Washington. ``We'll see a significant rise. I'm pretty worried about that.'' One of the Federal Reserve's principal jobs is to restrain inflation through its influence over interest rates, pushing them up when inflation rises and easing when the economy slows. Before the July inflation numbers were revealed, it was widely assumed that the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policymaking arm, would take subtle steps to depress interest rates at a regular meeting this coming week. But now many economists say they don't believe that will happen for a while. Further complicating the picture is the heavy debt burden the economy is carrying. Easing interest rates would only add to the toll being exacted by the budget deficit, the savings & loan bailout, bankruptcies and high levels of corporate debt. ``I think the Fed is in an odd position now,'' Chessen said. ``They don't want to move aggressively to counter the inflationary effects of the Mideast, yet they worry what it means in the long term if they don't.'' Another worrisome statistic of the week was a 2.6 percent decline in housing starts for July reported by the Commerce Department, the sixth straight monthly decline in an industry that many economists say is clearly in a recession and needs a dose of lower interest rates to revive. The Commerce Department also reported the trade deficit for June dropped to a seven-year low because of record exports. In other times that might have been good news but instead was seen as an aberration. Economists said the trade report didn't reflect the subsequently higher price of oil, which is likely to swell the U.S. import bill and discourage some foreign countries from buying U.S. goods. ``These trade numbers were computed when oil was $14-$15 a barrel,'' said Gary Ciminero, chief economist of Fleet Financial Group, a Providence, R.I.-based banking company. ``Add at least $10 to that and figure it out.'' Not all economists viewed the higher price of oil with a sense of foreboding. Some argued that when priced in 1990 dollars, oil still remains far below the levels of 10 years ago. Even if oil remains in the $25-$30 range, they said, oil is only one element of the inflation picture. Others say comparisons to previous oil-price shocks of the `70s are flawed and misleading, because other forces were at work in those times, such as sharply higher wages and a rapidly expanding money supply, which were pushing inflation up relentlessly. ``We used to have an economy with a lot of built-in price pressures, spirals in all sorts of things,'' said Thomas F. Carpenter, of ASB Capital Management in Washington. ``Those things are absent. All areas are soft.'' Still, Carpenter said, oil's rise will permeate the economy with higher prices. ``You can't get around it.'' End adv for weekend editions Aug. 18-19

DOC.HEAD: For Weekend Editions Aug. 18-19
Stock Market Follows Middle East, Sending Dow Sliding
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street's obsession with news from the Middle East has displaced corporate reports and other traditional signposts of the stock market's direction, sending prices plunging as optimism wanes. The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 254 points since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and stood at 2,644.80 by Friday. The conflict ended talk of the Dow average breaking 3,000 this year. Some analysts don't expect the price slide to stop anytime soon. ``Generally, trends tend to go farther than you think they will go,'' said A.C. Moore, research director at Argus Research Corp. The New York investment house believes the Dow average will touch 2,550 or even lower before the Iraqi situation stabilizes. Robert L. Kahan, manager of equity trading at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco, said he believes stock prices will keep dropping ``until something definitive happens'' in the Mideast. ``The market does not like uncertainty,'' he said. But not all market watchers are so pessimistic. Michael Metz, a managing director of Oppenheimer & Co., said he believes the Dow average will only drop 20 or 40 points more before the market enters a recovery. ``I would be amazed if the market would close below 2,600 this year,'' he said. ``It's always the case when everybody says `this market is going a lot lower and can't possibly go up' _ that's usually the time it's hitting the bottom.'' Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Co., wouldn't speculate how much farther stock prices may fall, but said he believes the market is oversold. ``You've taken an awful lot out. I would say you've got to rally at some point here,'' he said. ``You're probably awfully close to the end of panic selling.'' At that point, he said, bargain hunters should begin to enter the market, sending stock prices higher. Clough said the Mideast standoff did not set off the stock market's slide; instead, it only exploited soft market conditions that already existed. The economic trouble was evident in disappointing second-quarter corporate earnings released last month, he said. Moore said the market's turmoil reflects an underlying uncertainty about the world. ``We're realizing we don't have a great deal of control over the future as we seemingly did in the past with the move toward democracy and free markets,'' he said. Moore said he's never seen the market more sensitive to world events in the 20 years he has worked on Wall Street. There is ``lingering optimism'' in the market that the Iraqi stalemate will be resolved peacefully, but that optimism is starting to fade, he said. In addition, he said, ``You're starting to see more and more people talk about a probable recession.'' Should an all-out war erupt in the Mideast, analysts envision different scenarios for the market. Kahan predicted a war would send the Dow climbing because it finally would be evidence of some definitive action in the region. Metz said a war ``would spark a short-term nervous selloff and then the market would go up.'' Clough said a conflict would send oil prices even higher as supply concerns mounted, further destabilizing the market. ``Wars have never been good for financial markets,'' he said. The Mideast upheaval erased 71.78 points from the Dow this week, a drop of 2.6 percent. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 3.96 to 180.19 for the week; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 14.54 to 393.49; and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 7.71 to 331.61. Volume on the Big Board averaged 147.95 million shares a day, down from 181.29 million the week before.
